PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Republic
PETITION.PARA: A petition to the honourable the President and members of the Australian Senate in Parliament assembled.
This humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls upon the Australian Government to:
1.Ensure its members cease promoting Australia to become a Republic and to firmly uphold and maintain the existing Australian Constitution 1901 in its entirety and
2.Forthwith rescind the Australia Act 1986.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS (TASMANIA) REGULATIONS AND POLITICAL BROADCASTS (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY) REGULATIONS.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Senator Parer:

That the Political Broadcasts (Tasmania) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 482, and the Political Broadcasts (Australian Capital Territory) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 483, made under the Broadcasting Act 1942, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to a couple of matters raised by Senator Schacht and Senator Loosley. I listened to Senator Loosley with some care. I do not doubt that he was one who, some years prior to the introduction of this legislation, supported the banning of political television advertising, but I thought it not without consequence that the greater parts of Senator Schacht's speech and Senator Loosley's speech were justifying the banning of the advertising on pragmatic, political grounds. There was no ideological persuasion in Senator Loosley's proposition. He missed the one fundamental tenet. In fact, he described us as ideological zealots. He did not in any way deal with the question of people's rights.
—I was arguing the principle.

—He was not arguing to justify it on any ideological grounds; he was arguing on political and practical grounds, saying that television advertising was not an appropriate medium for conveying political messages.
—It would have been easier for you if that had been his argument, but it wasn't.
—I will come to that in a moment. It was interesting that Senator Schacht, the great civil libertarian of this chamber—
—I hope that is sarcastic.

—There was just a touch of base sarcasm in it. The truth of the matter is that Senator Schacht holds himself up as a civil libertarian, as the Chairman of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, but he seems to have this quaint notion that human rights and civil liberties begin at the very shores of Australia and extend out. I find it remarkable that Senator Schacht finds no difficulty in denying Australians the intrinsic and inherent right to watch television advertising if they so choose.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht made much of the fact that there has been, thus far, no great revolt on the streets as a result of the ban, and that was a measure of his approval. But it goes without saying that the identification card, about which we had an election, was not a major issue in that election. It was only after a subsequent awakening and awareness by the community of the implications of that card that we had the revolt that swept right across Australia. In due course the majority of Australians will take great exception to this legislation.

Senator Schacht also has some quaint notion that all wisdom and knowledge resides in Canberra. He had no difficulty whatsoever with the fact that the legislation imposed itself upon State elections and local government elections. I find it absolutely outrageous that the Federal Government believes that in some way it ought to be responsible for controlling the manner and the method of political advertising not only for State elections but also for local government elections. I find it an arrogance, an impertinence, which is breathtaking in its width.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in my view, it is not for the Government or for the Parliament to decide what is the most effective form of political advertising. It is inconsequential that, in the last election in California, which I think Senator Loosley referred to, 90c of every dollar was spent on television advertising—as if there were something inherently wrong with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disproportionate spending. It might be 90c under the regulations.

—Senator Loosley may see it as disproportionate spending, but when he was the General Secretary of the Labor Party in New South Wales the overwhelming majority of his expenditure at election times was on television advertising, because he made a judgment that it was the most effective communicator of the Labor Party's message.
—Between 50c and 60c in the dollar.

—Surely the honourable senator is not going to suggest that at the last election the television advertisements in respect of Kakadu National Park—when he had given up on his own voters and was seeking the Green voters—were not effective. Surely he is not suggesting that they did not persuade people to cast their vote for the Greens, and that because his Party happened to be higher than ours on the Green ticket the preferences were not running very heavily towards his Party. It was a very effective way of communicating a message—a dishonest message, a bland message, an untrue message but an effective message.
—But there are dangers on relying overwhelmingly on television advertising.

—It is a judgment for political parties to make, as to where one spends one's money. We have been through High Court cases about truth in political advertising. There is still relief to be had in the courts, however, in certain circumstances. The truth of the matter is that political parties invariably will spend the money where they judge it to have the most effective results. Senator Loosley talked about glossy, slick slogans; I think he referred to `Turn on the Lights' as one and `It's Time' as the other.
—And `Wran's the Man'.

—Yes, `Wran's the Man' was the third one. I thank Senator Parer. Putting aside `Wran's the Man', because I think that was a misplaced slogan, the other two were effective. What they did was to articulate an emotional, subliminal feeling of the time. There was a feeling, perhaps latent, in the community at the time that it was time, and the slogan captured that feeling. The object of political advertising is not to create new information, but to articulate the feelings, even if latent, that people already have. To that extent, both those slogans were effective. `Turn on the Lights' was a very effective slogan. We had been through a period of darkness in Australia and that slogan very effectively picked up that feeling.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that this legislation and these regulations are not about a government that is making, on behalf of the Australian people, a judgment as to where expenditure should be or expenditure should not be, what is the most effective way of advertising and what is not the most effective way of advertising. Quite frankly, it is none of its business to make those judgments. They are commercial judgments and political judgments, to be made by political parties—as are policies, as are platforms, as are issues and as are attitudes towards issues. The truth is that this legislation is brought before us because the Labor Party is going into the next Federal election without hope, without policies, without money and without any likelihood of any of those three elements changing in dimension. We now find that there is a ban on rights and freedoms of speech as a result of the crude politics this Government is seeking to play.

Perhaps there was, in a not too obtuse way, no more practical example of this Government's fear of freedom of speech, and a comparison between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party, when recently we had Her Majesty the Queen in Parliament House. The Government allowed the Queen to come into King's Hall for two hours or an hour and a half to meet a number of Australian people, but denied her an opportunity to speak. In the normal course of events, if the Queen had spoken, John Hewson would have spoken. If John Hewson had spoken, he would have created an odious comparison between himself and the new Prime Minister, Paul Keating. Mr Keating had gone through that dubious pleasure on the occasion of the visit of George Bush and he was not going to have it repeated. So that Keating could not be compared with Hewson, the Queen was denied an opportunity to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shows him up for the fraud that he is.

—Yes, it does show him up. Putting aside his glib, pre-prepared, rude, crude and unattractive one-liners, when he is required to say something of moment, something of consequence, something of relevance, something of thoughtful meaning, of course he is found to be vacuous. In fear of that being ever so obvious, he denied the Queen and John Hewson an opportunity to speak.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that it is not any longer curious but consequential to note that the party that claimed to be made up of icons of people's intrinsic individual rights is the first to use them and abuse them when its political agenda requires it to do so. As I say, Senator Schacht claims a great concern for human rights. Senator Loosley claims to be concerned for human rights. I rather wonder what the Lionel Murphys of this world would be thinking now if they could see what this Government is doing to people's human rights. However, notwithstanding the corruption of this Government, there is no prospect of its being re-elected. No doubt, in due course, this legislation will be repealed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In exercising my right of reply, I rise to speak in support of my motion to disallow the Political Broadcasts (Tasmania) Regulations and Political Broadcasts (Australian Capital Territory) Regulations. To put the matter into perspective, I will just recount what it is all about. Honourable senators will remember that some 12 months ago this Government decided to introduce legislation which would have banned all paid political advertising on radio and television for 12 months of the year. It was the most draconian, outrageous legislation ever presented before this Parliament in respect of attacking freedom of speech and freedom of political expression.

PARA.TAB: As the legislation progressed, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) took a cocky view by saying that he was confident the legislation would be passed—legislation representing a total ban on political advertising for 365 days of the year, for ever. It became apparent that the reason for his confidence related to some shady backroom deal between himself and the then Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Powell. I can recall being jointly interviewed with Senator Kernot—who spoke on this matter yesterday—by one Haydn Sargent on radio in Brisbane. During that radio debate I remarked that it was apparent that some deal had been made. Senator Kernot, who at that time was throwing her hat in the ring for either leadership or deputy leadership of the Australian Democrats, said after a pause, `I sincerely hope not'.

The grassroots membership of the Democrats became concerned that the parliamentary members of their party, who had come in here supposedly to keep the so-and-sos honest, were making a deal on a principle for which there could be no compromise whatsoever. As a result, the Democrats changed leadership and remarked that under no circumstances would they support this attack on freedom of speech and freedom of political expression in Australia. Senator Coulter took over the leadership. As a result, because the Minister had lost the deal, the legislation was amended somewhat—not without a battle, I might say. It was only with the insistence of the Liberal and National parties that the legislation was forced before a select committee for investigation.

In the meantime, the Liberal Party, led by a task force committee comprising my colleagues Senator Olsen, Senator Kemp and me, engaged in a series of discussions around Australia. We called our own meetings and we found that every group in this country, with the exception of one or two—not surprisingly, one was the ACTU and I think the other one was Phillip Adams—

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACF, I think.

—And maybe the ACF—were appalled by this legislation. As a result of all that, the Senate Select Committee sat and heard the evidence. Of some hundreds of submissions made, only one or two supported this Government. Yet, simply because of the weight of numbers, the Senate Select Committee came out supporting the legislation. My colleagues opposed this attack on freedom of speech and freedom of political expression—not based on any ideological reason but simply on the weight of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Towards the end of last year the Government decided to make this an urgent Bill, guillotined it through the House of Representatives, and put on a time limit in respect of debate in the Senate. I believe it was the longest debate that has gone on since 1964. But to show the incompetence of this Government, and this Minister in particular, even then it did not get it right. That debate had to be adjourned because the formulas in regard to the allocation of free time, as pointed out by Senator Macdonald, were found to be absolutely incorrect. We had to have separate discussions outside this chamber in order to come back with some sort of formula that was more equitable than the one that had been suggested.

The Bill was eventually passed with the support of the Democrats—except, I might say, Senator Sowada, who stuck to her principles. At the time I made the remark that when the Democrats were offered the choice between principles and money, they took the money. Not only did they collect a whole lot of additional free advertising paid for by the radio and television stations of this country, but also they made the absolutely lunatic proposal that at every election in the future a photograph, a CV and a brief description of policy for every candidate in the country be presented to every elector. That would cost millions of dollars, and logistically I would say it would not be possible. In the main, from the date of nomination close to an election will be about 20 days. In that period, every candidate in this country will present the Electoral Commission with a photograph, a CV, and a brief policy description, and the Electoral Commission will be required to put that in the hands of every householder in Australia.

There are going to be some bizarre results out of all this. Imagine if you are the local cheap grocer. You can just pay your nomination fee and get your brochure distributed to every household in the electorate. That is the sort of stupidity that can come out of this. As I said, it is going to cost the taxpayers of Australia millions and millions of dollars yet again. These things do not come cheaply.

The Bill was eventually passed, with the support of the Democrats, and was sent over to Government House, where the Governor-General gave royal assent. At the same time, the Government tabled regulations in respect of the ACT and Tasmania, on which I moved the notice of the motion we are debating and finalising today to disallow those regulations.

What happened then? They were found yet again to be wrong. The regulations were submitted, but they were gazetted on 2 January for application on 1 January. That is not legal under the Acts Interpretation Act. I might say that the Government had five working days to get it right. Yet again this Minister showed his incompetence—and that of his Government—by not even getting that right. Subsequently, as has been mentioned by the Minister, they recognised that they had made a mistake. They brought out another set of regulations, and there were errors in those as well. So they brought out a third set of regulations.

I quite legitimately sought the advice of the Clerk of the Senate on this matter. These things are opinions. All legal opinions are opinions. They are not definitive. One only gets the definitive answer when one goes to the courts. On the advice given to me, it was apparent that there were no regulations in force. They were all invalid or void. So I sought an opinion from the Clerk of the Senate, which I am perfectly entitled to do. He, doing his job, is required to provide an unbiased view. I want to make that very clear. What did this grubby little Minister do yesterday? He came in here and criticised the Clerk for providing me with that information.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Senator Parer, I ask you to withdraw the word `grubby'. It is unparliamentary language.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the word `grubby'. This cowardly little Minister was guilty—
—`Cowardly' is also unparliamentary.

—I withdraw that. I will rephrase it: he was guilty of a cowardly and intimidatory attack on an officer of the Senate during the debate. What he did was to imply that what the Clerk did was improper. This was an absolutely disgraceful attack on the senior officer in the Senate, who was unable to defend himself. We are not surprised by the actions of these characters on the other side. That is their modus operandi. When they get advice that is not in keeping with what they want to tell the public, they attack someone who cannot defend himself or herself. If this Minister had any sense of decency he would apologise to the Clerk in the Senate. If he does not, I would suggest that the President should pull him into line and demand that he do so.

PARA.TAB: At the same time Senator Kernot, trying to defend herself because of their agreement to go along with the abominable legislation, asked in debate if I would advise her whether I got the permission of the Clerk of the Senate to provide the legal advice that he had given me. Let me point out that Senator Kernot has been here long enough to know. If people on the other side question that right, they should look at the 1988-89 annual report of the Department of the Senate wherein it states:

Most advice to Senators relating to the Senate and Committee proceedings, whether given in the Senate Chamber while the Senate is sitting or elsewhere, is given orally, but in recent years there has been a tendency for Senators to request, and the Clerk to provide, written advice on matters of any complexity. . .

Advice is given to Senators on a confidential basis, but it is always open to a Senator receiving advice to disclose it. In recent years there has been an increasing tendency, in accordance with the general greater openness of parliamentary processes, for Senators to disclose the advice they have received on particular matters. This has created an impression in some quarters that the Clerk and the Senate have undertaken some new or expanded advisory role. In fact, the advice which is now given covers the same areas relating to Senate and committee proceedings as advice which has always been given by Senate Clerks, and the only change is that more written advices are given and more of them are eventually disclosed. It is the view of the current Clerk that this openness—

SPEECH.PARA: which this Government does not want to know about, hence the ban on advertising—
which is determined by the Senators who receive the advice, should not be discouraged.
That is Senator Kernot's answer.

PARA.TAB: I provided a press release, and there was a lot of debate and thrashing around by the Minister, Senator Kernot, and a couple of others from the Labor side, which is not surprising, as to whether I should have used the word `if'. This is just scraping the bottom of the barrel. I attached the legal advice to the press statement so that people could read the legal advice and make up their own minds and determine whether the contents of my press release were correct.

When the inadequacy of his own legislation and his own regulations was drawn to the Minister's attention, his only response to me—he is not known for having great intellectual abilities; in fact, that is the overstatement of the day—was that I had been emotional and, would you believe, dishonest. Can anyone believe that that person, of all the people sitting on the other side, would have the audacity to accuse someone else of being dishonest? Of everyone on that side, he is the last one to do that, and he knows what I am talking about.

I said to him, through the media, who contacted me,`I have put my advice on the table; if you disagree with it, put your legal advice on the table'. In the debate here yesterday he was asked the same question and his answer was no, he would not but he would show it to the Leader of the Opposition in private. What is wrong with openness and honesty in government? I was prepared to say, `Here you are, here's my legal advice. It is not just the advice I have received from the Clerk, it is also additional advice which I sought and received from experts in the field at the University of Queensland, and they supported that view'. As I mentioned earlier, legal advice is the opinion of one or more people and there can be differing points of view. That is why we have courts of law. The Minister refused to respond and provide his legal advice.
I ask the Minister why he has not yet tabled the other regulations? Does he have in mind some other nefarious little scheme—for which he is renowned? I do not know the answer to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he realises they are not there.

—He probably does not realise an awful lot. The comment was also made, and I think I should respond to it, that everything has gone along fine since this legislation came in. Let me tell the Senate: it has not. For instance, and this was alluded to by some of my colleagues, the Liberal Party in Victoria was running a mid-term campaign on radio and television. Lo and behold, there was a by-election for a local government seat in Wagga in New South Wales. The regional radio stations in Victoria were told not to run the advertisements because they might affect the outcome of this by-election for a local government seat in Wagga—what made it more ludicrous in the end was that there was only one candidate—so the advertisements were taken off.

PARA.TAB: We also had the fascinating situation of two referenda running, one in Queensland and one in the Australian Capital Territory. In the Act, the definition of a referendum is one that seeks to change the Constitution. Neither of those referenda sought to change the Constitution. The one in the ACT was to determine whether the electoral system would be single member electorates or Hare-Clark and the one in Queensland was in respect of daylight saving.

In Queensland, those supporting and those opposing daylight saving ran a fairly emotional campaign on both sides, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you will appreciate; and they were entitled to do so. They were entitled to run paid ads. However, people in the ACT were not. On verbal advice and on legal advice, the radio and television stations refused to run the ads. Irrespective of the outcome of the referendum in Queensland, those people who ran the ads opposing daylight saving would probably claim that it was only by alerting the city people to the problems in the bush that they were able to get the referendum result that they did. That is the sort of thing, in a general election campaign, that this Government has banned. It is preventing people—individuals in society, not necessarily people standing for Parliament—from actually getting their point of view across.

I wrote to Mr Westerway of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, asking him on what basis the ads in the ACT were banned. After some days he responded to me. Basically, what he said was that the ABT was somewhat limited in what it could do. I can tell the Senate, because I have had feedback from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, that it, being the policeman for this legislation, does not like it one little bit. Frankly, I do not blame it. The Tribunal said that, with the exception of children's programs, it cannot assess material for broadcast before it has gone to air and that it can respond to complaints from viewers or listeners only after a program has been broadcast.

What does that mean? It means that the radio and television stations have to take the risk; and, if they are wrong, they run the risk of having their licences taken from them. Mr Acting Deputy President, it is akin to you or me going to a police station, being unsure of the law, and saying to the local sergeant of police, `If I do a certain action, will you arrest me and put me in gaol or not?'; and he responds and says, `Go and do it and, your having done it, I will then tell you whether you are guilty or not'. It is absolutely ludicrous, and it is indicative of the great shemozzle this legislation is and of the fact that it should never have been introduced and should be thrown out. The new Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has indicated that it needs amendment. My observation would be that his consideration of amendments will not be based on principles, on which our whole stand on this matter has been based, it will be based on political pragmatism. If he thinks it is going to advantage the Labour Party, he will do it. If he does not, he will not.

That is the sort of thing that is wrong with this country. It is the sort of reason why Dr Hewson is so much accepted out in the community. He is prepared to put his cards on the table and not use simple, political pragmatism for the direction he takes. This is to be compared with the approach taken by the Prime Minister and to a large extent reflected by what came out in the statement last night. The statement, and I say this from a totally apolitical point of view, will not be any sort of incentive for investment decisions in this country, which is the only way to contribute to real growth.

I should like to comment briefly on some of the remarks made by other participants in this debate. As I mentioned, the remarks made by the Minister, quite apart from his attack on the Clerk of the Senate, were so shallow as not to warrant response. I listened with care to what Senator Loosley said and I believe he maintained a very lucid argument in the main, which is more than can be said for the incompetent Minister who handled the Bill and the Act. The only comment I would make is that I thought Senator Loosley went very well until he started to compare the Australian system and what might be the case in Australia with the American system, particularly in respect to voting and the attendance at the polls. There is no comparison between the two. This is where I think he went off the track. He would have been more credible if he had drawn parallels not between Australia and the United States but between Australia and New Zealand, which is the closest country with a similar system. However, that will be the subject of another debate further down the line.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I have moved a motion to disallow these regulations. An argument has been put on the other side that this is just a repeat of what happened before Christmas. I think that reflects the principled view we have taken on this legislation right from the word go. We have not deviated; we believe there is no room for compromise. I just wish the Democrats would go back to their initial grassroots support, that they would stick to what they said after they dumped their leader and not support this ban.

We had the crazy situation where deals were made. For example, the argument about talking heads was put in the debate on the legislation. The Democrats are aware that the reason for that is to make people turn off, to get them bored. From a Liberal Party point of view, this legislation suits us down to the ground because the sort of debate that will come up at the next election, where we will have the credible Dr Hewson against the discredited Mr Keating, will be right up our alley. But we did not support the legislation as a matter of principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—Senator Kernot, when you were offered the choice of principle or money, you took the money. We had the situation where everyone used France, for God's sake, as an example of the funding of political campaigns. Talking heads: that is a great description! They invented the guillotine, so they might as well have talking heads. There is a great corruption inquiry going on in France right now. We cannot legislate against people being corrupt; everyone knows that. It is there or it is not.

PARA.TAB: Be that as it may, the Democrats have an opportunity yet again—they have been given two or three—to decide whether they want to support principles, and the great principles we are defending here are freedom of speech and freedom of political expression. Mr Acting Deputy President, I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed from 14 November 1991, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to present the Opposition's view on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991. Reform of Australia's land transport infrastructure is a key national priority. It has been estimated that, if Australia can achieve world class performance in road and rail, gross domestic product would be increased by up to 2 per cent, with the bulk of 40 per cent of this potential gain coming from the rail system itself.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission, in its 1991 report on rail, estimated that moving to international best practice in management and work practices would increase gross domestic product by $5 billion per year, or $300 for every Australian. This Bill allows the Commonwealth to approve the shareholders' agreement relating to the establishment of the National Rail Corporation. The agreement is set out in schedule 1 of the Bill.

The agreement was signed by the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia at the Special Premiers Conference in July 1991. South Australia has not yet signed the agreement and Queensland has not yet become an equity partner at this stage. Provisions have been made for these two States to participate in the future if they so desire.
The coalition does not oppose this Bill, but we will be moving an amendment, in an effort to eradicate a weakness in the accountability provisions of the Bill, during the committee stage.

By way of background, the parties to the agreement agreed that a company would be established for the purpose of conducting interstate rail freight operations in Australia on a commercial basis in accordance with principles compatible with those set out in the Heads of Government agreement on the National Rail Freight Corporation of 31 October 1990. The principles are that the company will operate on a strictly commercial basis; have access to the requisite assets; operate under labour agreements that reflect best international practices in productivity standards—that should be borne in mind; be able to contract activities where appropriate; provide access to its network and facilities to public and private sector operators; be able to provide services to the governments on a strictly commercial basis; and not be in any way responsible for redundancies that may arise in rail authorities resulting from its formation and operation. A further principle is that, during the establishment period of five years, the current financial position of the Commonwealth and State rail authorities' interstate rail freight operations will not deteriorate as a result of the Commonwealth and the States participating in the formation and operation of the company.

The Bill provides that the National Rail Corporation will be subject to all rates, taxes and charges; not have the shield of the Crown; and be treated as an ordinary incorporated company, including being subject to the Trade Practices Act 1974. The Bill provides for the transfer to the NRC of assets owned or leased by the Commonwealth or the Australian National Railways Commission. It also provides for substituting the NRC for the Commonwealth or AN in cases where the legislative transfer of assets or contracts has been agreed in accordance with the shareholders' agreement.

The Bill provides for compensation where a transfer of assets under the proposed Act would result in the acquisition of property otherwise than on just terms, as defined in section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution. The Bill also authorises the making of regulations, not inconsistent with the proposed Act, that are necessary for carrying out or giving effect to the agreement and to the proposed Act.

To turn to the financial impact, the Bill does not appropriate funds. However, the Commonwealth's cash equity contributions under the NRC agreement are forecast as totalling $295.8m in the five years, commencing with $40m in 1991-92, plus another $20m brought forward under the former Prime Minister's statement.

The Commonwealth's commitment is dependent on the NRC meeting the agreed principles already mentioned, particularly labour arrangements. The establishment of the NRC is expected to have an impact on the deficits of State railway systems and the Australian National system. This will be no small task, as the total losses on interstate rail freight are estimated to have amounted to $377m in 1989-90. The NRC is supposed to break even within three years and to be fully self-sufficient within five years.

The Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia are founder shareholders. The number of ordinary shares is based on each shareholder's estimated long term equity in the company. Accordingly, the ultimate anticipated shareholding will apply at the outset instead of the usual basis of progressive cash and asset contributions. Additional shares will be issued if Queensland becomes a shareholder.

The shares initially allocated carry voting rights. During the establishment period, voting rights are fixed under the agreement. Afterwards, they will be in proportion to shareholdings, subject to a maximum shareholding of 49 per cent from any one party. The shareholders will contribute $414.5m, with the Commonwealth contributing $295.8m. The company will progressively take over functions from the Commonwealth and State systems, and this transference will be completed by the end of the company's third year.

The coalition has some concerns about this legislation. As mentioned previously, we will not be opposing it but we will be suggesting an amendment at the committee stage. Industry has also indicated that it has some concerns. The matter I want to raise here, and it is one for which the coalition will move an amendment, is the weakness in accountability provisions of the Bill.

On 5 December 1991, report No. 16 of the Auditor-General, entitled Accountability off the Rails, was tabled in the Senate. The report raised serious concerns about the appointment of a private auditor to the NRC and the erosion of accountability to the Parliament. While supporting the establishment of the NRC to handle interstate rail freight, and later possibly passenger services, the Liberal and National parties are concerned that the Commonwealth has the majority of equity in the Corporation, and consequently the auditing should be carried out by the Auditor-General or under his control in order to fully protect taxpayers' money. We attach a deal of importance to this, particularly as the Commonwealth plans to invest $296m over five years. The intent of the amendment will be to ensure that the Auditor-General has the control of the audit of the Corporation while the Commonwealth is the major equity holder.

There is a very recent legislative precedent for our concern that the Auditor-General should control the audit. We made the same point in the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 and were successful in having this provision written into the legislation. The Corporation must be open to public scrutiny. The Auditors-General of five States support the Auditor-General's Office's warning of the erosion in its ability to scrutinise the activities of a public sector company unless this amendment is made to the legislation.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee notes that while the necessity to enact legislation must be considered an `unusual circumstance', there is still no obligation to proclaim this piece of legislation once the other parties to the agreement—New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia—have enacted legislation to approve the agreement. I would like the Minister representing the current Minister for Transport and Communications to give his views on this matter in his response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the Minister for Transport.

—Oh, good, sometimes I think the Minister is acting. Another problem that the coalition and industry can see in the Bill is that unless governments cooperate with the Corporation to get the changes in place quickly, we believe it will be very difficult to get the costs down, as is anticipated by the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The agreement specifies that labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award which reflect best practice in productivity standards must be in place before any capital is committed. This aspect of the agreement is of vital importance and one the coalition insists should be enforced. It is no use ruining the window of opportunity even before it has been opened by just throwing money at the railways—which lose millions of dollars each year currently—without addressing the fundamental underlying problem. If the problems the Government has experienced with redundancies in Australian National is any guide, it is clear it is not prepared to take the hard decisions necessary. This is not an encouraging sign for the beginnings of the NRC.

It is not clear what the shareholding will be at the end of the five-year establishment period, but it appears no shareholder will be able to hold more than 49 per cent of the shares. This restriction places the claim of commerciality under a question mark. Also, in any commercial operation it would be known what the shareholdings would be right from the start.

Another point the coalition would like to raise is what happens to the leftovers in Australian National and V/Line once the NRC is operational. It is our belief that if any lines are profitable—or capable of becoming profitable—the NRC should be encouraged to take them over on commercial grounds. However, this may not be possible because of the clause in the agreement which gives the States the power to decide what happens to intrastate lines. Of course, I can understand the concern in my own State because Queensland, with its own intrastate lines which carry bulk commodities, has used those lines for over a decade as the milch cow for government to the detriment of the mining companies.

I will list some of the coalition's other concerns. Firstly, there are problems arising from the ability of the States to revoke references under section 51(xxxvii) of the Constitution. Under clause 3(1)(a)(i) of the agreement the States must enact legislation referring to the Commonwealth under section 51(xxxvii) of the Constitution the matter of the Commonwealth holding shares in the company when the company engages in intrastate rail transport services in each State.

The terms of the legislation when enacted by the States need to be considered as only an irrevocable reference which will apply to the long term will contribute to planning for viable long term commercial operations. However, under present case law it would appear that a referring State can at any time revoke the reference in the exercise of the sovereignty of the Parliament.

Secondly, there is resolution of disputes. Another area I want to comment on here is a matter which appears to be similar to one we were concerned about in the Roads Commission legislation. It involves a possible inappropriate delegation of legislative power. I am referring to clause (2) of the Bill which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: This Act commences on a day to be fixed by Proclamation.

There is no limit as to the time in which such a proclamation must be made, and in this regard the provision is contrary to the general rule set out in the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel drafting instruction No. 2 of 1989. The explanatory memorandum of the Bill states:
Proclamation will occur when all the parties to the Agreement have enacted legislation approving the Agreement.

This aspect of the agreement requires a more detailed examination for which there is no time now. However, it is quite possible there may be disputes at some future time for which there is no satisfactory process of arbitration as the Inter-State Commission no longer exists.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, there is the adequacy of capital. Article 5(3) of the articles of association provides that during the establishment period no charges in the capital of the company, other than the 500 ordinary shares, 500 B convertible shares and such of the A convertible shares as may be allotted to the Commonwealth or any State in return for cash or in satisfaction of the transfer of interests in assets, may be allotted without the unanimous resolution of the company and general meeting. It must be noted that A convertible shares do not carry a voting right.

The establishment period is the period of five years commencing from 31 January 1992 or such later date as is agreed to by members in writing, being the common date from which all rail authorities of the Commonwealth and the States carry interstate rail freight on behalf of the company. That is in article 2(1). The transition period has been defined as the first three-year period of the establishment period in clause 1 of the agreement.

The company runs the risk of being deprived of capital during the establishment period if the initial projections prove incorrect and if the members are unable to agree unanimously on the basis of allotting new shares to raise the required capital.

Fourthly, there is the access to and transfer of assets to the company by the rail authorities. Clauses 5(5) and 5(6) of the agreement provide for the access to and transfer of assets to the company by the rail authorities. The objective is that all transfers of ownership, leases or grants of access shall be completed before the end of the transition period of three years. While clause 5(5) in particular is probably intended to meet the constitutional hurdle referred to previously, the practical implementation may lead to disputes in relation to contract prices for use of the assets, as they are tied with the efficiency of operations of the State rail authority that owns the assets and to NRC standard costs.

Then there are best practice industrial agreements. The agreement between the Commonwealth and the States revolves around the ability of the company to negotiate successfully with the unions concerned a best practice industrial agreement. Thus recital B(iii) expresses the hope that the company shall operate under labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award, which reflects best practice and productivity standards through efficient and commercial consideration. This is vital. What is meant by best industrial practice? What is the benchmark? Is the authority to adopt the negative, destructive work practices which have been the largest single factor which has contributed to the destruction of much of industry in Australia? Are we going to have a closed shop with union leaders who have no interest in their members, but only in their own power base, calling the shots? Are we going to have the same inflexibility which bedevils the rest of industry in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you think you are sounding now when it comes to inflexibility?
—I will take that interjection.
—Good on you.

—Look at any industry in this country. I have had some involvement with this in the past, which is more than I can say for a lot of people on the other side, and I would say that one of the greatest disincentives to the investment we need in this country has been the sort of inflexibilities that have occurred—built up over a number of years, I will agree—in work practices. I can take you back through 20 years of people wanting to put major projects into this country, and I can take you to the jumbo steel mill type proposals of the early 1970s. In each case it has always been the industrial practices. It really is something that has to be addressed, and one cannot walk away from it.

PARA.TAB: It is not the wage rates. I am one of the first to admit that it is not wage rates in this country. I have often heard some people complain about the imports that come from where labour is cheap overseas. Our labour rates are half the labour rates of Japan, but they do not have the restrictive work practices that we have, and the debates—

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last five years there have been tremendous changes, and in the next five you will see more. That is not acknowledging what is happening.

—It is not something where you can change attitudes overnight, I would agree with you on that; but it is something we must do. It is not just the work practices themselves, it is the unreliability. The biggest problem I ever had in all the time before I came to this place was that overseas I would be hit between the eyes with a bit of three-by-two and told, `You are unreliable'. Fix up the unreliability, fix up the work practices and we have got a great country, but I do not think we will do it while we have got some of these narrow-minded people who are more interested in their own power position that in their members.

PARA.TAB: Are we going to continue to have featherbedding, with three people doing the job of one? The aim of best industrial practice must be not simply to have an improvement on a corrupt system but to have the most efficient and productive industrial practices in the world. That has to be the base. That has to be the standard which we must achieve. It is no good, in the economic position we have in this country, just to improve our position. We must be the best in the world. Unless this occurs, then all the effort, all the capital expenditure, will have been to no avail.

There is no doubt that it is incomprehensible—as I have always said, going back many years—that it is cheaper to move half a dozen or so cars by semitrailer from Melbourne to Brisbane than it is to move them as cargo by rail or ship. We support the introduction of a standard gauge rail so that we do not have to have the transfer costs of moving from one gauge rail to another. There is no doubt that that is a big step forward.

The infusion of additional capital is, under clause 5(1)(b) of the agreement, made dependent upon the confirmation by the company that best practices are in place to provide a basis for commercial operations. There would be considerable uncertainty of the viability of the company if best practices were not in place which were effective over a period longer than one year, to which awards under the current system generally apply. There may be room for disputes with unions on the contents of the ideal best practices agreement, leading to disagreements among members and consequential disruption to the injection of additional capital during the establishment period.

The sixth point is contracts for services and liquidated damages. Clause 5(3), which covers contracts for services between the company and the rail authorities of the Commonwealth and each State to be entered into before or during the transition period, lists matters to be dealt with in such contracts during the transition period. Certain inadequacies here raise the possibility that there is a lack of provision to resolve satisfactorily claims in this area.

The seventh point is voting on approval of the corporate plan. Article 118(3)(g) provides for the directors to submit the corporate plan, within seven days of its preparation, to the members for approval. After consultation the members may, within 30 days of its receipt, approve the corporate plan by special resolution.

Article 118(3)(h) provides that, if during the establishment period the members have not approved the corporate plan as provided in article 118(3)(g), the plan may be approved by resolution involving two, three, four or five members. It will thus be seen that any two members opposing any aspect of the corporate plan, regardless of the number of shares held by them, may be in a position to frustrate the company by denying approval of the corporate plan. Another set of circumstances would make it possible for New South Wales, with 26.5 per cent of the votes, to prevent the passage of a special resolution, even if the Commonwealth were able to win the support of Victoria and Western Australia.

In conclusion, whilst supporting the general thrust of the Bill in its attempt to bring national railways towards a viable commercialisation, the coalition believes that there are a number of difficulties lying ahead.

A recent article in the Australian, on rail and road systems, noted that the rail system was riddled with inefficiencies. This is what must be addressed. The article said that not one of the State based systems was making profits from interstate freight, and that would be correct. In fact, just as an aside, I can recall many years ago trying to transfer freight—explosives being sent from Newcastle into the Bowen Basin by rail rather than by road. With all the best efforts in the world, even though the cost of road had escalated at a considerable rate, it was still not economically possible to do so. One of the reasons was that, once one got to the border of Queensland, the rail gauge changed. There is no doubt that a standard rail gauge is something we should all aspire to.

The prospects for interstate rail freight in its present form still appear somewhat grim. The coalition supports the Federal system, which distributes powers in a way which encourages participation and acts as a barrier against centralist, remote and authoritarian control. There is widespread agreement that Commonwealth-State relations are in urgent need of reform. There is also widespread agreement about the problem which needs to be resolved—duplication, lack of responsibility and apparent lack of cooperation between all levels of government.

The legislation itself, we believe, is a move in the right direction. We, of course, find Australia in a very shameful state. We have intolerable unemployment, running at 10.3 per cent; successive quarters of negative growth; record rates of bankruptcies; youth unemployment which is totally intolerable; fourth and fifth generation farmers going off the land; and a 500 per cent increase in gross foreign debt, from $36 billion to $166 billion, over the past eight years—all this, of course, presided over by a government which in recent times has been torn apart by internal power struggles and self-doubt while the nation sinks lower and lower into an economic morass.

My own observation, having only briefly looked at the statement brought down by the Government last night, is that it will not contribute in any way to the revival, to the hope, to the attitudes of people in the next year or two. Unless that hope and that attitude can be restored, as I believe has been shown by the acceptance of the Hewson Fightback package, then this country will continue to go down what Senator Peter Walsh regularly refers to as `the road to Argentina'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate today is the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill, a Bill that is long overdue in its attempt to bring some commonsense back into the rail transport system in this country. I commend the move to rationalise our dilapidated rail system, thereby making it more efficient. I do regret, however, the general weakness in the proposed structure of the National Rail Corporation and I believe that these sorts of weaknesses should be corrected.

PARA.TAB: The inefficiencies in Australia's rail system are costing the country up to $4 billion a year, according to the Industry Commission. That means that micro-economic reforms of the railways has got to be one of the highest priorities for the continued growth of the Australian economy, particularly in regard to export potential. The various railways have to be made competitive. Only by being put on a competitive footing will railway be able to make its proper contribution to a more efficient economy.

The complete inefficiency and ramshackle state of the railways has been well documented. One of the most disturbing examples is the case of a major Melbourne manufacturer who was finally persuaded to experiment with rail transport. He ended up being told by V-Line and the New South Wales SRA last year, when he tried this, that the entire train with his first shipment had been lost en route to Sydney. Four days later it was discovered marooned in a siding near Goulburn. Gross inefficiencies such as this cannot be allowed to continue and should simply not occur in a country that considers that it has an advanced economy.

The Industry Commission report in April this year was scathing in its criticism and demanding in its reforms. The railways have to be put on a proper commercial footing and the system must be opened up to competition. Getting the railways onto a proper commercial footing means making all freight cover its costs, instead of the present system whereby the mining industry is overcharged to subsidise other freight users.

It also means opening the tracks to anyone who wants to run trains on them. The obvious potential competitors are the various State rail authorities, the mining and transport giants, and now the National Rail Corporation. There is simply no proper reason why the State rail authorities should be protected monopolies.

Not only are the authorities protected from the competition of other train operators but they are also protected to varying degrees from road transport. There are restrictions on road freight to protect the railway monopoly. These restrictions on competition must be swept away, and the mismanagement and union featherbedding that shelter comfortably behind them must also go. Australia cannot continue to throw away $4 billion of national income a year.

The National Rail Corporation, as established by this Bill, goes some way towards implementing the recommendations of the Industry Commission report and countless other reports that have urged similar measures over the last 40 years.The parties to the agreement, being the State and Federal governments, have decided to establish a corporation for the purpose of conducting interstate rail operations in Australia on a commercial basis. This sensible and long overdue move must be applauded by all Australians. This is not going to be easy, however, and now that the reform is finally on the way the momentum cannot be lost. Painful reform must continue, and at a more rapid and confident pace. The National Rail Corporation is not a crowning achievement of micro-economic reform but only the start of a hard and difficult slog towards competitiveness.

It is going to be extremely difficult to get costs down to the levels envisaged. It is, therefore, absolutely vital that the provisions in the Bill for ensuring that labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award reflect best practice in productivity standards are in place before any capital is committed. Once the capital starts flowing without the appropriate structure being in place, we have once again wasted the opportunity for reform. Getting the structure right is the major concern that I have with this Bill. Questions have to be raised as to the right of any State to revoke access to intrastate operations, the resolution of dispute processes, capital adequacy guarantees, asset valuation, and the power of any one State to disagree with the corporate plan for political purposes.

The NRC Agreement provides that the States must enact legislation to refer to the Commonwealth the power to engage in intrastate trade as a shareholder of the NRC. Under present case law, this referral can be withdrawn at any time. This possibility should be prevented by arranging for the NRC to conduct its intrastate operations on a joint venture basis.

Another question that must be raised is the adequacy of the procedure for the resolution of disputes set down in the agreement, in view of the role laid down by the Constitution for the Inter-State Commission to judge certain questions in respect of railways. It is uncertain, in reading the present wording of the Act, whether this constitutional mechanism would override the provision for conciliation and arbitration as set out in the agreement. If the Constitution is the ultimate means of appeal, this would leave any dispute between the NRC and the State authorities unresolved until such time as the Inter-State Commission met.

Problems could also arise due to a lack of capital in the `establishment period' set out in the agreement. Capital injection is set at a very low level during this period, until the States and the Commonwealth are able to agree unanimously on the basis of allotting new shares to raise the required capital. Should the initial projections prove incorrect, this could leave the NRC starved of the funds it needs to get off the ground. This issue must be looked at closely because of the danger of stifling reform before it is started.

The ability of the NRC to negotiate successfully with the unions concerning best practice industrial agreements must also be questioned. This is an important issue because the entire funding of the project is tied to the success of these negotiations. Without these agreements, no further funding will be available. Without them, the NRC cannot proceed.

We can see from this legislation and its obvious shortcomings that the NRC is not off to a smooth start. This is a step towards commercialisation of the Australian rail system and for this reason alone the legislation is necessary. Rail transport in Australia has great potential. Rail is ideal for most of the freight carried here. The problems to date have been the chronic inefficiencies that have plagued rail. The infrastructure has deteriorated, lines have been decommissioned, restrictive work practices have created enormous inefficiencies, and costs are artificial.

This has led to a situation where rail has lost more and more of the freight market, when instead it should be dominating the market. It is high time that the rail operators realised that they are not in the rail business; they are in the transport business. Rail can be efficient, cheap and profitable all at the same time. The commercial sector can see the convenience and the capability of the rail system, and laments its inefficiencies.

If the National Rail Corporation can fulfil its promises, it will be a step in the right direction towards increased competitiveness. It will create a more competitive economy, one with the right infrastructure in place to allow us better to weather the next downturn in the business cycle. Thus I support any moves towards this end.

However, the legislation before us poses some potential problems, as I have outlined. I must therefore express some reservations about this Bill and whether it provides the best possible vehicle for the National Rail Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill is to establish a National Rail Corporation, along the lines that were mooted by various States quite some time ago. To my knowledge, the Commonwealth Government and the governments of New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia agreed to set this up according to the principles agreed on 30 October 1990.

PARA.TAB: One of the main reasons is to operate the rail connecting Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth on a commercial basis, which certainly has not been happening in the last few years. To do all this, it has got to have complete access to the track, to achieve the run-through in micro-economic reforms that is required.

To date, the major problems causing rail to be unable to compete with road have been—on top of the rail track itself being run down a certain amount—the different awards for operators of the trains and people that work on the trains between, say, Perth and Sydney, and the different rail authorities with their different running stock and locomotives, rather than rolling stock that goes right through. There are three safe working systems, I believe, between Sydney and Perth; there are three State rail authorities operating them. You just do not have a certain amount of efficiency.

I welcome this move because, in the long run, our side of politics will be privatising the whole system. I believe, however, that the track should remain the property of the Federal Government, in case of war and other reasons why it would be needed.

Labour agreements that reflect the best international productivity have got to be put into action too. It is pointless having more than one award right across. That is what has led to the problems at the present moment.

The upkeep of the track between these States has been a problem. It has been let run down. One of the reasons it has been let run down is that the amount of money that is available does not go far enough because of the way it is kept up. We on this side of politics will be looking to privatisation of the contracts to maintain the line, where contractors can work 24 hours a day if necessary rather than for the limited times when the major capital equipment that is needed for rail upkeep can be used.

I suppose we could look at the airport model: FAC owns the airports at each end and licenses the airline operators to work in the airspace in between. It would be the same with a rail track: private contractors could be allowed to put their own rolling stock on the track, to be hauled by ANR locomotives, National Rail Corporation locomotives, or indeed, in time, private locomotives. It has to be a fully commercial operation.

It has been impossible in the last 20-odd years for rail to compete with road. Because road is mainly private enterprise, the trucks can move quickly—too quickly in some cases—and when they get to the other end they go straight into their terminals and trailers can be disconnected. At present wagons arriving in Perth from Sydney may get shunted in late on a Friday night and no-one can get to them until Monday morning—two days wasted. With a private enterprise system they could go into private freight yards or yards leased off ANR and they could be accessed immediately. It is useless a train getting to Perth from Sydney faster than a truck—and they should get there faster if truck drivers keep to their strict speed limits and regulations—to have those wagons tied up for a couple of days in a yard that cannot be accessed. This Bill provides the means of getting somewhere down that track, but I am afraid it does not go far enough. Part of the Bill provides access to the rail network and its facilities for public and private sector operators.

Of course, notwithstanding this Bill, the new Corporation should not be responsible for redundancies that may arise from the transformation of the rail system. We do not want to put those people out in the paddock without anything else, but that responsibility lies, I believe, in the area of social security. Rather than making the rail system an inefficient transport system that cannot compete with others because of that factor, I am sure that social security can look after those areas.

During the first five years, the current financial position of Commonwealth rail and State rail will not deteriorate as a result of this new company. That is what we have been told by this legislation. It is going to be subject to all rates, taxes and charges, of course, which any other company has, and will not have the shield of the Crown. Assets that are leased by the Commonwealth or ANR are to be transferred to the National Rail Corporation, and the total commitment in the Bill is $295m over five years.

Of course, I have my doubts, and others have their doubts, whether this is quite enough to get this transport system up to the standard that we require in this day and age. As I said before, if it is going to work it will depend on agreed principles, especially with the labour arrangements. If we remain with the present labour arrangements, I am afraid it is not going to get very far.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in 1989-90 the losses on interstate rail amounted to $377m. I presume that this system will wipe that off as soon as possible. The break-even time is supposed to be three years—although I reckon that that timetable is a bit short—with the Corporation to be fully self-sufficient in five years. It is going to be very difficult to do that in this situation.

This idea has been around for quite a while. It is 12 months since we were supposed to see this Bill, which was set up first of all to start on 1 July 1991. It was postponed then and it was supposed to start on 31 January 1992. That has come and gone, and I do not quite know when it will be actually getting going.

As I said before, this is the time this Corporation has to work. If we fail to get rail back onto its feet this time, I am afraid that the rail system of Australia will go down the tubes and road transport will take a further share of it. In the last few years in this place there have been attempts to get rail back to where it should be in Australia. However, those attempts have been brought about by loading taxes, regulations, and other measures onto road transport and that is not the way to do it. When one loads it onto road transport, rather than making rail efficient, one is loading it onto short haul road transport.

From my knowledge, I would say that about 70 per cent of road transport is in distances of about 60 or 70 kilometres. So when one tries to load taxes onto the long haul transporters, using the kind of measures that this Government has used in the past few years—I have always said in this place that I do not believe that any road transport from Perth to Sydney or Melbourne to Brisbane should be able to compete against rail, and yet it does, and very easily—one is also damaging the road haulage system in the short haul. One of the prime examples of that was when B-doubles were allowed in Victoria. In order to put a load on them, and to get money back to spend on rail, they were loaded with registration fees of about $12,000 a year compared with a standard semitrailer system of about $4,000 a year. Unfortunately, this does not work and the people of Victoria are obviously paying for it in the cost of their freight.

When this company is put together I understand that a valuation of the assets has to be done. I certainly hope that for Westrail, in Western Australia, the valuations will be true and correct. Westrail is the most efficient rail system in Australia. It is shown that Westrail's part of interstate rail is the only line that is making a profit. So we would like to be assured that it will be evaluated on a true basis. I do not really understand why this Government insists that in this case no one shareholder will get more than 49 per cent of the company. If that limit is imposed, I cannot see how we will have true competition in the long run, especially when we are talking about it all being internally owned. If we are talking about overseas ownership, that is a different story.

I would like to know what is to be done with the leftovers in this system. Once you have the main interstate lines all running on the one basis, what will be left over? V/Line and AN as well? What will happen to those other lines? Will they eventually be brought into this system or will they just wither away and the lines close down? I know that a lot of lines in Australia have been closed in the last 20 years. I have been a supporter of some and a critic of others, especially of the grain lines in the more remote areas. A lot of those lines are now part time lines. We would like to be assured that where lines are needed, they will be kept; so we would like to know what will happen to the leftovers.

Of course, we want to be assured that the State of Western Australia—and indeed, any other State—will always have the right to withdraw if things are not going well, if we are being imposed upon and if we are not getting our due rights. As I said, Westrail has been making a profit of $2m a year. There are disputes and resolutions that have to be looked at. There is also the guaranteed capital, which I have mentioned before, and assets valuation, which I have covered. All in all, I believe that this Corporation will begin what should have been put into action quite a few years ago. When the coalition is in government, it will be an easy step for us to go as far down the road of full privatisation as possible.
I listened last night to the Keating package. There was quite a bit in it on rail. The Government is going to upgrade the line from Sydney to Brisbane and from Melbourne to Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —It needs more than new bridges and new sleepers.

—The Government is finally going to standardise the Melbourne to Adelaide line. Some money is to be spent on the line between Perth and Kalgoorlie. A heap of money was spent on the line from Perth to Koolyanobbing in about 1983, when BHP had the iron ore mine at Koolyanobbing. As soon as the upgrading was done, BHP pulled out and left the Western Australian iron ore industry to its own resources. Fortunately, it appears that the miniature steel mill in the south-west is getting off the ground and we hope that the Koolyanobbing iron ore mine will reopen. Incidentally, it is within 30 kilometres of my home town. A lot of money was spent on that line. So I hope that the money that was mentioned last night will be spent on the line between Koolyanobbing and Kalgoorlie and on into the Nullarbor.

PARA.TAB: I will commend the measure in the package for spending money on rail if, as Senator Brownhill said, it goes beyond changing the sleepers. The Corporation is a start but, if it fails this time, the whole rail system of Australia will fail. It is certainly time that railway lines were standardised around Australia, not only the line between Melbourne and Adelaide, which still has a gauge of five feet three inches, left over from the old colonial governments and their pig-headed engineers. The Hewson package, with its elimination of the fuel excise, was not mentioned in the Keating package last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would give the railways a lot more than this package does.

—That is right; it would certainly give the railways a lot more than this package does. I have argued at different times and in different places that fuel excise being paid by rail is just part of the loading up of rail to pay for social costs. I have never been able to understand why rail has paid fuel excise, or why fisherman have paid it either. They do not rip up too many roads out in the ocean.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is supporting this package. It goes a certain way, but I believe it has to go a lot further. I believe it can be made to work, especially if the Government is prepared to do something about labour arrangements. Those arrangements and redundancies have to be looked at, because they have prevented rail from being competitive in the past. I would like to see us go back to a system where rail competes with road, especially on the long hauls. It would give us a much better system around Australia and would tend to make the roads on the long haul areas a bit safer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill is, to the Australian Democrats' mind, a belated and cautious acknowledgment by the Federal Government that rail is an essential element of our national infrastructure. For years, the Australian Democrats have argued that unless there are major changes to the way rail is managed and funded, we will fail to make the transition to an equitable, safe and ecologically sustainable transport system.

PARA.TAB: For years our arguments and those of rail unions and transport interest groups were ignored. The result of these years of neglect has been lives wasted in needless accidents on busy major highways, at great social cost to the community. Huge quantities of fuel have been wasted in transporting goods and people by road, while a functioning rail system would have done the job much more efficiently, and large sums of money have been wasted as a result. Local government authorities have had to pick up the tab for much of the road damage that has been created by the closure of rail lines through the decades and continuing to this very day; unfunded, or not sufficiently funded, by their so-called partners in government at Federal and State level.

The establishment of the National Rail Corporation and the National Road Transport Commission late last year gives us at least some sign that Labor's love affair with roads, cars and trucks is coming to an end, and giving way to a more rational policy in which each transport mode can be used to its best effect. But the signs, as far as the Democrats are concerned, are far from complete. I will argue later that rail funding is still too low, and this Government's land transport policy is still far from cohesive. But before turning to the investment funding and rail construction plans that this new National Rail Corporation will oversee, I will look at the establishment of the Corporation itself.

As I have said, the Democrats support the establishment of the Corporation because it should be able to implement significant improvements in the rail transport system. It is based on the Commonwealth-State agreement, one which we welcome. It is an acknowledgment, not only by the Federal Government but by those various State governments, of the importance of a national rail system.

The Commonwealth-State agreement and the Articles of Association allow for full privatisation of the Corporation after the five-year establishment period. It is very well known that the Australian Democrats strongly oppose the privatisation of such a vital public asset, for the obvious reason that provision of community services becomes much more difficult to achieve once government control is lost. A fully privatised corporation would be under absolutely no obligation to provide community services, even when those services might be fully paid for at commercial rates by the Commonwealth. The decision as to whether those services would be provided would always be in the hands of the fully privatised corporation, should that come to pass.

Nevertheless, in spite of our opposition to privatisation of the national rail system—which, as I say, is provided for by this Bill after the five-year establishment period—we feel compelled, on balance, to support the legislation on the basis that it is an important step in the right direction; a step, as I say, which acknowledges the need for a fully national, coordinated, hopefully efficient and effective rail system in this country.
Looking at the second reading speech of the Minister, when the Bill was introduced last year, we see this claim:

SPEECH.PARA: Even small improvements in the efficiency of our transport system offer potentially large economic and social gains.

The word that jumps out at me, from that sentence, is the word `small'. It jumps out because of the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night, which I would like to comment on. It has been touted as a major boost for rail transport. An additional $454m will be provided to the Corporation to standardise and improve the national rail system.

PARA.TAB: At first glance this level of rail spending really looks like a most welcome boost to a vital element of our national infrastructure. It is a boost, and it is welcome, but I would quote the Minister's second reading speech: on balance it is a small improvement. I suppose the Prime Minister and the Government are hoping that the claim made in the second reading speech will be true, and that small improvements will have large economic and social gains—at least in time for the next election. But, as I say, any improvement is a welcome improvement. But it must be remembered that under Labor investment has been appallingly low.

In his statement of last night, the Prime Minister points out that the construction of a national rail highway `should have been done 100 years ago'. That means that it could have been done over the last nine years under Labor governments in which Mr Keating was the major policy architect. The fact is that not even $454m over the next two years will compensate for the total neglect thus far of rail by this Labor Government.

There has been no evidence provided by the Government to demonstrate that the money it proposes to spend will result in a major shift of freight from road to rail.
