We are told in last night's statement that Melbourne to Sydney rail transit times will be 12 hours, a reduction of 1 1/2 hours. But a modern, heavy truck can do the trip in 10 hours and go direct to its final destination.

I would be fascinated to know whether any cost-benefit studies have been done predicting, as a result of the package announced, such things as the shift of freight and passengers from road to rail, the reduction in road deaths and the reduction in greenhouse gases due to greater fuel efficiency. If such studies have not been done the Government is simply throwing public money at rail in the absence of a cohesive transport strategy. If there are studies, the public and certainly the Parliament deserve to see them.

The Democrats recognise that the national rail highway that is represented by last night's statement is a step in the right direction, provided that the NRC succeeds in reducing operating costs and improving reliability. But we are convinced that more money could have been spent for far greater benefit. Why, for example, did the Government fail to take the plunge to upgrade the Melbourne-Sydney line to a fast freight train standard, reducing the transit time to, say, nine hours and providing a truly competitive transport service—surely necessary if we really do want to shift freight from road to rail?

It should be remembered that more than $730m has been spent by Labor on upgrading the Hume Highway, Melbourne to Sydney. This puts the $110m to be spent on the Melbourne-Sydney rail line into its proper perspective. The fact is that roads were the real winners in last night's statement. The hype that surrounded the rail plans has tended to disguise the fact that road spending will be increased by a greater amount, around $600m.

I want to put on the record here too, Mr Deputy President, that I have some particular concerns about the rail transport plans emerging for Victoria. For example, the statement includes the blunt admission by the Prime Minister that the future of spur lines off the Adelaide-Melbourne line is `a matter for the Victorian Government'. Mr Keating, of all people, knows very well the parlous state of Victoria's finances and this means that he has signed the death warrant of existing broad gauge lines to rural Victoria and has washed his hands of any responsibility for the consequences—a callous and unacceptable way, in my view, to treat rural Victorians who are now dependent on a functioning rail line. The Federal Government must consult the Victorian Government to identify the likely closures and their social and economic consequences and decide what action should be taken to avoid or to cushion the blow.

I am also concerned that the upgrading of the Melbourne to Geelong line, which of course is welcome, has been driven rather too much by the desire to shore up some two or three marginal Federal seats and five or so marginal State seats that will be serviced on that particular line. It seems to me, however, irrational to upgrade that part of the line, Melbourne-Geelong, when one can travel at the other end, at the East Gippsland end of the Melbourne-Gippsland corridor, and see electrification poles being ripped out of the ground. This is an area where 80 per cent of Victorians live and it should be seen as a corridor, not just as a vote catching Melbourne to Geelong exercise. This illustrates the point I am making about the emphasis in the package last night on the national rail highway at the expense of those routes that are not part of that major trunk system.

In the context, the plan to build a road from the South Dynon rail terminal to the Swanson and Appleton docks, virtually mid-city in Melbourne, really mystifies me at this stage. It is a move that will add more trucks to an extremely heavily congested area right on the edge of the central business district in a city suffering from chronic and worsening smog problems. That problem is seen as a major one by citizens of that city, just as Sydney people are concerned about theirs; and it seems to me that the logical thing to have done there was to have upgraded the rail link. Surely this would have been a greater contribution to efficiency and, in the case of much of the freight movement, would have removed one change of mode from the process.

Just to summarise the transport initiatives in last night's statement: they appear to have been too hastily cobbled together in the absence of a clear transport policy framework and without a thorough cost-benefit assessment. If the Government begs to differ from that, it will need to put evidence on the table.

I repeat, however, that the Bill before us today is supported by the Democrats on the basis that it represents a step in the right direction and an acknowledgment of the need for a national rail system, a need recognised by both the Federal and State governments.

I am aware that calls have been made, in relation to this legislation, for the Corporation to accept the Auditor-General as its auditor during the five-year establishment period. I am also aware that the Opposition intends to move an amendment to this effect. I find the Opposition's attitude bewildering, if not hypocritical. If the Corporation is to be allowed to operate on a fully commercial basis—something which I understood to be very firm Opposition policy, as it is Government policy—and indeed down the track to become a fully privatised body, again a matter which is Opposition policy and the potential for which has been put in place by the Government but is opposed by the Democrats, then surely to be proposing that the Corporation be forced to use the Auditor-General as its auditor flies in the face of that free enterprise, privatised approach.

I received a letter from Mr Greiner's Transport Minister, Bruce Baird, urging that the Corporation be free to choose its own auditor and supporting very strongly the Bill in its present form. I wonder whether Senator Parer got that letter. The real issue at stake is that the Corporation should remain accountable to the Parliament for as long as the Commonwealth is a shareholder; and I hope that the Commonwealth will be a shareholder in perpetuity. To this end, I will be moving an amendment to require that the Corporation's annual report to its shareholders be tabled in both Houses of Parliament. My amendment will acknowledge the Corporation as an independent body and will allow the Corporation to choose its own auditor, but will require, as appropriately should be the case, that the Corporation's report be tabled here in the Houses of Parliament, the Commonwealth being a shareholder on behalf of the people of Australia.

I think the Opposition has gone overboard on this one, and so too, of course, does Bruce Baird, the appropriate Minister in New South Wales. This Bill has the Democrats' support and we will move that amendment in the committee stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991 is really a machinery Bill, in the sense that it sets up machinery whereby a National Rail Corporation can be established. It is set up pursuant to an agreement between the Commonwealth and several States—New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia. It has that distinguishing mark of being an agreement between States, one of which is presently ruled by the coalition. So it is an across-party agreement, as it were. That is to be very much welcomed.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 1 contains a memorandum of association and articles of association which set up this company, and schedule 2 sets out the functions that this Corporation will perform once set up. I suppose the significant thing about the legislation is not so much the mechanisms that it sets up to enable rail to return to the place it ought to, but the fact that it is a ringing endorsement of rail transport. It is good to see that this legislation, which is a symbol of the nation's faith in land travel, and specifically in rail travel, has been endorsed by the statement last night of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) which says that hundreds of millions of dollars will be devoted to backing up what we today are symbolising by passing this legislation. It is clear, as Senator Powell has said so well, that rail is here to stay, and so it should be.

Rail is a very efficient means of transport; and it provides an alternative to road transport, which has its problems. It is to be noted in this context that the statement last night also indicated that hundreds of millions of dollars devoted would be devoted to roads. So after the plan has been worked out, we will then have very efficient rail and road systems in Australia. That is proper, given the fact that Australia consists of major cities and towns which are quite divorced from each other when compared with other countries. Vast distances must be traversed, and traversed as efficiently as possible. If there is anything that vindicates this Government's stand on micro-economic reform, it is what it is doing now in respect of land transport. This Bill heralds a most imaginative scheme, a great undertaking, and last night's address by the Prime Minister ensures the great vision will be realised.

There are a few things to be noted about rail transport. Though it may run on power produced from a fossil fuel such as coal, ultimately it utilises that energy much more efficiently than does road transport. Because the burning of that fossil fuel can be located in particular areas, it is better for the environment. These matters are of considerable importance, and it is proper that they be pointed out.

I have talked to the most reliable of authorities about trams—of which Melbourne boasts; and I know Senator Panizza would like Western Australia to adopt them. May I say, Senator Watson, they would even go well in Tasmania; and Senator Reid should press for a tram service in Canberra. Trams are said to be three or four times more efficient in the utilisation of fuel than cars, and trains up to eight times more efficient. So they ought to be looked to as proper to be introduced everywhere.

We should, in this great vision that the Prime Minister has put forward—this vision of having a spine, as it were, right down the east coast of Australia from your great city of Brisbane, Mr Acting Deputy President, down through Sydney—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good concept but pick the best route.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Through you I say to Senator Watson that I agree that the best route should be chosen. The overall concept of providing a rail service right round the eastern part of Australia is a great one which I assume is approved by all. However, the spine that the Federal Government has undertaken to build should be looked at only as a spine; the railway lines that run across it or into it should also be looked at.

PARA.TAB: In that context I would like to say something about my State, Victoria—a great State—and to make some comments on how the vision that the Federal Government put forward last night should be utilised by the proper building of railways in that State and the revamping of the railway lines that are already there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't he mention the VFT?

—The VFT is a private undertaking and I would have thought that if the private companies that want to undertake it were to put forward a proposition that would make it practical, there would be no problem about building a very fast train.

PARA.TAB: As things now stand, it is true that rail freight services operate at a deficit, but studies have shown that rail enjoys significant competitive advantages over road transport for medium to long distance haulages, in terms of fuel and energy efficiency. I have already spoken about that. It is important because transport costs are at the heart of the total price that our nation's export oriented products, such as steel, coal and wheat, incur. It is imperative that the movement of these goods between producers and purchasers occur in the most cost-efficient manner. This Bill is the first stage in the plan to achieve those essential economies.

Let me go now to the position of railways in Victoria, particularly in the west of Victoria. I go to Wannon as part of my duties; it is a great part of Victoria and of Australia. The Victorian Government—to give it proper credit—has invested more than $100m in recent years in making substantial improvements to performance of rail in that area. As a result, VicRail's capacity to move wheat efficiently and with flexibility from the great producing areas of Victoria to the ports of Portland and Geelong will be retained. Although Senator Panizza is familiar with wheat growing in Western Australia, I suppose he is not quite so familiar but nevertheless considerably familiar with the great wheat producing areas of Victoria, which no doubt he admires.

It is important that the rail system in the west of Victoria be retained. If it is not retained, the wheat would have to be transported by other means such as the B-double trucks. These cause considerable problems in terms of damage to the roads, particularly in the country areas, and to the smooth flow of traffic. If rail were to disappear from that part of Victoria, and all transport was to be done by B-doubles, Victoria would be under all sorts of strain.

One of the problems with the spine line that will go down the east coast of Australia, around the corner, and over to Adelaide is that it will be of a different gauge from the lines that run in the west of Victoria. It is imperative that this great scheme that the Federal Government has initiated does not result in the lines in Victoria being rendered non-viable. It is imperative that money be spent to make sure that they are kept open so that wheat, and cargo of all sorts, can be transported by rail. Passenger lines also must be maintained in that State.

Unless adjustments are made when this new line is put around Australia, there is a threat not only to the cargo carrying capacity of trains in Victoria but also to some of the V/Line passenger services there. For example, in Victoria we have passenger services to Ballarat, Ballan, Melton and Bacchus Marsh. These are heavily patronised, popular and offer relatively high cost recoveries. There is a need to enhance these services through the introduction of better vehicles, more frequent trains and improvement to passenger amenities. It is clear that the National Rail Corporation brings risks as well as opportunities and we must ensure that the opportunities are grasped while the risks are avoided.

It is proper that the needed change in Victoria be looked at promptly. For example, there is a need to look to the issue of whether there ought to be special provision made for lines between Sydney and Melbourne so that the time for the journey can be reduced from 13 hours, as it is now, to 10 hours. It can be reduced with some improvements to infrastructure and at a relatively low cost. If this is done there is a chance that there will be re-engendered in Australia a culture of travelling by rail. To some extent, this has not been the situation in recent years but it was there in the old days. It provides a very safe alternative to travel by road and by plane.

I think Mr Dick Smith, who is the immediate past President of the CAA, said that we have to get more traffic off the roads. He proposed that it go into the air, but with improvement to the rails there is another alternative open. That would mean that Australia is provided with good air services, good road services and good rail services.
There are also proposals to bring Sprinter trains into Victoria, and if the planning is properly done that will ensure a good long term performance by both freight and passenger rail services.

I have spoken about the need to have national rail services. I have spoken about the need for Victoria, on the basis of that State being central to the prosperity of the nation as a whole, to have good rail services. It is a matter not only for Victoria but for the nation as a whole to see that the lines presently running in Victoria are run efficiently. There are proposals to re-route lines, for example, between Melbourne and Ballarat. When that is being considered, it should be considered not only in terms of what is best from the point of view of economics, although that is a very important issue, but in terms of what is best for the customer because, after all, it is the customer that must be properly served.
I have spoken about the development of rail transport with the recently appointed Secretary of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Railways Union, Mr Peter Bourke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he a relation of Brian?

—Since Senator Panizza has asked that question, I had better tell him that Mr Peter Bourke is a person who, like the honourable senator, has had much to do with the country. He was stationed in Bendigo and he performed a splendid service for his members in that area of country Victoria and, through them, for the State as a whole. He is a person who is dedicated to the upgrading of rail services and the proper provision of trains for the transport not only of cargo but also of passengers. I have spoken to him and to other members of that union such as the Deputy Secretary, Russell O'Brien, and they are dedicated to making the rail services in that State efficient.

PARA.TAB: This is a most imaginative scheme. It looks to the creation of a very efficient transport system throughout the nation, in union with business, with those companies such as BHP which make the steel for these lines; in conjunction with the unions, such as the Victorian Branch of the ARU; and nationally with Australians as a whole who are dedicated to the more efficient running of the nation.

Finally, I think this is the start of a great scheme in Victoria and in Australia as a whole. In years to come, history will reveal to people that it was one of the great undertakings by this Government. I would like to thank Mr Andrew Wilkinson and Mr Eric Ward, who provided me with much of the material that I have relied on and who have convinced me that rail is certainly the way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the National Rail Corporation Agreement Bill 1991, I begin by making some general observations with regard to transport.

PARA.TAB: First, it is important that the transport infrastructure in Australia is structured in such a way, and is so competitive, that whatever mode is used will be the most efficient and most economical way of carrying out the particular task. I do not think we should get carried away with promoting one against the other, as tends to happen from time to time in debates such as this. It is very important, as far as this Bill and the agreement that has been reached between the Commonwealth and the States are concerned, that in the medium and longer term the structure is such as to maximise the efficiency advantages of rail in the carriage of some goods, in those tasks that rail can carry out.

I do not think the proposed corporation should be seen as one that will necessarily lead to the replacement of road transport or of air transport. They all have a role to play. Under the regime we have had in Australian transport or in interstate transport, there have been disadvantages to different modes of transport, which have worked against the States within Australia using the most efficient means of carrying out a particular task.

I want to refer particularly to a couple of points as far as this Bill is concerned. Some of it must go back to the statement of last night, although I shall not dwell on it: the rail systems are still paying fuel excise. Fuel excise was put in place, as I am sure we are all well aware, initially for the task of building and maintaining roads. The rail system currently is, in effect, charged about 7c per litre of fuel that is used—to enhance a competitor. That in itself creates an anomaly and puts rail at a significant disadvantage as a transporter, particularly of bulk commodities. That is something that needs seriously addressing. I have raised it in this place and prior to coming here, on a number of occasions. It was not until we saw the light of day of the Fightback package that we actually saw this particular problem, which is a very unfair imposition on the rail system, being addressed. I bring it again to the attention of the Government.

Some years ago we found, in work that we did in Western Australia, that about 20 per cent of the direct cost of carting grain in Western Australia on rail arose as a direct result of the fuel excise. It put up significantly the cost to the individual producers whose wheat was carried on rail. It put the rail system at a significant disadvantage to road transport and it meant that a task that should have been carried out on rail was forced onto the road systems through bad economic policy.

The next concern I have about this Bill is the emphasis, when we have a States and Commonwealth agreement, on interstate carriage. Senator Cooney alluded to this. In terms of maximising the efficiency from this agreement, I ask whether enough consideration has been given to the impact that it could have within the States, particularly in my State of Western Australia. In a number of the tasks that are being carried out, and because of the different gauges of the railway line, it could put the State systems at a disadvantage.

I would hope that in the not too distant future we will see a statement from the Premiers of the various States, and the Commonwealth, as to how they will allow the various State systems to maximise an agreement such as this, as far as the cartage of goods within a State is concerned. Of course, the vast majority of the tasks carried out by rail, particularly in agriculture and mining, are carried out within the States. Having said that, I must add that I believe that this will also give the opportunity for goods and services, particularly bulk carriage of goods, to move between States much more efficiently and more effectively than has happened in the past.
There is another very great concern that I have in terms of this agreement. When we get down to the principles, we look at (iii) and (v). Paragraph (v) says:

SPEECH.PARA: provide access on a commercial basis to the NRC network and to terminal facilities for private and public sector operators;
I endorse that particular principle, but then when we go back to (iii), which says:
operate under labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award,. . .

I want to ask how we can have one enterprise award to cover the total operations for both the private and public sectors, in terms of this particular agreement. I do not believe that it can be effectively or efficiently done. In particular, when we get private operators coming onto the particular line or operation, we will find that they will be coming in to carry out a particular task.

PARA.TAB: There will be different requirements in terms of the manning levels, the hours, the stoppages and what is required to carry them out. For example, a quite different agreement would be required for the shifting of minerals across this country, from that required for, say, motor cars that were brought into the port of Fremantle, and put on the train to Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide or any of the capital cities. I believe it is quite ludicrous for us to see `operate under labour arrangements incorporated in an enterprise award' in the principles of the agreement. It really spells out clearly the problem that the Government has with its current industrial system when it operates on the basis of a fundamental principle that big is beautiful when, in fact, situations are quite different.

In Western Australia some years ago we saw the introduction of two-man crews for carriage of grain in our State. It was one of the decisions that kept a significant amount of grain on our rail system. In addition to that, obviously it kept the trains rolling. In fact, in terms of the grain task that was being carried out, it increased the number of people employed in the rail system by actually taking one person off a particular train, because more trains were running and carrying out that particular task. The situation in Victoria, South Australia, Queensland or New South Wales, could be quite different for different tasks.

As I am sure Senator Panizza would have mentioned, you have different crewing levels to carry out a task in the mining industry from those you have in the grain industry. You also have a different arrangement in terms of the cartage of wool on the rail system. Talking about wool, much of that has moved to road transport in recent years because it is a more efficient way of moving it.

But in terms of this agreement, I do question the wisdom of having as one of the principles that we operate under a single labour arrangement incorporated in an enterprise award. I think it is sheer nonsense. There must be flexibility in terms of the various tasks that have to be carried out. Hopefully, under this new agreement we will see an increase in passenger movement across Australia, but to try to have an enterprise award for the tasks that have to be carried out on a passenger train, as against a goods train or a bulk train, is really quite ludicrous.

The other point that I would like to raise here concerns the amendments relating to accountability. Senator Parer covered these, so I will not say a lot on them. But in terms of the accountability of such corporations as the National Rail Corporation it is essential that the Auditor-General be the auditor for the Corporation. I think that the reports on the accountability and the credibility of these particular operations and their overseeing should come through the Auditor-General and should be reported back to this Parliament on a consistent annual basis.

I conclude my remarks by saying, first, that it is important—and I re-emphasise this point—that transport policy must be designed so that the most efficient and most cost-effective of the modes of transport which can carry out the tasks wins each particular task. There should not be a loading in favour of rail, road or air transport. Secondly, it is essential that the impost of the fuel excise on rail transport in this country be removed so that it is not put at a disadvantage in relation to its competitors, particularly the road transport industry. Thirdly, in terms of the principles that are incorporated in this agreement, having a principle whereby one operates under labour arrangements incorporated in one enterprise award really amounts to staying in the Dark Ages and not moving into the nineties and the two thousands.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position of the Australian Democrats on issues is becoming increasingly unpredictable. They seem to wish to have the luxury of looking at each issue on a case by case basis, which gives no consistency in terms of their position on many fundamental issues. The issues that give me most concern are those of accountability to this Parliament. It was the Australian Democrats who endorsed the recommendation of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts. That recommendation was that the Australian National Audit Office was to be the auditor of government instrumentalities, including government corporations. At the time this did not fit easily with some Labor Party people. Increasingly we are seeing attempts by this Labor Government to usurp the fundamental role of the Auditor-General. It is increasing, and it is very disappointing to find the Australian Democrats—the people who want to keep everybody honest—falling into this attitude of relaxing the essential role that the Australian National Audit Office has to play in terms of its responsibilities to this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The role of the Auditor-General is essential to the accountability of this Parliament. The Auditor-General can perhaps be perceived as an extension of the arm of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts, with which it works most closely, and also of the Parliament itself. Indeed, the Auditor-General meets on a regular basis with members of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts.

I wish to state quite clearly, because there is some confusion, that the position of the Liberal-National coalition is in no way to be seen as a reflection on the private sector auditors or on the high professional manner in which they execute their responsibilities and the high ethical standards to which they adhere.

The issue is merely one of what is the appropriate authority to be the linkage between this Parliament and the statutory authorities in circumstances where the Commonwealth has a significant and a major financial interest. While members of this Senate are rightly concerned about community service obligations and the wider social responsibilities of statutory corporations, it is distressing to see legislation of this nature demeaning the role of the Auditor-General and replacing him as the essential link between these so-called increasingly independent statutory corporations and the Parliament. Increasingly, we are seeing such corporations—though not all of them—thumbing their noses at issues of social responsibility, community service obligations and accountability at times when it suits them. This is a serious contradiction, since all of these statutory corporations have a bureaucratic arm supposedly directed to meeting social responsibility criteria and accountability-type responsibilities.

Let me give an instance. Telecom has decided to centralise certain activities in Tasmania, with the result that a significant number of people will be moved from the north-west and the north of the State to Hobart. Unfortunately, Telecom did not see fit to communicate to the staff or to the wider community the cost-benefit behind this decision. It was an autocratic decision which appeared to lack logic to the unions and appeared to lack logic to the communities in which these staff members were located. I think this is typical of what is happening.

What we must see is a strengthening of the relationship between this Parliament and the statutory corporations, and that appropriate linkage is the Australian National Audit Office through the Auditor-General. We all know that the Auditor-General should be the final arbiter, but he does have the power to contract out audit responsibilities to the private sector and increasingly he is doing so. This is quite significant and quite appropriate. In fact, as issues are becoming more and more technical in certain areas, I think it is entirely appropriate that he should not only be relying increasingly on the private sector to provide audit services, in terms of getting teams of people in to audit particular activities of government instrumentalities, but also reaching out to seek advice on a technical nature from the private sector. Therefore, it is indeed an unfortunate time to see yet again a reversal in principle by these Australian Democrats sitting on the cross-benches who have such a significant impact on accountability issues, on moral issues, and on issues which affect the future of Australia.

Standards in this country are very much at risk. All too often this Parliament is being seen as a rubber stamp. In the House of Representatives two days ago, on an important tax Bill, the Government did not have an adviser to answer Opposition queries—on a technical tax Bill, No. 4. This is just another reflection on the fact that this Government wants to make this Parliament a rubber stamp. We must avoid that. The Auditor-General is central in maintaining proper accountability.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans)—by leave—agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Last week the commander of the UN Advance Mission in Cambodia, General Loridon, criticised the Khmer Rouge for obstructing UN personnel; on Tuesday the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Gordon Bilney, attacked the Khmer Rouge for jeopardising the Cambodian peace settlement; and today we learned that the commander of the Australian contingent in Cambodia has been shot whilst flying over an area known to be under Khmer Rouge control. When will the Minister come clean about the danger posed by the Khmer Rouge to the increasingly fragile peace settlement and to our forces in Cambodia?

—The area of Cambodia over which this unhappy incident occurred—an injury to Colonel Russell Stuart, who is the commander of the Australian contingent to the UN Advance Mission in Cambodia—is an area where the Khmer Rouge have been active. But it is by no means an area confined to the Khmer Rouge. In fact, it has been described as a patchwork quilt, involving occupancy on the ground by the three resistance factions. The only faction that is not in the immediate area that was the subject of the attack is in fact the SOC army of the present Phnom Penh administration.

PARA.TAB: So it is simply not to be assumed that the shots were fired by a member of the Khmer Rouge. Investigations are proceeding. It may never be known where the shot came from; it may never be known whether it was the result of some kind of order and some kind of semi-disciplined military exchange or whether rather it was the actions of a bored or disgruntled individual soldier. All of these things are possible. So the very premise of Senator Hill's question does not stand up to very close scrutiny.

It is, of course, the case that there are and will continue to be throughout the UN's occupancy of this transitional role in Cambodia, risks to the soldiers on the ground. We do not need rather unhappy grandstanding of the kind that we are listening to today from Senator Hill to be aware of those risks. We do not need to be reminded of them. We have stated them—Senator Ray, as Defence Minister, has done so; Mr Bilney has done so; I have done so—on innumerable occasions. There are risks from disease; there are risks from mines. There are risks of being exposed to some degree of sporadic fire or cross-fire in the context of the kind of military engagement that has happened on this occasion, particularly in the period before the disengagement of the various factions—their cantoning into barracks of one kind or another—and the putting aside of their arms is accomplished.

This is a very delicate and difficult stage of the peace operation, particularly in the absence still of the full-scale UNTAC group which is so crucial to the success of the operation. The risks will continue throughout this period. Our troops there are professional soldiers. They know of, are aware of and accept those risks—just as we have to be if we and other countries are going to make a contribution to the resolution of this very unhappy, drawn out, continuing tragedy in Cambodia.

We believe that the settlement process is very much on track. It has taken time to assemble the resources, both financial and otherwise, that are involved in the full scale UNTAC operation. My understanding is that tomorrow the UNTAC operation will be formally endorsed and approved by the UN system, and it is to be hoped that the deployments of the necessary personnel, both military and civilian, will now very rapidly proceed.

It does not help this process, which is going to be a protracted, difficult and rather fragile one, for it to be exposed to the kind of cynical shafts that we continue to get from Senator Hill. He and the Opposition have been no help whatsoever at any stage of the laborious attempts to put together a peace plan in Cambodia. He has hoped for nothing more than that some political advantage, as he saw it, could be gained by the process falling apart. It has not been an edifying sight to witness the role that he and the Opposition have played in this, and he has done nothing to improve his reputation by that question here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps we are a little more concerned about the safety of Australian personnel than the Minister is. If he was concerned, he would have put down a statement in the first instance. The Minister says the settlement processes are on track, so why is it that the new Secretary-General of the UN is now going back to the factions, arguing that they should agree to a 100 per cent demobilisation rather than the 70 per cent agreed at the Paris Peace Accords of which Senator Evans was a principal part?

—The Secretary-General's report to the General Assembly does express the view that 100 per cent demobilisation of the armed forces of the Cambodian parties would be preferable to the language of at least 70 per cent demobilisation provided for in the comprehensive settlement. Of course it would be preferable. Blind Freddy could see that 100 per cent demobilisation would be preferable. The biggest lunatic in the country could see that 100 per cent demobilisation would be preferable. It is obvious that it would be preferable. But the point is, it is unachievable, and the point is that the Secretary-General has recognised that the best that could be negotiated is a 70 per cent demobilisation. That is the language which remains in the settlement text; that is the language that remains in the plan that he and the United Nations have endorsed; and that is another cheap shot, another total misconstruction of the situation, demonstrating a combination of both incompetence and immorality in Senator Hill's approach to this particular issue.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation and relates to the significant changes to Australia's aviation policy as outlined last night in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement. Could the Minister indicate how soon the new policy decisions will be in place or will begin to take effect? In view of the importance of the tourist industry to the Australian economy and, in particular, to Queensland, can the Minister indicate whether the policy changes will assist this industry to expand and create additional employment opportunities?
—Read the Fightback! document.

—Senator Macdonald interjects and says that we should read the Fightback! document. Indeed I have. Obviously Senator Macdonald has not. I do want to say something briefly about the one paragraph that passes for an aviation policy in the 600-page Fightback! document. The Government is proposing very substantial changes to Australia's aviation policy that will take aviation, with confidence and with security for potential investors, into the twenty-first century.

PARA.TAB: The first stage of this process involves the immediate implementation of the removal of aviation specific restrictions on equity investments between Australian operators. That is, it breaks the barrier between international and domestic operations in Australia. The first stage is to proceed immediately to renegotiate our bilateral agreements that require renegotiation for multi-designation and to facilitate charter operations by Australian based operators.

The second stage, with implementation as soon as possible but no later than 1993, involves trans-Tasman services by inviting the New Zealand Government to agree to multiple designation on trans-Tasman routes with operations by any Australian or New Zealand carrier and Qantas domestic carriage. Implementation of a policy of multiple designation for Australian carriers is part of this stage of the proposal, along with allowing additional freight carriers to operate on international routes to and from Australia, and multiple designation for Australasian carriers in international markets at the end of the day, if we successfully negotiate a common aviation market with New Zealand.

This stage will centre on moves toward this common market and these changes will be of particular benefit to the vitally important tourism industry in this country—currently, as I said yesterday, the largest export earner that this country has, contributing fully 10 per cent of our total export earnings.

The Australian aviation industry already has an annual turnover in excess of $7 billion and directly employs 50,000 people with, of course, significantly more in indirect employment. A vigorous Australian aviation industry is essential for the continuing development of the tourism sector—a sector which accounted for 450,000 jobs in 1990-91.

The economic benefits of this new policy cannot be overstated in continuing the growth of employment in these important industries. The Government has adopted a strategy for change, unlike the Opposition's one paragraph throwaway in the Fightback! document.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have copied it all.

—I managed somehow to flesh it out to 20 pages. The one substantial difference between the Government's approach to aviation and the Opposition's is in the operation of international airlines in Australia. The Opposition has proposed an extremely dangerous and anti-Australian proposal in providing for substantial benefits to be given—the Opposition calls it the open skies policy—to the 35 international carriers that operate in Australia without any reciprocal benefits being offered to our Australian carriers in those countries.

PARA.TAB: Only this morning, when discussing these issues with senior officials of an international airline that travels to Australia, they expressed their astonishment that anybody would propose something like that. In order to assist the stability and certainty that we need in aviation for the benefit of the people who have to invest these sums of money, I ask the Opposition, firstly, to support these proposals, which I know it does; and, secondly, to indicate that it will not pursue the option it is advancing of providing significant rights for international carriers in Australia without negotiating reciprocal rights for Australian carriers in the countries from which those airlines come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation whether it is a fact that several Sydney Labor controlled councils have instituted a legal challenge to the construction of the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
—That is hardly news—I was referring to your back bench then.

—Just wait for the good part. Is it a fact that these court hearings are scheduled to be held around June and have the capacity to drag on for years? Is it a fact that, in view of the legal challenge, the FAC is moving at a leisurely pace with its planning, despite the fact that Cabinet accepted the $7m EIS submission in November last year and the Minister gave the Corporation an extra $1m so it could proceed rapidly with it?

—No, it is not true; it is fundamentally untrue. The opposite is in fact the case. The Federal Airports Corporation was proceeding with the planning for the third runway, as Senator MacGibbon says quite correctly, prior to the decision being taken by the Government. After the final decision was taken, the FAC board confirmed that decision and indicated, as a resolution of the board, that it would be proceeding with the runway.

PARA.TAB: As I said yesterday, work is proceeding apace with the third runway and I was briefed, as I am regularly, in Sydney only last week. The planning is proceeding apace; it is absolutely on track. We are confident the runway will be completed by 1995.

In respect of these court actions, I hope Senator MacGibbon is not suggesting in this democracy that we all enjoy that he actually prohibits the access of citizens to the courts. I hope he was not suggesting that. What is happening in the courts with the people who are quite rightly taking action that is available to them has nothing whatever to do with the process of planning so far as the FAC is concerned with the airport. It is proceeding regardless.

The next round, as I understand, in the courts will take place shortly—next month. We will find out then whether the councils even intend to proceed with this action. That is a matter for them. If they do, they will. In the meantime, the FAC will proceed with the construction of the third runway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I therefore can assume that if the legal challenge proceeds the delay is inevitable and that would help the Labor Party through the next election. Why did the Minister say in October last year that `physical construction would commence before the end of 1991'?
—The answer to Senator MacGibbon's supplementary question is no. It is not necessarily true that the court action will slow down or impede work.
—Not necessarily; it is highly likely.

—I cannot believe that Senator Alston was ever a lawyer. I qualify that statement for the benefit of our legal fraternity. What I meant by `it ain't necessarily true' is this: if the court action succeeds, it will delay the construction; if it fails, it will not. There is a fundamental legal principle in there somewhere, I say to Senator Alston.

PARA.TAB: The physical work on the runway has commenced. In terms of this furphy that Senator MacGibbon is chasing, I have to confess that last year I was offered the opportunity of having a sod turning ceremony at the airport to mark the start of the work because the fences were being put up. I was so busy putting together a new aviation policy for this country that I did not have the time to attend. Senator MacGibbon can check with the FAC and it will confirm that. I said to Mr Snelling, who offered me this opportunity last year, `Let us get the substantial stuff fixed and I will do the mickey mouse stuff later on this year'—which I will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the major changes to the taxation depreciation regime for new investment in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement last night. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the impact these changes will have on Australia's ability to attract new investment projects in the future?

—The depreciation allowances that were announced in the statement last night can benefit Australian industry and investment in a number of ways. The prime purpose of those changes to the depreciation system was to make the system of business tax in so far as it relates to investment much more competitive than it was with the international regime and in comparison with a number of other countries—countries with which we are sometimes traditionally compared, such as those in the OECD, and countries in our region where sometimes unusual depreciation and other investment incentives exist.

PARA.TAB: Accelerated depreciation will now be available for all plant and equipment assets with lives of over five years and for industrial buildings and tourist accommodation. This makes our tax treatment of investment competitive internationally and, I believe, will encourage business to invest in Australian industry.

Large benefits are available at the longer lived end of the assets scale, with plants with effective lives of 20 years now eligible for a 20 per cent declining balance write-off over 7.5 years. Together with the development allowance, which was also announced in the statement, these changes will create substantial benefits for major projects, particularly projects eligible for the development allowance of over $50m.

As far as the various elements of the depreciation changes are concerned, as I said, they emphasise longer lived assets. It is the Government's view that depreciation arrangements currently in place for short lived assets are fairly internationally competitive. For medium life assets, there are some changes which bring them more into line with international practice.

The One Nation document contains a comparative set of block graphs which show the position of Australia in respect of depreciation, following the announcement, compared with a variety of other countries. That shows that, even in the treatment of longer life assets, we are still behind a country such as Germany. On the other hand, the corporate tax rate in Germany is currently 65 per cent, I think, and we have a 39 per cent corporate tax rate in Australia.

Some people expected a return to 5:3 depreciation. I am not saying that Senator Watson did—I see him nod his head—but some people asked for that. We took away 5:3 as a government when the 39 per cent corporate tax rate was introduced. Then, 5:3 was a distortion in the taxation system because it gave effectively the same depreciating life to an asset of 30 years as it gave to an asset of six or seven years, for example. That was a significant distortion in the tax system. The proposals announced last night do not carry that distortion with them.

The changes are extremely significant for Australian industry. They are significant for the tourist industry as well, and they will be very helpful in the longer term in encouraging investment in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows the previous question. Yesterday's economic statement says that additional financial incentives to industry `will not select on the basis of preferred industry sectors'. Is the Government genuine in its commitment to ecological sustainability and, if so, why does it not direct these incentives and/or others so as to move the economy in the preferred direction? On the contrary, why is it selecting the offshore banking industry for special and favoured treatment? Why is it reducing the tax rate on offshore banking units from 39 per cent to 10 per cent, when the lowest tax rate most Australians can expect is 30 per cent? Will this not encourage further offshore speculation and a further diversion from productive investment at home?

—I suppose it is inherent in all questions from the Leader of the Australian Democrats that we should have preferred industries and that they should be the ones that he prefers—and nobody else. Let me make it quite clear that there are no preferred industries in measures of general application such as depreciation allowances, or in the 10 per cent development allowance which accompanies the changed depreciation regime. That is the Government's intention.

PARA.TAB: The industries which become the beneficiaries of these things will self-select. They are not to be selected by government or by the Australian Democrats or by anybody else. They will self-select. That does not mean that governments cannot, in an additional way to general measures, help particular industries by removing impediments to their progress of one kind or another. That is what we have been doing and what we will continue to do.

If we take, for example, the waste management industry—which I am sure is of interest and concern to Senator Coulter—the Government has in a variety of ways given help to the waste management industry: in bringing together the research community in that area and companies, in facilitating seminars and exchange of information, market opportunities and things of that kind. That is a facilitating role which the Government can play with an industry like that, and we will continue to do it.

Senator Coulter asked about the proposal in relation to the offshore banking facility. We in Australia are in a competitive world and, with the changes taking place in Hong Kong, there is a continued search for alternative venues for offshore banking facilities. Singapore has been quick, as usual—and I congratulate it on its quickness—to create offshore banking facilities in Singapore. We have an opportunity to do the same.

It is not as if one can compare the tax concession granted to offshore banking facilities with the taxation paid by Australian individuals or Australian companies. The fact of the matter is that there is no income at all at present from an offshore banking unit. The 10 per cent taxation will apply to income which this country would never otherwise get. It is not to be compared with the personal tax or the company tax regimes.

I believe, and Mr Greiner believes, for example, that there is great advantage in facilitating the development of offshore banking facilities in Australia. The danger about offshore banking facilities is that domestic banks will use them to try to obtain the lower tax benefit which applies to offshore banking. That has to be carefully fixed up in the legislation. When Singapore introduced offshore banking it found that there were one or two indications of abuse of that system. The relevant bankers were told that they would have to leave Singapore at 8 o'clock the following morning or they would be in gaol at 9 o'clock. They have had no further trouble there.

We have to be careful to make sure that the legislation is rigorous in terms of penalties in respect of any abuse of that system. I think that it creates an opportunity. I do not think that it is in any sense detrimental to the well-being of Australian taxpayers generally. In fact, it will add taxation revenue which would never before have existed if that opportunity had not been offered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from the Minister's reply that he believes unadorned market forces with which he will not interfere will move us towards an ecologically sustainable economy? Secondly, as he has indicated that there is no money currently going through this offshore banking industry and therefore we are deriving no benefit from it, does it not follow that if he is expecting to get income from it there will be a diversion of investment from Australia and into offshore banking?

—It is not about diversion of investment but new investments. I cannot follow Senator Coulter down the garden path into all these spooky scenarios that he finds in the woodshed. In answer to the first part of his question, no, I do not believe that unadorned market forces will produce an ecologically sustainable development economy.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In the light of public comment this morning, can the Minister inform the Senate of the projections for growth outlined in last night's economic statement and the basis on which those projections were calculated? Can the Minister outline the importance of the Government's agreement for the Labor movement to achieving those forecasts for growth?

—I would like a word with Senator Schacht afterwards, as he said he intended to ask me a different question. I was in danger of giving him the answer. He has asked me an important question about forecast growth.
—What was the other one?

—We will have to wait until next week. Senator Schacht asked me about forecast growth in 1992-93 contained in the statement given last night of 4.75 per cent. Last night the Prime Minister outlined the scenario for later years with growth of 4.5 per cent in 1993-94, 4.25 per cent in 1994-95 and 3.75 per cent in 1995-96. These figures are achievable.
—No-one believes them.

—Let me tell Senator Short why, because he is clearly a man of little faith, except for some recently discovered faith, which I shall refer to in a moment. Let me mention the lesson of history in relation to recessions in Australia. I know that Opposition senators such as Senator Short believe that history began the day John Hewson announced his plan for a new tax-led recovery. To look at history in terms of this post-recessionary experience in the Australian economy is very instructive. In the three years following the 1982-83 recession—that is, the recession of those opposite—this Government delivered growth of 6 per cent, 5 per cent, and 4 per cent. The 1961 recession—a Liberal government recession—was followed by growth of 6 per cent, 7 per cent and 7 per cent in the next three years.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite do not want to listen. As the anxiety rises, so does the level of interjection. I understand that lot very well. The 1974-75 recession was an exception. After the 1974-75 recession the growth rates were 2.7 per cent, 2.9 per cent and 4 per cent. The reason for the failure of growth after the 1974-75 recession was that there was no wages policy. That reduced the profit share for Australian companies very significantly. For the information of Senator Bishop, who is showing a lively interest in this answer, this current recession has not been preceded by a wages explosion.
—No-one believed you in the last eight years, so they won't believe you now.

—Perhaps if Senator Macdonald opened his ears and shut his mouth for a minute he would understand that this current recession has not been preceded by a wages explosion. The profit share of Australian companies—the factor share—is structurally sound.
—It is the lowest for 25 years.

—Oh, come on, do not talk rubbish; it is structurally sound. The forecasts, which are consistent with early signs of recovery in the economy and consistent with those of private sector commentators, quite apart from lessons of post-recession experience in Australia, are in this situation based on low interest rates and improving, although still very subdued, international economic conditions. In saying that, I think we should remember the importance to the economy of the trade with countries in this region, which is still growing strongly. For example, OECD forecasts underline the strength of the Asian economies with which we trade. The OECD says that imports by the Asian countries will grow in volume by between 8 and 12 per cent in 1992 and 1993.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite—I am not looking at the Australian Democrats—are fixed in a sort of static model of the Australian economy which derives from their limited experience in government. The fact of the matter is that the whole performance of the Australian economy in terms of trade has undergone an extraordinary structural change in the last decade. Just as our relationship with Great Britain has undergone an extraordinary structural and historic change, which some people in the Party opposite do not seem to accept, so has the trading relationship of this country changed. The importance of the relationship with countries in the Asian-Pacific region is very significant in looking at the world scene and the forecasts of growth which are given in the One Nation statement.

Other things which are important are the depreciation in the exchange rate since late 1991; a cyclical recovery in stocks which is starting to take place; and, of course, the breaking of the drought. That is just in relation to the short term forecasts which are immediately post-recovery. There are longer term scenarios dealt with in the statement. I will not go into those at this time, but if anyone wants to ask me about them I am quite happy to go into them.

There is one thing that I can say with certainty: people can criticise these forecasts but, whatever one says about them, they are not horrible forecasts like the Opposition's, as evidenced in the document published by Chris Murphy the other day, in terms of unemployment, growth in GDP and all the significant indicators which affect the Australian people. They are very bad forecasts. They are part of an ideological exercise which would mean medium term pain of great intensity in order to achieve some distant ideological goal, perhaps by the year 2010.

TALK.START.PARA: —We provide for jobs.

—Senator Hill says that the Opposition's forecasts provide jobs, jobs, jobs. Every forecast provides unemployment, unemployment, unemployment. Honourable senators opposite have to get used to one thing: it is all very well to take comfort from the present recession, but in the next 12 months—

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. We have been very tolerant. I draw your attention to standing order 73. Would you kindly ask the Minister not to give an expression of opinion, not to state the Government's policy or give a legal opinion, as he has done through the entire course of his answer, and to conclude his answer.

—Order! The answer is a very long one. I point out to Government Ministers that, counting supplementaries, there have been only nine questions today. However, the position is not helped by constant interjections, which extend Ministers' answers.

—Mr President, Senator Bishop described my answer as tiresome. I thought Senator Bishop had been particularly tolerant and charming today; and I thank her for that. The fact is that over the next 12 months we are going to put the blowtorch right on the Opposition. The scenarios which the Opposition has announced—they are right there in its document—will be in every household in Australia. Senator Hill, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, says, `Jobs, jobs, jobs'. I ask Senator Hill: when, when, when—in the year 2010?

—My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given that the Government has deliberately budgeted for a cumulative deficit in the Budget of $20 billion for the four years to 1994-95, how is it to be funded?

—It is all very well to add up three years of Budget deficits, but in the papers there is a statement of our intention to bring the Budget back into balance by the year 1995-96. There has been some suggestion by some commentators about an increase in the PSBR. There is a word or two in the statement about that and I will refer Senator Short to it in a minute.

PARA.TAB: Everybody is talking about Max Walsh. Max Walsh has been writing the script for Apocalypse Now since 1967. He has done it every year. He did it to those opposite; he has done it to everybody else. I do not deride him for that at all. He has been a very sensible voice at many times on many issues. But he cannot resist the Apocalypse Now article every now and again and he did it yesterday.

In so far as the PSBR is concerned, not many commentators agree with Max Walsh, I must say. The Budget-time estimate for the PSBR in 1991-92 was 4.3 per cent, up from 1.7 per cent in 1990-91. The current 1991-92 estimate is broadly unchanged at about 4 per cent. Increased Commonwealth and State government borrowing requirements are expected to be offset by lower borrowings by the Wool Corporation and the Wheat Board. Beyond that, the net PSBR is expected to decline to about 2 per cent of GDP in 1995-96. The expected fall in the net PSBR after 1991-92 is basically a reflection of the expected decline in the Commonwealth Budget deficit, which is referred to in the statement, and the other elements of the public sector are expected to have broadly offsetting movements in their net borrowing requirements over the period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is quite clear that the Minister is not even aware that the Government's economic statement contains not one word on how that massive cumulative deficit is going to be funded. I ask: if the deficit is to be funded by increased sales of government bonds, what is the impact of that demand for funds on domestic interest rates? Can the Minister give an assurance that interest rates will not increase, particularly in the light of the continuing collapse in company profits, as evidenced by the further 20 per cent fall in company profits in the December quarter of 1991 announced today—to the lowest figure since the December quarter 1987?

—I am glad the honourable senator got his facts right about company profits. He was interjecting earlier that they were the lowest for 20 years. The year 1987 is not, in my understanding, 20 years ago. The honourable senator has to have either his interjections right or his questions right; he cannot have both.

PARA.TAB: The honourable senator raised the question of increased demand for government bonds. I have already referred to the public sector borrowing requirement. The honourable senator then went on to ask whether I would give an undertaking about interest rates. No, I am not prepared to do that; I have never done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet you are not.

—Senator Short can make all sorts of spooky analyses himself. They have never been right when they have come from him. The Government is very confident about being able to maintain low interest rates, and we will continue to do that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. As part of the Prime Minister's One Nation statement, have the Government and the union movement agreed to principles to govern pre-start industrial agreements? Can the Minister advise whether such pre-start industrial agreements will contribute to greater investment being undertaken in Australia?
—What exactly is `pre-start'?

—The Government and the ACTU have agreed on some basic rules for pre-start industrial agreements. Senator Hill interjected, `What is a pre-start agreement?'. That is a fair enough interjection. What we refer to is the sort of agreement that was concluded between the ACTU and the Toyota motor company to enable the Toyota greenfields development—an investment of $420m—to go ahead in Altona, Victoria, just last year. That is the sort of agreement we are talking about.

PARA.TAB: The objective of these pre-start agreements is to signify now to all would-be investors in major development projects in Australia that it is possible on greenfields investments to arrive at substantial improvements in industrial relations performance by reaching agreement on certain principles beforehand; and for existing companies, where they wish to undertake major expansion in their enterprise, for that expansion to obtain the same sorts of arrangements. Therefore, investors will know what the industrial relations outcomes will be before they actually start—before a sod is turned or before they start the development of a project.

The sorts of features that these agreements will contain are understandings or agreements on what is the best way to organise work patterns and job design for the particular project, how employee consultation can be built into the industrial relations relationship, and how to get optimal use out of capital equipment and capital investment in the project. The guidelines will be world best practice in quality, efficiency and reliability. That will be the objective underpinning the sorts of work patterns and job designs we will aim for.

They will also contain agreements, if possible, to get one union on site or, during the transitional stage where it is not possible to get one union because of the rationalisation the union movement is undergoing, at least to have one bargaining unit so that all unions, whichever area they come from and represent, will bargain together. The effect for the employer will be a single union agreement. That will help remove demarcation disputes that have bedevilled some projects in the past. It will also aim to ratify award coverage. The preference that we will be expressing is for one single workplace agreement, and I think that is strongly what the ACTU's preference is as well. The agreements will contain dispute settlement provisions to avoid disputes.

These sorts of pre-start agreements will encourage investment. They will be a feature of our $454m investment in Australian rail development. That investment is predicated on getting these agreements in advance. It will mean that investors in tax free bonds for public infrastructure development will have an advantage. It will also mean that there is a demonstration of our commitment to the evolving cooperative nature of industrial relations in this country and to getting major project development off the ground quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I would like to ask the question which I think Senator Schacht had in mind. Would the Minister care to explain the social justice implications of the proposal in last night's grotesquely misnamed One Nation political manifesto that the bottom 42 per cent of taxpayers should get no income tax reductions, whilst someone on $100,000 a year will be almost $2,500 better off? Would the Minister also confirm that today's front page story in the Telegraph Mirror alleging that the Government is offering $46 a week in personal tax cuts for the average worker is fundamentally inaccurate?

—I have not seen the article in the Telegraph Mirror. It is a fair assumption that it may be wrong, but I think Senator Alston should ask the editor of the Telegraph Mirror about that, not me. In so far as the social justice implications are concerned, I am sure my colleague the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security would provide a more detailed answer than I can. The long term taxation regime which has been outlined in the statement certainly greatly improves the taxation position of a whole range of Australian lower to middle income earners.
—But not the poor.
—Well, I am not avoiding the question.
—You are not answering it.

—I cannot answer it in terms of the detail, but the Government has a whole range of social justice policies which are published and available and they are designed to take care of those people on lower incomes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from that that the Minister is saying, `Well, there may be some social justice implications in some of our other proposals, but as far as this one is concerned, I cannot volunteer one piece of evidence to suggest that this is other than socially unjust for those 42 per cent of taxpayers'. Also, what income tax cut will be offered to a person on average weekly earnings under the Government's proposal?
—I represent the Treasurer in this place and I will get an answer from the Treasurer to those parts of the question which relate to tax.
—Don't you know?

—I said that I represent the Treasurer in this place and I will obtain an answer in relation to those parts of the question which relate to tax. I will also obtain an answer for Senator Alston on the social justice implications in the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to statements made by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, on Sydney radio today when he stated that `wages for young people had been too high'. Will the Minister explain this statement and will he confirm the Government's intention to slash youth wages, thus ensuring that those young people able to find a job are left open to exploitation by employers as their living conditions fall below the poverty line?

—I did not hear the comment that has allegedly been made by the Treasurer that youth wages are too high. I do know that this Government is concerned to change the basis of the fixation of youth wages. The problem in the past has been that youth wages have been determined by the age of the worker and not by the types of skills, abilities or qualifications that that worker might have and bring to the task of work that is allocated to him.

PARA.TAB: The Government wants to change the nature of the fixation of youth wages to one that recognises qualifications, skill and experience and to set the wage not on the basis of age but on the basis of the contribution the individual can make to the workplace. Therefore, if a young worker has the qualifications and is able to do a job that is done by an adult worker, then the right rate of pay should be closer to that of the adult worker rather than that youth worker being tied to an age rate which could mean that his real ability and contribution to the enterprise are being exploited.

The Government is discussing that concept at the present time. Some further development of it has to be undertaken before it can be introduced as the standard. It is consistent with the restructuring of awards that we have undertaken around Australia. We have encouraged workers to become more highly skilled, to seek training, to broaden their qualification base, and to receive wage increases based on that type of training and improved qualification.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does that mean that youth workers will have to compete with adult workers for the same jobs?

—It does not mean that. It means that if a youth worker is doing the job that an adult is doing and has similar skills and qualifications, he should receive similar wages. The number of jobs that young workers are sometimes used in, such as couriers, telephonists and simple jobs like that, are drying up in this community. We need to recognise that the future young workers of this country must be hooked into a training regime in which they regularly update their qualifications to suit the needs of industry. They should see training and education as a lifelong process, not a process that ends when they leave school or at the end of an apprenticeship. It does not mean to say that youth workers will necessarily be displaced.

PARA.TAB: On the question of reductions in youth wages, there is a fond view presented sometimes by the Opposition that if we slashed youth wages more young workers would be employed. Anyone who has looked at the labour market figures would have to agree that the slash would have to be very deep indeed for that economic device to show any improvement at all in youth employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the vague changes to the industrial relations system that were outlined in the One Nation statement. I ask: will individuals or small groups have the right to make their own workplace agreements? Under what circumstances will the Industrial Relations Commission be able to refuse registration of a workplace agreement? Will there be any right of intervention before the Commission by third party employer or employee organisations with respect to whether any agreement should be registered?
—There is an abysmal lack of understanding and knowledge in the Opposition about how industrial relationships in Australia work.
—Just answer the question.

—I am answering the first part of Senator Vanstone's question, which was: can individuals or small groups make their own independent agreements? Most of the awards of the Industrial Relations Commission, particularly in the private sector, are minimum rates awards. The normal characteristic is that workers and employers agree to overaward payments either collectively through their union organisation or individually with their employers and sometimes in small groups.

PARA.TAB: So please do not propound the continuing fantasy that bedevils Mr Howard and assumes that there is no discussion in most Australian workplaces between workers and employers about whether or not individual workers are entitled to an extra margin above what the minimum rate prescribed by the Commission might be. It is the normal characteristic of the workplace. I have to say that in larger workplaces the normal characteristic is that that is done by direct overaward negotiation with the union. None of the features in the new industrial relations system that we will introduce will change any of that.

The conditions under which agreements may be registered in the future and the role of third parties are matters that will be partly picked up in the discussions that the Prime Minister has foreshadowed with the ACTU tomorrow. We will be conducting negotiations with the ACTU to deliver on the commitments that we have made in the one country statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called `One Nation' actually.
—The One Nation statement. I might say as well that, since they do, or may, involve changes to industrial law, consistent—
—How?

—Well, Senator Hill is a lawyer. He is a member of a profession that has more restrictive work practices than any other. The legal fraternity in Australia is the best example of the most restrictive work practices I have ever seen anywhere, and Mr Greiner is to be congratulated on trying to do something about that. But we will come to those terms and, if there are changes in industrial law, we will of course consult with the other industrial parties as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister for Industrial Relations was asked whether individuals or small groups have the right to make their own workplace agreements. Do I take it from what he is saying that basically the situation is not going to change much; that any negotiation below a minimum rate will not be allowed? The Minister was silent on the question of whether there will be any negotiation about terms and conditions, which can be just as important as salary rates. Will he allow any negotiation on matters that are not in an award? Do any changes have to be upwards? But, more importantly, is he honestly telling this chamber that, notwithstanding the announcement that the Prime Minister made last night and the rhetoric about new and advanced changes to the industrial relations system, he will not have a clue about the ideas until he talks to the union tomorrow?

—No, of course not. Tomorrow we will be seeking to obtain the agreement of the ACTU to the wages figuring that we have in our statement. I might say, in view of the reaction of spokesmen of the organisation, I am confident that agreement will be obtained. Might I also say, that distinguishes us in delivering the economic outcomes—
—You are a hopeless wimp.

—I am sorry, I thought the honourable senator had finished her question. Does she wish to interject further? That will assist the productivity surge that this country is about to witness across the community as the recovery takes hold, and the workplace bargaining arrangements that we are making will ensure that that productivity surge is ongoing.

PARA.TAB: But let me go very quickly to the detail of the honourable senator's supplementary question and conclude on this point: the minimum rate determined by the Commission in respect of the wage that an industry sector can afford to pay can be styled the umpire's decision. If honourable senators opposite are asking us to flout the decision of the umpire and go below what the umpire thinks is fair and reasonable, I will say that that is the big thing which distinguishes the Opposition from this Government.

We are committed to protecting the right of individual workers, who do not have a strong bargaining position and who otherwise can be exploited, by ensuring that there are minimums below which they cannot be exploited. That means recognising the role of the Commission and accepting the umpire's decision on minimum determinations. It does not mean, as Mr Howard seems always to imply and the honourable senator is now inferring, that, by the removal of the safety net of minima, workers can, during a time of high labour market unemployment, have their living standards driven down by merciless and exploitative employers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Transport and Communications inform the Senate of the Government's intentions in relation to road funding? Will the nation benefit from these proposals?

—I thank Senator Foreman for that excellent question. The announcement in the economic statement, One Nation, made by the Prime Minister last night, of an extra $600m to be spent on roads in Australia during the course of the next couple of years will be greeted by Australians as being very important indeed.
