There will be a great deal of gratitude for the 15,000 direct jobs that this will create. The nation will benefit tremendously from the number of indirect jobs it will also create.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, if we can get goods to and from ports more cheaply, we must benefit as a trading nation. That is precisely what the Government has set about doing in the strategy outlined last night for rail, road and ports. We have announced a $350m scheme for the untying of grants at the conclusion of the current program of road funding for the States. Also, $255m—an enormous amount of money—will be allocated to maintenance across the national highway system. That means jobs that can be created not only in the great cities but also right across the rural areas of Australia. It is labour intensive work; the jobs are quickly available; and no doubt a tremendous number of people will benefit.
In addition, $140m will be spent on some ring-roads—not just any old ring-roads, but three in particular that provide exactly the strategy that I spoke about before.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Victoria!
—I refer to a Port of Brisbane link in Queensland; the Liverpool-Hornsby ring-road in Sydney—
—That is not in Victoria.

—To the best of my recollection, I do not think that is in Victoria. I also refer to the western ring-road in Melbourne. Any suggestion that they are all in Victoria would be like most of the other suggestions that Senator Macdonald has made in the last few days. His problem is that he has been sitting there like a stunned mullet since the statement came down last night. Those three ring-roads are programs of tremendous national significance and we would hope that even the Opposition would understand their importance.

PARA.TAB: It is only fair that the national highway system should be expanded to include links not just between Sydney and Melbourne, that people have concentrated on, but between Sydney and Adelaide and between Melbourne and Brisbane. So the Sturt and Newell highways have been added to that plan as well. This will benefit people from the four capital cities—not just from one or two and certainly not just from Victoria. As well as all of that, there is another $70m going to the black spots program. This will save lives around Australia in the next two years. Many lives will be saved just because the Commonwealth has been prepared to put in a great deal of extra money, and it could not have picked a better time to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 July 1991 Senator Alston asked the Minister representing the Treasurer a question on notice about schemes in his portfolio relating to access by people aged 60 years and so on. I have an answer which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
—Is leave granted?
—Yes, on the basis that the Minister also explain the inordinate delay.
—If the honourable senator does not want it to be incorporated, it does not have to be.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: (Question No 1074)

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, on notice, on 26 July 1991—

Name each of the programs and schemes in your portfolio which are accessed primarily by people aged 60 years and over or have been set up specifically for such people and what was the appropriation for each of these schemes in 1990-91.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the Honourable Senator's question—

PARA.TAB: The Portfolio has a nil response, apart from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).

The ATO has no programs accessed primarily by people aged 60 years and over. However, two publications, `Income Tax and the Single Aged Pensioner' and `Income Tax and the Married Aged Pensioner', are clearly directed at this group. The printing expenses incurred for these leaflets amounted to $5,500 in 1990-91.

In addition, aged people were significant users of the `Tax Help' scheme, which provides assistance to the disadvantaged in completing their tax returns, using community volunteers. This scheme was set up specifically for disadvantaged people including the aged.
The scheme attracted 18,086 clients in 1990-91, categorised as follows:
Aged9,152
Ethnic origin3,693
Low income3,658
Aborigine or Torres Strait Islander504
Disabled423
``Other''656

This means that aged clients comprised at least 50.6% of users of the service, given those who may have been identified as being of ethnic origin, disabled, or some category other than aged. The scheme cost $257,000 in direct salary cost and an estimated $104,000 in administrative expenses to run in 1990-91.
Other programs which may be accessed by people over 60 are:

INTERJECT.PARA: the Counter Service project, an extension of the ELS transmission service which gives disadvantaged taxpayers help with their tax return and allows them to have it lodged electronically at a Taxation Office. Counter Service runs in the peak lodgment months of July to October, and

the Outreach project, an extension of the Counter Service project, whereby Taxation Officers go out into the community to give help with tax returns and have portable terminals on which they lodge returns electronically. Outreach was conducted as a pilot in July-November 1991 in Canberra and among Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: In 1991, its first year, Counter Service assisted 23,294 people, of whom 3,238 (13.9%) were pensioners. Statistics do not show the different categories of pensioners, but it is likely that the majority were aged pensioners. It cost $201,139 in salaries and $19,038 in administration.

In the 5-month outreach pilot, 271 clients were assisted and 204 returns were lodged. Of these clients, 32 (11.8%) were pensioners. Again, the statistics do not show the different categories of pensioners, but most would be aged pensioners, ie over 60. The pilot cost $34,956 in salaries and $8,010 in administration.
Booklets and pamphlets have also been designed on pensioner rebates and tax file numbers. These booklets were for ATO staff to assist this group in answering taxpayer enquiries more effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 December 1991, Senator Coulter asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the possible involvement of Australian banks in conduiting funds to Saddam Hussein's weapons development program. The Treasurer has provided me with an answer to the honourable senator's question and I seek leave to incorporate that in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 December 1991 (Hansard page 4875) Senator Coulter asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the possible involvement of Australian Banks in conduiting funds to Saddam Hussein's Weapons development program. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

INTERJECT.PARA: The question of possible involvement of Australian banks in channelling funds to Saddam Hussein's weapons development program and the possible involvement of Australian banks with BCCI has been referred to all Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. The following information has been made available by those agencies.

BCC Australia Limited, a wholly-owned subsidiary of BCCI Holdings (Luxembourg SA) the holding company for the BCCI group of companies, was incorporated on 2 August 1985 to engage in merchant banking activities. It held a dealer's licence under the Securities Industry (New South Wales) Code which it surrendered during 1990. The Australian Securities Commission (ASC) has been monitoring the position of BCC Australia Limited since the events involving the Bank of Credit and Commerce International first came to notice in July last year.

On 8 July 1991 Mr John William O'Brien was appointed provisional liquidator of the Australian company by order of the New South Wales Supreme Court pursuant to the company's own petition. A report as to affairs was lodged with the ASC on 16 August 1991. The ASC has conducted a preliminary investigation of the affairs of the company. This enquiry has not revealed any failure to comply with the provisions of the Corporations Law.

BCC Australia Limited because of the nature of its activities, was a cash dealer for the purposes of the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and as such was required to comply with the reporting requirements of the Act.

On 17 December 1991 following an arrangement with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), officers of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (CTRA) together with officers from the ASC conducted an inspection of the accounting records of BCC Australia Limited.

The purpose of the CTRA audit was to ascertain whether or not the Company had complied with the reporting requirements of the Cash Transaction Reports Act. The result of CTRA enquiries cannot be made public as the secrecy provision of the Act (Section 25) prohibits the disclosure of information obtained by a person in the course of performing duties under the Act.
As the affairs of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International are still under investigation it is inappropriate to provide further comment regarding operational aspects of the investigation.
The Reserve Bank has not investigated any allegations concerning involvement of Australian banks in conduiting funds to Saddam Hussein's weapons development programme.

BNL Atlanta maintained a very large number of relationships with banks outside of the United States. As far as Australian authorities are aware, there is no suggestion that any of those banks conducted this relationship with BNL Atlanta on a basis other than expected of international banks operating in the wholesale interbank market. The nature of such credit lines is such that one bank can draw on them without the creditor bank knowing the use to which the funds are being put.
The Reserve Bank has not undertaken any investigation concerning any alleged involvement of Australian banks with the Bank of Credit and Commerce International.

Further, the Reserve Bank has informed the Treasurer that it has not been asked by any of the overseas authorities that might be looking into these questions, to investigate any involvement by Australian banks.
The Reserve Bank has indicated it is not aware of any links between the operations of BCCI and the former merchant bank, Nugan Hand, in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 December, Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question regarding taxation depreciation. I now have an answer to that question and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: On the 19 December 1991 Senator Watson asked me as Minister representing the Treasurer a question regarding taxation depreciation.
The Treasurer has supplied the following answer:

As mentioned in responding to the honourable Senator's question on 19 December 1991, legislation giving effect to taxation depreciation changes announced on 12 March 1991 was introduced into the House of Representatives on that day.

Having regard particularly to the needs of corporate taxpayers with a balancing date of 31 December in lieu of 30 June, a considerable effort was made to ensure that the amending Bill and Explanatory Memorandum were publicly available in time for the parliamentary Christmas recess.

It is also relevant to mention that, following consultations between officials and a large number of industry bodies and tax professionals, a detailed Statement of the intended operation of the depreciation changes was issued on 26 September 1991 by the then Treasurer, Mr Kerin, and myself.

In cases like this where some taxpayers may be obliged to compute taxable income prior to the enactment of announced legislative changes, the Commissioner of Taxation has advised that taxpayers who make the computation reasonably based on the announced changes or, in this case, the amending Bill will not be subject to penalty tax.
I understand the honourable Senator has been advised to this effect by one of the Commissioner's senior officials.

In summary, the honourable Senator may be assured that no corporation liable to pay a 1992 company tax instalment prior to the enactment of the introduced legislation will be penalised for any reasonable reduction in the instalments based on the changes as announced or as contained in the Bill presently before the Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week Senator Baume asked me a question about youth unemployment figures. I have a reply, but it is quite long. Will the Senate extend me leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard rather than have me read it?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Mr President in reply to a question from Senator Baume from Tuesday's question time I offer the following.

Senator Baume asked a question about youth unemployment and how my colleague the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services arrived at the figure of 8.8 per cent as the percentage of young people seeking full-time work and unable to find it.

The 8.8 per cent figure is simply the number of young people who are full-time unemployed as a percentage of the young people between the ages of 15-19 years. The 30 per cent figure is the number of unemployed young people as a percentage of young people in the full-time labour force.

In asking his question Senator Baume alleged that the 8.8% was a `phoney figure' and that the Minister had claimed that the 30% figure was misleading. In fact neither is the case—as we have already seen 8.8% is the correct figure to describe the number of young people who are unemployed as a percentage of the teenage population.

What is phoney is Senator Baume's constant use of the 30% figure as if 1 in 3 of all young people in the teenage population are unable to find a job. I refer to his press release of 16 February which boasts that there are `No Jobs For 1 in 3 Young Australians'. Granted Senator Baume gets it right in the text of his release but the implication is clear; Senator Baume wants to make the situation sound even worse than it is. He wants people to believe that every 1 in 3 of all the young people in the 15-19 age category are unemployed. In fact what we have is a situation where the majority of young people in the age group are in further education. About 1 in 10 of all young people in the age group are unemployed.

Mr President, no one on this side of the Parliament thinks that youth unemployment at it's current level is satisfactory but Senator Baume and others of his scaremongering type delight in making it sound worse.

What is phoney is the Opposition's Fightback package which has absolutely NOTHING specific in the great thumping doorstop of a thing (because that's about all it's good for) for young people who are disadvantaged, that is the type of young people who Senator Baume sheds crocodile tears for.

The only thing they say is that they will abolish the Youth Bureau which amongst other things administers grant programs for disadvantaged young people. They will abolish the CES not realising that abolishing them also abolishes Youth Access Centres which are designed to help young people especially the disadvantaged. What vision! What foresight!
Concerning the second part of the question that Senator Baume raised in his supplementary question, no-one has ever claimed that the youth unemployment rate is less than the adult rate.

If one were to calculate the share of unemployment in the total population, the figure would be 6.5 per cent. No-one has ever suggested that this is the true unemployment rate amongst adults—because obviously the great bulk of the 5 million or so adults who are not in the labour force are not doing anything of immediate relevance to the labour market.

The same does not apply to young people—the great bulk of the 537,000 15-19 year olds who are not in the labour force (either full-time or part-time) are in education and training, which is of direct relevance to their future labour market prospects.

Mr President, the only people who have been misleading in this debate are the Opposition—who continue to pretend that a 30 per cent youth unemployment rate mean that 30 per cent of all young people are unemployed. That is manifestly untrue and Senator Baume's righteous indignation is just an indication that he has been caught out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given this day by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume on 25 February 1992 relating to youth unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Archer asked me a question about the Australian-Russian fishing agreement. Again, I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

There is a fishing Agreement between the Australian and former Soviet Governments that entered into force on 15 February 1990. Article III of this Agreement indicates that Australia shall permit USSR fishing vessels to carry out feasibility fishing operations in areas of the Australian Fishing Zone. Any such feasibility fishing that is agreed must conform with the Agreement, any subsidiary agreement, Australian law and an annex to the Agreement which sets out procedures relating to such operations.

The management of Commonwealth fisheries is now the responsibility of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA). A subsidiary agreement was signed by AFMA on 25 February 1992 to allow a joint venture operation involving an Australian company and Russian interests to use a Russian vessel for feasibility fishing in the Great Australian Bight (GAB) fishery.

The GAB fishery is still considered to be a developmental fishery and there is provision in the Management Plan for up to three large vessels to be licensed for limited periods to carry out exploratory fishing in the offshore areas. While this provision has existed for some time, there has been very little interest and until this joint venture operation there was only one such vessel doing exploratory fishing in the area.

The Russian vessel is restricted to outside the 400 metre depth line and outside certain additional areas in which there are known resources. The vessel will have two AFMA observers on board at all times and will be required to lodge full catch reports and other information. The arrangement is for a maximum of six months and is on a full cost recovery basis.

The nature of fishery resources in this area is virtually unknown and it is important, given the pressure on other fisheries, to have the area properly explored. The vessel has no access to any other area of the Australian Fishing Zone and certainly not to the south eastern fishery.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given this day by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Schacht this day relating to growth forecasts in the economic statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In his reply to Senator Schacht today, Senator Button said, in the course of a lengthy answer, trying to defend the Government's economic record and to put some justification into last night's disastrous economic statement, that company profits had increased as a share of national income. When I interjected and said that that was not true, he violently disagreed with me.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of page 2.24 from Budget Paper No. 1 of the 1991-92 Budget statements, which has

SPEECH.PARA: a chart entitled `Corporate Trading Enterprises Profit Shares'.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [THE GRAPH IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 351]

TALK.START.PARA: —That graph shows the share of profit in relation to national income going back to 1966-67, which I understand was the first year on which such data was compiled. The graph shows what is called the gross operating surplus of companies, less income tax paid by them and less net interest. In other words, it is the profit of trading enterprises after they have paid tax and their interest bill. That graph shows that in 1990-91—the last year for which these figures were available—the profit share of corporate trading enterprises was the lowest it had ever been since this data was first compiled, which, as I said, goes back a quarter of a century to 1966-67.

PARA.TAB: The table I have had incorporated is a graph. It does not contain the actual percentage figures for profit share. I would like to read into the record those profit share figures for the years of the Hawke Government. In 1983-84, the profit share was 20.7 per cent; in 1984-85 it was 21.25 per cent; in 1985-86, 20.1 per cent; in 1986-87, 19.4 per cent; in 1987-88, 19 per cent; in 1988-89, 18.7 per cent; in 1989-90, 15.4 per cent; and in 1990-91, 13 per cent. In other words, with the exception of the first year of the Hawke-Keating Government—1983-84—there has been a decline in the profit share of trading enterprises in every successive year of this Government.

Today's profit figures for company profits before income tax for the December quarter 1991—these figures were just released today—show that company profits for companies with more than 30 employees are now at the lowest level since the December quarter of 1987; it is 20 per cent less than the December 1990 quarter figure, and it is 27 per cent less than that for the December quarter of 1989.

So far as companies with fewer than 30 employees are concerned—in other words, basically small business—we all know what has happened to those companies and their profits over the last one to two years and longer. They would more than confirm the figures put out today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

I just wanted to have that on the record because it is simply not true for the Government to say, as it is saying, that the company profit share has held up well. It is not a fact. Indeed, the contrary is the case. There has been a progressive fall in every year except the first of the Hawke-Keating Government in the company profit share. No wonder this country faces the deepest recession for 60 years. Yesterday's spending, pump-priming, unfunded binge is just going to add to the misery of the millions of Australians who have already suffered so grievously at the hands of this Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the statistics outlined in this publication it is easy to understand the extent of the problems associated with family law. Since 1976 a total of 642,246 divorces have been granted and last year the figure of 42,635 was regrettably an increase on the previous five years. Over half the divorces involved children, with some 44,000 children having been caught up in family break-ups last year alone, and 750,000 since 1976.

PARA.TAB: Against this background it is regrettable that the court has not had any increase in the number of mediation centres, as was intended, in Melbourne, Dandenong and Parramatta. Apparently it comes down to a matter of resources. Given the evidence to date that has been taken by the Joint Select Committee into Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, we have been given the impression that mediation is successful and needs to be made more available. One hopes the Committee will be able to help in that regard.

Another interesting comment made in the report by the Chief Justice relates to costs. He has introduced a practice direction requiring solicitors during litigation to give their clients a written estimate of costs incurred to date and likely anticipated costs. During the parliamentary inquiry the question of expenses in the legal process has been constantly raised. I also note that the Chief Justice refers to the establishment of the parliamentary inquiry, and remarks:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Court welcomes public scrutiny and sees the enquiry as an important opportunity to extend community awareness of the Court's work and of the problems it faces.

Therefore, the Senate can take a bow for having agreed to set up the inquiry. It was interesting to note that before the inquiry was established Justice Nicholson left me in no doubt that he saw the inquiry as unnecessary and an intrusion into the court's work. Having met him and having noted his remarks in this annual report, I now know that he realises that we are here to try to help improve the position in terms of scrutiny of the Family Law Act. I hope that at the end of our inquiry everyone will agree that we have achieved something.

PARA.TAB: If the court welcomes the extension of community awareness, it is a matter of continuing regret that so much of the proceedings are forbidden to be publicised or reported in any way. That is another area at which we are looking in our inquiry; we will see what happens when the Committee scrutinises that area in a forthright way. I hope that the next annual report of the Family Court will be able to report favourably on our parliamentary Committee's final report on the proposed changes to family law. I also hope that the work of our Committee will make things better for people who get to the stage of litigation in the Family Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The opening comments in the report by the Chairman of the War Memorial Council reveal that the year 1990-91 was a significant one for the Memorial. There was a new organisational structure, a new director and a new corporate plan. Another significant and unfortunate event was the ill-fated decision to introduce fees for entry to the Memorial. The Parliament in February 1991 judged that this was simply not appropriate for our national War Memorial, and the fees were subsequently removed. It was certainly not appropriate that veterans and war widows, those who have sacrificed so much for our country and whose sacrifices are embodied in the concept of a national war memorial, were required to pay to enter the Memorial.

PARA.TAB: It was staggering to learn, therefore, that it was only after the fee had been rejected that the Memorial Council commissioned a paper on funding options. This clearly should have occurred at the outset. It reflects badly on the decision making processes of the Council and Memorial management. Clearly, no decision should have been taken until there had been a thorough consideration of the options. If the only option to ensure the continued development of the Memorial's activities was an entry fee, then the Government should take a good look at the regard in which it holds the Memorial and the resources it gives to it.

The entry fee saga was not the only controversial event at the Memorial in 1990-91. The drafting of the new corporate plan was criticised by me and others for a mission statement which intellectually undermined the raison d'etre of the War Memorial. At one stage it omitted a clear statement of the Memorial's true purpose. I am glad to say that this was finally included after public pressure.

Both of these decisions, I believe, reflect the need for formal representation of ex-service organisations on the War Memorial Council. It could easily be argued that decisions such as that concerning entry fees would have taken a different course had there been ex-service organisation representation on the Council. Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, indicated last year that the coalition in government will ensure that such representation does occur.

It is also of concern that in the current financial year there have been a couple of situations in which the management of the Memorial has not distinguished itself. The first was the sacking, at short notice and contrary to earlier assurances, of several security staff and their recall on the same day, following the intervention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys).

The second situation concerns the restricting of guiding at the Memorial. In the face of absorption of the training and affairs of Memorial guides into the education section of the Memorial, and the insensitive and uncooperative manner in which this was occurring, a number of those voluntary guides—some of them very experienced—have resigned over the past 12 months. There have also been reports of guides being asked to restrict tours to an hour or less, to bypass commemorative areas, and to be selective in how they describe sensitive events such as the Banka Island massacre of the nurses and the shooting of Vivian Bullwinkle by the Japanese.

I wrote to the Minister on these and other matters of concern in December of last year. In the Minister's reply in January he sought to reassure me that such reports were not entirely accurate. However, the letter and the concerns raised in it have certainly had a noticeable impact. Since the Minister's reply and, I understand, a preliminary expression of interest by the Canberra Times in the matters raised in the letter, the approach of Memorial staff has changed noticeably. I trust that this will continue.

In the annual report, the Chairman laments the prolonged public criticism of the War Memorial as destabilising. It must be stressed that the Memorial has an emotional foundation and an emotional legacy and that there will always be great interest in how the affairs of the Memorial are managed. It is widely recognised that the Memorial is one of the finest of its type in the world. Any criticism levelled at the Memorial is only out of a desire to ensure that it continues to uphold its traditions and to maintain its standing as a fine and respected institution. With its already proud history, I am sure it is the wish of all Australians in this year of fiftieth anniversary celebrations year that the sentiments of the Chairman are realised when she says that the Memorial is entering a new and positive phase of its history.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry Commission report on the Australian dairy industry raises great concerns within the dairy industry, particularly in my own home State of Victoria where the majority of dairy producers are in business. The report comes at a time leading up to the need for new dairy industry legislation, as the so-called Kerin plan reaches its sunset date on 30 June of this year. The establishment of the Kerin plan in the early 1980s was a difficult process in an industry which, between the various States of this country, was fraught with difficult and competing interests. It was to the credit of this chamber, particularly the role played by my former colleague Senator Michael Macklin, and to Minister Kerin that that plan came into place and has operated since.

PARA.TAB: New legislation is necessary. The Government must not write that legislation along the lines of the report that the Industry Commission has put down. To date, we are unclear of the Government's position. I want the Senate and the Government to be clear on the position of the dairy industry, particularly in my own home State of Victoria.

The Industry Commission report makes a number of recommendations which can be summarised by saying that it speaks of vastly reducing many of the current interventions that are in the industry. The dairy industry is very concerned about the consequence of those reductions in intervention. The Industry Commission recommends removing price distortions, ensuring that the industry has flexibility to adjust to changing circumstances, that least cost locations are used for milk production relative to market outlets, and a number of other items. The consequence of that, according to the Commission, is an expectation that prices for milk will go down by some 12 per cent. The potential effect on dairy producers is quite catastrophic.

These, we must remember, are amongst the most efficient dairy producers in the world. That should not be forgotten, particularly when they are, in the export context, competing on a very unlevel playing field. The farm gate price of manufacturing milk would decline by between 5 and 9 per cent, or 2c or 3c per litre, and the prices of manufactured dairy products would fall by around 12 per cent as these market support payments were reduced—if the Industry Commission report were pursued. Total milk output would contract by around 5 per cent, putting dairy farmers, many of whom are currently only just scraping a living, right to the wall.

It is important, I think, that we acknowledge the efficiency and effectiveness of the dairy industry in our Australian economy and particularly in our Australian community. For every dollar that a dairy farmer in this country creates, an additional $3.66 is created in his or her community. This creation of wealth is dependent upon continuing support for the dairy industry and will be very much at risk should the report of the Industry Commission be pursued and lay the basis for the Government's new legislation.

I wish to put the Government on notice that at least the Democrats understand that our dairy industry does not play on a level playing field; that no such playing field exists; that we cannot ask dairy farmers to go to the forefront in an international situation which is unfair to them; and that we must not risk that industry, nor must we risk the many rural communities that are dependent on that extremely efficient Australian dairy industry. The loss of skills and the loss of export income that would come as a consequence must be borne in mind as the Government drafts new legislation to replace the Kerin scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to speak to this matter. I would also urge the Government to think very carefully about the recommendations of the Industry Commission in its report on the Australian dairy industry. It is all very well to take a philosophical attitude to this industry without putting it into a proper perspective in terms of its position in the community at large.

PARA.TAB: Most of the dairy farms are relatively small in acreage. They do not have enough room to advance into broadacre farming such as beef farming. Many of them are in areas where the topography, the climate, the soils or various other things may not be suitable for cropping and where this opportunity does not exist. If we were to take the sorts of actions that would follow the adoption of the recommendations of the Industry Commission, we could further hurt very severely a lot of what are regarded as lesser rural communities.

One of the problems facing rural Australia these days is the continuing drift from the country to the cities and the lesser number of farms and the loss of community units. There is no reason at all why the sorts of recommendations that have been put forward should be adopted at this time. The dairy industry has made fantastic advances in efficiency and productivity. The manufacturing industry has done a great deal in terms of getting into the best lines with the higher profit margins, particularly in the cheese area.

The Australian cheeses that have come on to the market in the last 10 or 15 years have been absolutely magnificent. Instead of there being just a bulk market of sending product somewhere overseas for on-processing, the cheese is now produced in Australia. The Australian people are now consuming considerably more cheese than they used to, and the market overseas for particular varieties is improving all the time. As far as my home State is concerned, we have three manufacturers—Lactos, United Milk Products and King Island—all of whom are producing product which is keenly sought in many parts of the world.

While this is going on and while these advances are being made, there would be no justification at all for adopting the sorts of propositions that are put forward. The industry needs a continuation of the present scheme for further consolidation and further profitability. The manufacturing industry was in terrible trouble a few years ago. Nearly every company in Australia was bankrupt or almost bankrupt. In the main, they have now settled down, with many amalgamations. The business is now profitable and should be encouraged to continue in that way.

The economy, generally, requires micro-economic improvements in order to pick up and it is absolutely necessary that transport costs, general costs, marketing costs for exporters, the introduction of a tax regime that would allow exporters to be treated much better than they are at present, and matters of that sort are addressed at this time. I certainly urge the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) who is in the chamber at the moment to recommend that the Government not follow all the recommendations put forward by the Industry Commission in this instance, but proceeds on the basis on which the industry is currently operating.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to address very briefly the Industry Commission report on the Australian dairy industry. The substantive issues which concern the Australian Democrats in the State of Victoria have already been put on record by Senator Powell. However, I wish briefly to commend Senator Archer for the comments he has made and lend support to the position that he has adopted which is essentially an interventionist one to assist the dairy industry. In that sense, it departs considerably from the position advocated on economic issues by the coalition parties which generally tend to think that the free market forces should be allowed to operate.

PARA.TAB: In this case, however, I am very glad to see that there has been a very enlightened response, a response that calls for government action. It rejects the essentially very dry position adopted by the Industry Commission and recognises that the dairy industry in Victoria and throughout Australia is of extreme importance. We as a community need to decide whether we are prepared to perhaps pay a few cents more for our cheese and other dairy products to ensure that the farmers in Gippsland and other areas in Australia survive and continue to be part of a viable dairy industry in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Australian Dairy Corporation seems to fit in very well with some of the remarks made about the Industry Commission report into the Australian dairy industry by Senator Archer in particular.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the Corporation on its annual report and the work that it does in trying to enhance the profitable production and marketing of Australian dairy products. On 27 November, when this report was before the Senate, I made a few remarks but was unable to complete all that I wanted to say. Our dairy foods are as good as, and in many cases better than, any in the world. Our dairy food exports earn more than $700m each year. More than 100,000 Australians have jobs thanks to the dairy industry. The industry provides about 20 per cent employment in a number of important dairying regions. This is especially important in light of the particularly difficult times rural Australia is experiencing.

Studies show that for every 100 jobs in dairy factories an additional 110 jobs are created in associated regional activities. The flow-on effects beyond the region are about as large again. Currently, Australia's dairy industry manufactures many specialised products for markets here and overseas. Its farmers currently produce milk valued at some $1.7 billion each year, all of which is processed within Australia. On top of this, processed dairy foods are valued at about $4.5 billion a year, an added value of $3 billion annually.

The industry's major investments in research, technology and market development will see these export earnings grow. Dairy farm productivity is increasing by 5 per cent per year, as it has for the past decade. The industry's willingness to adapt to change means that it will benefit from even minor reforms in the international trading environment.

Already, Australians buy premier quality dairy foods at prices as low as anywhere in the world. Our farmers produce milk at lower cost than those in Europe, the USA, Canada or Japan thanks to our pasture based farming. In fact, few countries can produce quality dairy products as cheaply as Australia. Australian consumers are now paying the lowest prices in the world for dairy products—although I sometimes wonder when I go shopping at the weekend whether the women shopping in the supermarkets think they are paying the lowest prices.

Dairying is a very real industry—close to the people it employs, part of everyone's day-to-day life, and earning export dollars for all Australians. In the south Burnett where I live we have a number of dairy farms. Unfortunately, the number has been reduced over past years. If the Government introduces many of the recommendations of the recent major study by the Industry Commission into the dairy industry, which we were looking at earlier, many more dairy farms will indeed face extinction. These recommendations could cut the average farm income by up to $21,000 per year. It is no wonder that Senator Archer said that he hoped the Government would not act on all of the recommendations of the Industry Commission report.

Already, a significant scaling down of the Queensland dairy industry has been undertaken to remove any areas which cannot compete with interstate and trans-Tasman competition. The number of farmers in Queensland has wound down from 20,000 to 2,000 in recent years. These farmers have quotas and are obligated to supply fresh, quality dairy products 365 days of the year. I compliment people who are in the dairy industry. It is a constant job. If they want to have a day off they have to find somebody who is willing to come in and do their work for them, otherwise they can never have a holiday. I pay tribute to those people who help to keep the dairy industry going.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the wives.

—I also pay tribute, as Senator Newman has pointed out, to the wives of the dairy farmers. It is a constant job for them, too, in so many places. As many areas between Bundaberg and the border are now being swallowed up by real estate development, to meet future demand this area would have to increase its supply. These are some of the things that I was interested in. I have been very pleased indeed to be able to speak to this annual report.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Ombudsman's annual report for 1990-91, I intend to confine my remarks to the section on the Australian Taxation Office. I remind the Senate that the written and oral complaints received by the Ombudsman show the importance and necessity for his office. The Ombudsman's office received 362 written complaints and 839 oral complaints with a 76 per cent and 75 per cent resolution respectively in favour of the complainants, the taxpayers. Without this office, at least 600 taxpayers in this country would have felt that their rights had been denied by the Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: The Ombudsman and his office are an important check on the activities of the ATO, especially for those taxpayers who are involved in contentious issues and who have arrived at a stalemate in their negotiations with the office. Further, the cases handled by the Ombudsman show clearly those areas where procedures and regulations practised by the Taxation Office need revision and change.

It was pleasing to note that the effect of self-assessment, electronic lodgment and the establishment of problem resolution offices has resulted in a decrease in the number of oral complaints involving unreasonable delay in the issue of assessments and refund cheques. I congratulate the Taxation Office on its achievement, particularly those officers who staff the problem resolution section.

However, hand in hand with congratulations come areas within the Taxation Office that need revision. I was interested to note from the report that the main ongoing issues in the tax field continue to be, first, delays in the processing of interest payments under the Taxation (Interest and Overpayments) Act and in giving effect to tribunal and court decisions pursuant to section 200B of the Income Tax Assessment Act. A second issue is the offsetting of credits for debits not yet due. I believe that for the Ombudsman to single out these two areas signifies a potential weakness in the workings of the Taxation Office. I have had constituents come to me concerning both areas.

It appears that several branches of the Tax Office consistently fell below what could be viewed as a reasonable level of performance; that is, to finalise more than 90 per cent of the cases within 30 days of issuing amended assessments and refunds of tax overpaid. The Ombudsman makes quite a point of stating that in 30 per cent of all interest on overpayment cases received in 1989-90, the Tax Office had failed to meet its own standard of finalising payments of interest on overpaid tax within 30 days. This is despite the issue being brought to the attention of the Tax Office the previous year.

The Ombudsman is also very harsh in his criticism of the Tax Office in failing to comply with section 200B of the Act. If a taxpayer's objection or appeal is successful in the AAT or the Federal Court and results in a refund of tax overpaid, the effect of section 200B is to require the Tax Office to refund the overpaid tax within 60 days of the decision becoming final.

The Ombudsman is convinced that the Tax Office is not fulfilling its responsibilities under this section. The Ombudsman has recommended that the Tax Office's computer systems be upgraded to enable it to issue interest cheques simultaneously with amended assessments. The Ombudsman's report states that on 28 June of last year the ATO reported that its office was investigating the problem and would remedy it after the full extent is known. I hope that since this was in June the Tax Office has attended to this problem. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, whether this has been done.

The report also highlights the difficulties being experienced by taxpayers resulting from the Tax Office's practice of applying tax refunds to tax debits which are not yet due and payable. This problem is particularly prevalent amongst provisional taxpayers. I have already called for a significant reduction in the uplift factor that is applied to provisional taxpayers as a result of the present economic climate. For a provisional taxpayer to be denied his refund is adding insult to injury for this class of taxpayer.

I note that the Ombudsman states that the Tax Office has implemented a policy of paying the credit to affected taxpayers on request using manual transactions, as its present computer systems are not sophisticated enough to handle this type of transaction automatically. The Ombudsman's office continues to receive complaints relating to the practice of offsetting all or part of a refund against a debit assessment. Therefore, this is an area that the Tax Office needs to correct.

The report also highlights the need for the Tax Office to record all of its settlements in writing and explain the penalty situation to the ordinary taxpayer. This only reinforces my persistent call in this chamber for all taxpayers to have certainty in their dealings with the Taxation Office. Finally, I am pleased to note that the Ombudsman—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak to the Ombudsman's annual report for 1990-91. In the overview of this report attention is drawn to the issue of the Ombudsman's jurisdiction to investigate program related actions of the ABC. It seems that in this respect, as in a number of other areas, the SBS is well ahead of the ABC because, while the SBS accepts the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the ABC for some reason does not.

PARA.TAB: Mr Cameron, who became the fourth Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman in April of this year, believes, like his predecessor, Professor Pearce, that he does have the right to investigate the way the ABC dealt with a complaint it received. As Mr Cameron notes, there exists a clear need for this dispute to be resolved by the Parliament in the form of a legislative amendment. The alternative is costly litigation between two government agencies at taxpayers' expense, which is to be deplored.Honourable senators would be aware that on 14 August last year Senator Herron introduced a private senator's Bill seeking to address this. The Bill makes it clear that the Ombudsman's jurisdiction should extend to the ABC, and it is a Bill which ought to receive the support of the Senate.

It is interesting to note the comments of the Ombudsman with respect to his power to report to the Parliament. As the situation stands, the Ombudsman may report to the Parliament in three ways. After submitting a special report to the Prime Minister, it is then within the powers of the Ombudsman to forward the report to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives for presentation to the Houses of Parliament. On the two occasions that this power has been exercised in the past 15 years, no substantive response was forthcoming from the Parliament. The Ombudsman might also submit from time to time a report to the Prime Minister for presentation to the Parliament. Finally, of course, there is the annual report. In none of these cases is there a direct link between the Ombudsman and the Parliament.

In the report the Ombudsman relates the circumstances of his equivalent in New Zealand. There, the Ombudsman is an officer of the Parliament and is funded separately from the agencies of the Executive Government. In my opinion, this arrangement has a great deal to recommend it. After reading the report, one cannot help but see that in pursuing its charter the Ombudsman's office suffers from severe financial constraints. This can be directly linked to its dependence on the Executive for its budget allocation and the great uncertainty that must necessarily exist from year to year in its funding. That situation could shortly start to seriously affect the capacity of the Ombudsman to meet his obligations.

These are very serious concerns not to be taken lightly, because the implications of an emasculated administrative watchdog will be an increasingly self-serving rather than public-serving Commonwealth administration. In terms of funding and in terms of a charter to answer directly to the people, the idea of the Ombudsman as an officer of the Parliament has, I believe, great merit.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration was reviewing the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman and has now reported. I believe that important recommendations flowing from this review are only worth while in so far as the Government responds to them quickly and effectively. With a staff of only 72 and a budget of $4.4m in 1991, the Ombudsman and his staff have performed well in their efforts to meet the increasingly heavy demands placed upon them.

As a senator in this place, I must say that the work of the Ombudsman is of great value to me in representing my constituents, particularly because he alone is able to go into a department and read a file which is not given to any of us to do which often, of course, results in a change of attitude on behalf of the department concerned. Certainly, in looking after defence constituents, I find that the defence Ombudsman is a very valued adjunct and participant in the democratic process. It would be very bad indeed if we were to allow the Executive to starve such a worthwhile organisation of its resources. To place it under the responsibility of the Parliament itself, to me, seems much the best way to go.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Office of Film and Literature Classification and Film and Literature Board of Review

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 December, on motion by Senator Calvert:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having been cut off in my prime on 2 December, I hope today, thanks to a letter from the now Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin), to finish off my concerns. These could appropriately also be dealt with under document No. 52, the Australian Film Finance Corporation. I raised concerns about the fact that the Film Finance Corporation, using $270,000 of taxpayers' money, was financing a pornographic movie called Sacred Sex, which has since been shown around the country, and an abbreviated or cut version of which has been shown on the ABC .

PARA.TAB: When last speaking I said I would be writing to the then Minister for the Arts, Mrs Kelly, and Mr Beazley. I have not had a reply from Mr Beazley, but I have received one from Ms Wendy Fatin who is now the Minister for the Arts and Territories. It is interesting to note that although I raised concerns about this issue, together with the concerns of Southern Cross Homes in New South Wales—which sent me a petition from some 170 people saying that they were disgusted with the fact that the Government was in the game of handing out money to organisations funding these types of operations—Ms Fatin did say in her reply that, amongst other things, to stop these types of corporations wasting money on this type of production, they must qualify under a test under division 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Ms Fatin said that this test ensures, amongst other things, that those programs are of broadcast quality or suitable for public exhibition in the cinema; that a film which received a rating more restrictive than R would not be considered a qualifying film; and went on to explain why this particular film only received an R rating. Hence, I am speaking on this film today because the film did receive an R rating but was banned in New Zealand. I think that is a reasonable example of beauty, or whatever one likes to call it, being in the eye of the beholder. Even though we gave that film an R rating here, it was banned in New Zealand, so obviously someone there thought it was a pretty poor production.

The Minister also said that it would not be appropriate for the Government to intervene in the individual funding decisions of the Film Finance Corporation. I would just say that if the Government is not going to keep its eye on these types of funding decisions by, in this particular case, the Film Finance Corporation, well who is? Who is going to be the watchdog?

This week we heard again of another of these funded groups, aptly named SICH, the students initiative in community health. I raised that group last year through my Waste Watch Committee and pointed out that it was advocating male prostitution as a way for students to work their way through college. The Minister then gave me an assurance that its funding would be reviewed. This obviously was not done because I notice that this group has raised its head again in its Catalyst magazine. This year, after receiving $200,000 worth of funding, it advocated killing the Pope, going out graffiti writing and engaging in other anti-social behaviour. I understand now that the Minister has cut its funding and I applaud him for that. In fact, I wrote a letter to the Mercury in Hobart congratulating him on that effort.

We have also had other way-out things being funded around the country by different governments. We had this fantasy line in New South Wales that the Premier, Mr Greiner, took so much offence to. I am glad to see that, in its wisdom, the Government withdrew funding for that. The point I am making is that, while we are in Opposition, my colleagues and I will continue to raise matters of concern about the funding of some of these way-out projects and, in this particular case, the funding of a pornographic movie using $270,000 of taxpayers' money through the Office of the Film and Literature Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —At some later stage I wish to speak on the annual report of the Office of Film and Literature Classification and Film and Literature Board of Review for 1990-91. I do not wish to do so this afternoon but at some later stage when some further material—I have most of it to hand—will be available. I will then be able to indicate to the Senate that there has been a considerable drift in the accuracy with which the Film Censorship Board is listening to the wishes of the elected representatives of the people. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Horticultural Research and Development Corporation is a relatively new body that is not yet widely enough known or appreciated throughout Australia. The industry takes in every State, climate and soil condition in Australia and the Corporation coordinates the work of the CSIRO, all the universities, the departments of agriculture in the States, and the various industry boards. I note that in the year under review the Corporation had interviews with more than 30 of those bodies. The job of the Corporation is to coordinate the work that is being done and, with funding assistance, to ensure that the most appropriate work is done.

PARA.TAB: The Corporation covers everything from apples, pears, potatoes, citrus, cut flowers, dried fruits, to macadamia nuts—all sorts of things—and is extending all the time. In 1990-91 the Corporation handled over 200 of these research projects and expended approximately $6 1/2m in doing so. The report lists the projects lined up for 1991-92. There are approximately 350, almost double the number of the previous year, and $8m will be expended. The work the Corporation does is most important. It is especially designed to improve the industry and to improve the products that are grown.

The work of the Corporation covers everything from disease control through to genetic engineering. Genetic engineering is itself a most misunderstood phrase. In this instance it is used to cover breeding out various weaknesses in plants; improving genes to avoid the use of chemicals as fertilisers or insect controllers of aphids, blight and so on; studying the use of water, pollination, tissue culture—all the things that are necessary to improve Australia's horticultural industries. There are vast numbers of people in our area of the world who provide markets for our foodstuffs, flowers, dried fruits and so on.

The executive director of the Corporation is Dr Chris Rigney, and I support the work he is doing. I praise the Corporation for the work it has already done. I hope that more people get an understanding of what this Corporation is doing and that, as a result, the industries can participate more and be of even greater benefit to Australian primary industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It was only yesterday that I spoke on a report of the Australian Institute of Marine Science, which is very much connected with the Great Barrier Reef. The annual report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority deals with the reef itself. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is off the coast of Queensland and Queensland is very proud of it. As I said yesterday, I consider the Great Barrier Reef to be the eighth wonder of the world. It is really a marvellous, God-made place. So many people love to go there and see it.

PARA.TAB: The park is the only large marine ecosystem in the world which is comprehensively managed with the explicit goal of ensuring that its use is ecologically sustainable in perpetuity. In discussing the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority annual report, I want to focus on three brief issues. In the chairman's report he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As managers, we are acutely aware that our scientific knowledge is insufficient for us to be certain that our goal is being achieved.

Indeed, there are three major questions about the park which still remain unanswered. One of them—the cause of the crown-of-thorns starfish infestations—has been extensively studied over the past few years. An enormous amount has been learned in these studies, not only about the starfish but also about the processes and other living organisms which constitute the Great Barrier Reef.

PARA.TAB: Only recently I read that sophisticated computers are currently providing help in protecting the reef from starfish. The article said that a team of Townsville-based marine scientists, using supercomputers to model the larval dispersal of the starfish, have revealed its spread and predicted future points of infestation. The results have confirmed the basic southward drift of the starfish and the high incidence of outbreaks on reefs around the middle of the Continental Shelf. They also showed that reefs such as Green Island and John Brewer Reef are more susceptible to infestations because of their connection with upstream reefs, and that the area around Cooktown acted as a partially self-contained source of larvae and a possible site for the start of future infestations.

The article went on to say that the modelling program they are trying to establish up there involves feeding data on prevailing tides, winds and the east Australian current, together with the physical make-up of individual reefs, into supercomputers with very fast processors, large disc capacity and a high system input. Another instrument which is proving very helpful in monitoring the activities of the reef is the video camera and photographs. These are used to record in detail the effects of the reef's predators as well as the long term effects of tourists. Of course, many tourists visit the reef and that is one thing they have to be careful about.

The first tests in this program have begun at Michaelmas Reef, a popular tourist spot near Cairns. As I was looking at the report, I found a very interesting photograph of Michaelmas Cay, a very beautiful island on the reef which I have had the privilege of visiting a couple of times. There are a tremendous number of birds on the island. As I looked at the photograph, it brought back memories of my visits to Michaelmas Cay.

This research on Michaelmas Reef will help to provide warnings of any adverse changes from overuse by tourists as well as the harmful effects of oil spills, cyclones and commercial and amateur fishing. In a recent article in the Courier-Mail, a project officer with the authorities said:

SPEECH.PARA: In ten years of monitoring we will be able for the first time to see any gross changes to the reef.

I would like to say one thing about the worry over the crown-of-thorns starfish. Captain Cook had to off-load a lot of luggage when his ship hit a reef while sailing up the Queensland coast many years ago in 1770. In order to lighten his ship he also had to have five cannons thrown overboard. Not so very long ago a team of people found the cannons. Believe it or not, quite a deal of the reef had grown over them; they had to be dug out of the reef. So it is quite obvious that the reef continues to growth, despite crown-of-thorns starfish attacks.

PARA.TAB: As I say, we are very glad that we have the Barrier Reef off our Queensland coast. Many tourists who come to Queensland just love to visit the reef.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: I preface my remarks by paying tribute to the immediate past Director of the Office of Australian War Graves, Alf Clarke, who died on 15 December last. I knew him for only a fairly short time, but his heart was very much with the war graves office. He died very shortly after his retirement. I offer my condolences to his family and express my appreciation of the love and care which he gave to the Australian war graves.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to mention briefly my pleasure at having been included in the official party as a representative of the Opposition at the fiftieth anniversary commemoration of the Fall of Singapore Week which was held a few days ago, and at the Battle of Australia in Darwin commemorations a week ago. We met with sons and daughters who perhaps had never known their fathers who were prisoners of war of the Japanese in Singapore and Thailand. We met with widows who, for many years after the war had ended, had cared for veterans disabled as a result of their war service.

We attended a terribly moving ceremony in the mist very early in the morning at Kranji war cemetery in Singapore where an international ceremony was held to remember the dead. Again, on the following morning, the Sunday, the 8th Division had its private family service. Many of the families had come to Kranji for the first time and they remembered the members of their families who had made the supreme sacrifice. As an Australian, I was very proud to see a detachment from the 1st Battalion of the Royal Australian Regiment, which is currently serving in Butterworth, Malaysia. Members of the battalion came down to Singapore to provide a guard of honour for the ceremony.

All Australians would be very pleased to see how well Kranji cemetery is kept by the Commonwealth War Graves, to which Australia makes a contribution. So many of our dead lie buried there. It is a beautiful cemetery and I urge Australians visiting Singapore to make sure that they visit it.

The annual report of the Office of Australian War Graves briefly mentions that in the past year the Office also arranged, on behalf of the Department of Defence, 54 memorials for Australian service men and women who died in service in the past year. There were eight from the Navy, 35 from the Army and 11 from the RAAF. We do not often realise that being a member of the Australian Defence Force is a very dangerous occupation. Even in peacetime, training has to be realistic and people do die. I take this opportunity to make sure that people are reminded of the contribution that is made even in peacetime in training to defend this country from war.

One very disturbing thing I noted while reading this report is the fact that in most States there has been an increase in vandalism of Australian war graves. South Australia, Hobart and Launceston are picked out for particular mention. The war graves office is now trying to combat the problem in the major war cemeteries and gardens of remembrance by investigating security systems suitable for use when staff are not on duty. It is a terrible commentary that we should have so allowed a lack of respect for our dead to grow in our society that people are prepared to commit acts of vandalism against war graves. I alert the Senate to something which I have noticed in reports. I am appalled to think that this is a growing problem.

One innovation I draw to the attention of the Senate is a backpackers guide that is being produced by the Office of War Graves. This will assist visitors backpacking in France and Belgium to find their way around the Australian battle sites in those countries. This guide commemorates the seventy-fifth anniversary of the arrival of the AIF in France and Belgium in 1916. The leaflet will be distributed through our embassies and airline offices and should be of assistance to all who visit the battlefields of World War I. That is an imaginative way of hopefully trying to educate people to respect what the young men of this country have done for this country over the years.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Operations of the Registered Health Insurance Organisations--Annual Report 1990-91

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Private Health Insurance Administration Council--Financial Statements 1990-91

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's so-called free health care system has led to a grossly inefficient and unstable health care delivery system that can no longer be sustained. One of the things that surprised me greatly in last night's statement was that health has yet again been neglected by this Government. I am sure that will be of great concern to Australian citizens, especially the elderly, many of whom are languishing on so-called `elective' waiting lists for medical treatment.

PARA.TAB: Broad public acceptance of some of the features of Medicare, such as its universality and the availability of free medical and hospital services, has until recently hidden very serious deficiencies in the system. But no longer are those deficiencies hidden. They include a massive rise in hospital waiting lists and rising costs of private health insurance which have been largely due to the massive decline in the population holding private health insurance. The appeal of the so-called free health system has led to the widespread drop-out of people from the private health care system.

The overburdening of the inadequate public health care system has led to massive waiting lists and an under-utilised private system. While more than 60,000 people languish on those waiting lists for public beds for elective surgery around Australia, private hospitals have average bed occupancy rates of only 55 to 60 per cent.

Private health insurance costs have increased markedly as the private funds have had to cope with the declining membership and, in many cases, a more costly membership as the young and healthy give up their membership of the funds. The newly unemployed—the thousands and thousands of them—who now cannot afford to take out private health insurance are also added to that list.

The annual report of the operations of the registered health insurance organisations highlights the decline in the numbers of people with private health insurance. At 30 June 1991, 43.5 per cent of the population was covered by private insurance at the basic table level. Only 12 months ago, 44 per cent of the population had this level of coverage.

The report shows the steady decline in membership of private health funds since this Government came to office. The table indicates the decline in membership from 50 per cent in 1984. In fact, the proportion of the population with private health insurance has fallen from 67 per cent in 1982, when this Government came to office—and this report only goes until June 1991. I was in Mildura only a couple of days ago and people there were talking about the number of people who had fled the private health insurance system since then. So I am sure that if the figures were up to date they would be even more devastating. All the people who formerly had private health coverage now require treatment in the public system which, as I have said, is greatly overburdened.

What is the Government's solution to the crisis in the private health care system? It comes up with a proposal to nationalise our private health insurance market and to create one single private health fund—a typical and predictable response from this Government. However, the coalition has responded to the problems in the health care system by developing a comprehensive blueprint as part of its Fightback package that will restore the incentive to take out private health insurance and provide the correct balance in the system between public and private resources. Under our policy there will be financial incentives to take out private health insurance. There will also be an expansion of private insurance options.

The annual report tabled today also highlights the massive defunding of the reinsurance fund—a turning away by this Government and a neglect of the health of this nation. As I said last night, it gives cold comfort to those working in the health field and those needing the services of the health providers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
