PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 December, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the latest Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) figures which confirm that farm incomes have been slashed by a massive 75 per cent in 1991,
(ii)that this is a disaster of massive proportions,

(iii)that it is suggested that recovery is unlikely before the second half of 1992, which will simply be too late for hundreds, and maybe thousands, of farmers who are bankrupt, financially and emotionally, and

(iv)that the Liberal and National parties have been desperately trying to tell the Federal Government for the last two years that farmers were under unprecedented financial pressures that were not merely a result of bad management or low commodity prices; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns this selfish, self-serving, navel-gazing Labor Government which is so arrogantly pre-occupied with who should become General Custer that it has failed to see that a significant sector of our economy has been ruined by their disastrous high-interest-rate policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start this debate, which is on a notice of motion which was moved last year, by quoting from an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review headed, `The cost-price squeeze hits the farmers' under `Economics Extra' by Michael Stutchbury. He says at the beginning of the article:

SPEECH.PARA: The pain in the bush reflects the long-run cost-price squeeze on Australian farms.

Last December, when I drew the attention of the Senate to some quite startling figures on the state of the rural economy, I mentioned that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics had announced that farm incomes had fallen by a tragic, massive 75 per cent in 1991. For Australia it is a crisis of quite significant proportion. The net value of farm production in 1991 was $21 billion, the lowest net value since 1982. Farm cash operating surplus fell from 1989-90 to 1990-91 by 40 per cent and is expected to fall a further 18 per cent between 1990-91 and 1991-92. Farm business profit fell by a massive 357 per cent between the financial year 1989-90 and 1990-91 and is expected to fall a further 67 per cent between the 1990-91 financial year and the 1991-92 financial year.

PARA.TAB: These figures are averages across all farm enterprises. For some, the situation was and remains far worse. For sheep and beef producers there has been a 178 per cent drop in profits, and even for specialist beef producers, who according to ABARE have had a pretty good year, farm business profits slumped by 100 per cent.

I have been warning the Senate for quite some time now about how, even though interest rates might have fallen lately, all the input costs have built into them the high interest rates of the regime that was imposed on Australian farmers by the Labor Government.

Since those figures were released, the Government has staged its 1992 Agricultural Outlook Conference. The news at that conference was that prices for Australia's major export commodities would remain weak and that the net value of farm production would sink further to another record low. It suggested that, despite considerable economising on costs, farmers would still suffer a further drop of 16 per cent in net farm cash income.

The considerable economising farmers have undertaken includes sacking staff. In fact, farming employment has dropped from 152,000 to 140,000, while the figure for unpaid family helpers has jumped by 50 per cent. That means that children are being removed from school, often before their schooling is completed. It means that farm wives are becoming the stock hands on the property.

In many cases it has meant the husband going off farm to look for work or take stock on the road while his wife takes on the full time running of the farm on top of her other duties, also full time, with the children. I do not need to remind the Senate that Australia until recent weeks has been affected by drought over several States. The Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs has been looking at the treatment of drought and the Federal Government's approach to drought funding. We have travelled to all States except Victoria and interviewed or taken evidence from 170 witnesses. The witnesses have been a broad spectrum of those involved in the process—from agricultural departmental officers through to consultants and to counsellors.

Most importantly, the Committee has travelled to drought affected areas and spoken directly with farmers affected. We have seen the devastation, the despair and the desolation. I cannot describe to anyone who has not travelled to Cobar in New South Wales, to Roma in Queensland or to Esperance in Western Australia just how serious the drought has been for the people in those areas. But what is most depressing is the overwhelming sense of hopelessness that we as outsiders felt, yet those families, whose livelihoods and all they had worked for were about to be lost, still had the most tremendous courage and, surprisingly, very little bitterness about a situation that in so many cases was simply not of their making.

Time and again the story was repeated. We heard of the family that had 80 per cent or more equity in their properties but were encouraged to buy the farm next door for their sons or to economise their operations. They bought in good faith and with reasonable expectations of being able to meet repayments. Many borrowed at 12 per cent only to see commodity prices fall, unanticipated abandonment of the reserve price scheme for wool, and interest rates jumping to 18 per cent, 20 per cent or even higher. I have it told to me many times that many farmers are in trouble only because they took too many risks and were too greedy. That has not been the case. Farmers have not been greedy, but have been very long suffering in the past eight years of Labor Government.

What woolgrower could have predicted that the Labor Government would abandon the reserve price scheme, particularly when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy at the time, Mr Kerin—apparently the farmers' friend—said that if there was any movement in the reserve price it would be up, not down, and certainly not out. He was quoted at the time as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The rural sector is vital to our national economy and the rural community is vital to our national identity. This has always been the case in Australia, and it's not about to change.

They come as cold words of comfort now that he and the rural sector have been decimated. But given such assurances as those from the Minister, what farmer could have anticipated that interest rates would double in a matter of a few short years? Who could have anticipated such a massive and widespread collapse in commodity prices? Who could have predicted that on top of all these other factors farmers would first be hit with a flood, as Nyngan was, then a drought and then another flood all within a period of four years?

PARA.TAB: It is important to remember that farmers have been caught in a desperate cost-price squeeze for the past 20 years. Since 1973-74 prices paid to farmers for their output have doubled, but prices paid by farmers for their inputs have jumped 4 1/2 times. I ask honourable senators to think about that. How would people react if their household budgets had suddenly jumped in that way? How can anyone prepare adequately for a string of disasters against that background? The simple answer is that they cannot do so. It is history that the number of farms is reducing as is the number of farmers. In the year 1989-90 to 1990-91 the total number of farmers dropped from 243,000 to 228,000. That reduction will accelerate, I anticipate, this financial year.

Certainly based on figures given to the drought inquiry in Queensland and Western Australia, there has been a significant increase in the number of farmers moving from the sound to the doubtfully viable category. Previously, 20 per cent of farmers in Queensland were borderline; that figure is now 30 to 40 per cent. In Western Australia at least 6 per cent of farms are not viable long term, with a further 33 per cent suffering short term difficulties. Half the 30 to 40 per cent of farmers in Queensland I mentioned basically have no future at all, and this was said to us by the Queensland Government.

The crisis in rural Australia has been developing for a number of years, and most certainly during the entire period of the Labor Government. But I draw the Senate's attention to just how much Labor has done for this most vital sector, a sector which still, despite its adversities, produces 27 per cent of export income. In outlining the specific attacks that the rural sector has suffered from successive Keating budgets, let us not forget the greatest legacy the former Treasurer, now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), left this country, and that was a record period of record high interest rates. That alone was of sufficient magnitude, but Mr Keating's abuse of rural Australia went even further.

Let me quote to the Senate what I heard the Prime Minister say today at the National Press Club: `Draconian high interest rates slow the country down'. He was making a claim that some of the policies that we will put into place in government after the next election may cause high interest rates, which they will not. The Prime Minister—Mr Keating, the former Treasurer—did cause high interest rates to prevail for far too long, which caused so much harm, so much hardship, and knocked all the confidence out of the business sector. So what has happened to the farming community is on his head.

In May 1983 the Labor Government cut general depreciation allowances and abolished special depreciation allowances for on-farm fuel storage. That same year it scrapped the in-out opting arrangements of tax averaging and increased the margin paid by farmers under the fuel freight subsidy scheme, and it automatically indexed excise taxes to CPI and imposed a new tax on fortified wines. The year 1983 was a big one for Labor's rural bashing campaign—Senator West should be hiding her head under her desk—because in the Budget of 1983 the Labor Government abolished sales tax exemption on oils and lubricants for farmers. Labor imposed a 200 per cent increase in export inspection charges and abolished tax incentives on income equalisation deposits.

The year 1984 was a little quieter. The wine industry was the only one targeted with the introduction of a 10 per cent sales tax on wines and alcoholic cider. In 1985 the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme was emasculated and the subsidy on LP gas abolished; capital gains tax was introduced and on-farm water conservation was changed from immediate write-off to a five-year schedule.

In 1986 the fringe benefits tax was introduced by the Hawke-Keating Labor Government, along with a further 3c a litre increase in fuel excise, a 20 per cent tax on wines and an increase in agricultural quarantine fees. That was not a bad year for a little bit more bashing of the rural community by the Hawke-Keating Labor Government.

In 1987 we saw a cut in wool research funding by $5m and the fuel freight consumer component was lifted. In 1988 the Hawke-Keating Labor Government did another job on those of us in country areas. Export inspection charges were increased again and fertiliser subsidies were abolished, along with immediate write-off for electricity connection, changes to depreciation allowances which cost rural industry $90m, wool promotion funds were cut by $20m, the export trade incentives programs were cut by $78m and primary industry levies were increased. If some of these things had not happened it would have helped the rural community, but these all put more costs on the rural community. Indeed, primary industry levies were increased by $105m largely through lifts in the wool tax and livestock slaughter levies.

Since that time we have had further increases in export inspection charges to 100 per cent cost recovery and cuts to CSIRO rural research. Furthermore, this Labor Government has made cuts to soil conservation, cuts to isolated children assistance, and drought aid has been removed from the national disaster relief arrangements. Furthermore, family allowances have been assets tested, which has effectively eliminated most farm families, no matter how cash poor they are. All those things were done in the space of eight years to the rural communities. One wonders now why the rural communities are in the state they are.

I have already referred to the great calamity perpetrated on the wool industry last year by the Federal Labor Government. The wheat industry suffered no fairer fate. Today both those industries are experiencing historic difficulties. I suppose that, given the long list of destruction I have just detailed, we all ought to be grateful that wool and wheat growers actually received a mention in the statement from General Custer last night. The Prime Minister told Parliament that we should help farmers during the recovery phase. I have read the much-ado-about-nothing-much package launched last night. I will not go into the arithmetic of it because I do not believe that there was any.

It is worth noting that, despite all the indications that help was forthcoming for the rural sector—a sector suffering the most extreme crisis in the history of this country—farmers rated only a total of 14 lines, and five of those lines had only a couple of words in them, out of a total of 16 pages. We had the Prime Minister suggesting only hours earlier that help was on the way—and 14 lines was all the attention Australian farmers get.

I cannot be ungrateful. In those 14 lines there was a one-off addition to the rural adjustment scheme. Farmers can now borrow even more money to plant crops this year. The Wool Realisation Commission will be allowed to make cash payments to woolgrowers in the event that sales from the stockpile occur faster than anticipated. Some much needed extra funds are to be provided for rural counselling services, and I welcome that. Depreciation allowances will assist those farmers who have sufficient equity to make new machinery purchases. But remember all the things that have been taken away before they get a little given back. I do not think that is what the rural communities have needed in the last eight years—take a little away and then give a little back. There was so little when so much needed to be done.

Here we have an industry in crisis, and we get crumbs and tinkerings. There was no question of underwriting this year's wheat crop so that farmers would have confidence to risk capital in planting. Last year saw a record drop in the size of the crop. We cannot afford to have another small national harvest because we will jeopardise our traditional markets if we cannot supply them. Despite evidence provided by almost every single witness to the drought inquiry to the effect that the income equalisation deposits scheme had to be made more effective, despite the fact that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has been made aware of this, again nothing was done about the income equalisation deposit scheme. Once again, farmers are being left to get out of their crisis the best way they can, with short term solutions and not long term strategies.

The coalition has done the homework for the Government on assistance for the rural sector. We spelt it out for the Government in our tax reform package. Obviously, the Government has read bits of it because it cribbed some of it last night, but it ignored the strategies for rural Australia. Last week the Agricultural Council failed to adopt a national drought policy, but we were told that it would do something about it in July. Last night the Prime Minister failed rural Australia yet again.

I cannot imagine a more dramatic set of figures than those the rural sector presents at the present time. What more needs to be done to make the Keating Labor Government realise that the rural sector is on its knees and that something has to be done? What does it take to get these soft-bellied Ministers on the other side of the chamber out into the real world? The country is dying and the Prime Minister is playing drop-the-hanky in the other place.

My notice of motion in December last year was presented to the Senate when Mr Hawke was still Prime Minister. Since then we have had a change of Prime Minister. But despite all the media hype, the re-imaging of the honourable member for Blaxland, rather like a new advertising campaign for an old product, nothing has changed. It is the same stale, pie in the sky, trust me, I am wrong, thinking that we have learned to ignore over successive failed Budgets, economic statements, mini-Budgets and assorted packages. The disaster of massive proportions which I alluded to last year is even more apparent today, and the Federal Government stands condemned for its selfish navel-gazing arrogance. It has remained oblivious to the disaster it has created for a major sector of Australia's economy.

I finish with a quote: `Burn down your cities and leave our farms and your cities will spring up again as if by magic; but destroy our farms and the grass will grow in the streets of every city in the country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the contribution of Senator Brownhill on this notice of motion. Once again, we have not had outlined clearly just what the Opposition would do if it were in government and what the impact of its proposals might be. I will endeavour to look at some of those proposals later and also to touch on some aspects of that reference to General Custer, which I found most interesting.

PARA.TAB: The Government does not deny that farm incomes have dropped. Farm incomes have dropped for a number of reasons, which really have not been outlined very well today by my colleague opposite, Senator Brownhill. Of course, it comes as no surprise that the Government does not accept this notice of motion. The Opposition clearly has chosen to overlook a worldwide recession; to ignore what is happening in the rest of the developed world, and I presume to an even worse extent in the developing countries of the world. We see massive unemployment in the UK, the USA and the EC countries. That must have an impact on farming, on food commodities that people must buy and on their general purchasing power.

We see turmoil in certain parts of the world, particularly in what used to be the USSR, now the CIS, or the Commonwealth of Independent States. Those states cannot agree on what they will do about their defence policy. They cannot agree on what they will do with their defence forces—who should have which parts of them. Before I am pulled up because my remarks may seem irrelevant to the motion, I hasten to add that the USSR was a very large importer of Australia's wool and I am outlining to honourable senators the impact of this turmoil in the USSR on our markets for this commodity.

Our third largest purchaser of wool is in a great state of turmoil and has a problem paying its way in the world. In the last several weeks we have witnessed food aid being flown in to provide the people of Moscow and other cities with enough food to stop food riots. We have heard people speaking against Yeltsin and the current leadership of Russia. We must hope, holding our breaths, that the regressive, reactionary conservative forces that ruled the Soviet Union prior to the rise of Gorbachev are not able to overthrow those people who are attempting to bring about some reform in that country. That reform is a slow and long process. It must have an impact on our wool market particularly and to some extent on our wheat market. We must not forget that because it must have a major impact on our markets.

The other matter that has been overlooked is the corruption of the markets. We have the USA to thank for its export enhancement program. We have the EC to thank for its common agricultural policy. Both those policies work in competition. It is like two elephants fighting: the ants underneath get trampled. In some markets we just happen to be the ants because those two bodies have attacked some of the markets we share in other countries.

Our time here would be much better spent on actually arriving at a decision on how we can send messages to the EC and the US in an attempt to convince them that the GATT negotiations must continue, and must also have a result that will turn around the activities and the gross subsidisation that these two major groupings involve themselves in. We certainly sent the message very clearly to the US when President Bush was here. We certainly spoke at length to the US press corps which attended with him. Members of the Opposition were very good and vocal at doing that. Unfortunately, I do not recall seeing many of them doing it when the British press corps visited here last week. They were more intent on saying that we should look to Britain and kowtow to Britain, and that we were not doing things correctly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—John Howard for one.

—That is right. I suggest that some of that time and effort spent by members of the Opposition on being critical of members of the Government and their attitudes might have been better spent if they had taken the time to brief the British press corps travelling with the Queen, and to advise them of the impact on this country of the EC's common agricultural policy. Lest we forget, the UK is a member of the EC.
—Obviously your trade negotiations Ministers can't do it so you want us to do it for you.

—The Ministers have done a very good job. There have been a number of bipartisan trips and delegations to the EC and the US which must continue. Instead of attacking and getting into petty quibbling about past tense and history, as does a lot of Senator Brownhill's motion, we would be much better off discussing and organising how we can actually continue our very important lobbying and support work for the Ministers and shadow Ministers who have been involved—and I must recognise that a number of those have played an important part in this work as well. That requires a bipartisan approach. I know that the Democrats share our concerns about this as well.

PARA.TAB: We have also had the good old argument of the wool reserve price brought out again today. I would like to ask honourable senators opposite what they would have done. Would they not have abolished the reserve price? If not, how would they have funded it?

We have also heard calls today for a wheat guaranteed minimum price. We only heard calls for a guaranteed minimum price for wheat. We have not heard the Opposition acknowledge that in yesterday's statement $20m was set aside for a crop-planting scheme and RAS funding. This scheme will be funded purely by Commonwealth money and will assist farmers in need to plant this year's summer and winter crops. I say `crops', not just wheat. It needs to be remembered that many of our grain producers are not just producers of wheat; they do produce other commodities.

During our hearings relating to the drought on the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, as has been alluded to, one of the issues that we were confronted with by grain growers was concern that those who were in financial difficulties would not be able to access funds to put in a crop once the drought broke or once the season changed. This will enable those people to access funding purely for that purpose. They will be able to plant their crop and get their cash flow moving again. That needs to be praised and noted for its usefulness. We also need to note that it is for crops and not just wheat. It is exceedingly important that we recognise that. I recognise the value of the wheat farmers but I also recognise the value of other primary producers and other grain growers. There are many other sorts of grains.

We acknowledge that there has been a downturn in returns to these farmers. We also have to acknowledge that this has had a consequent effect upon the communities within which they live. That must always be remembered. Last night it was alleged that only a few lines of the economic statement related to farmers. It would appear that those opposite want to put farmers in a separate category and exclude them from the benefits of the other programs that will occur—the one-off family allowance payment and the increase in the family allowance supplement. These will help farming families, although one wonders whether the Opposition recognises that. We must also recognise that any improvement in the rail system, improving the rail access to ports—

TALK.START.PARA: —Making up for neglect.
—There has been neglect between six States and two Territories.
—Making up for neglect. That is what it is. You cut funding in the last 10 years.
—Have a look at your record. I wouldn't pursue that if I were you, Senator.
—Yes, I will pursue it.
—When your mob was in Government—
—Order! Senator West has the call.

—Senator Cook is much more familiar with the Western Australian Liberal Party Government's running down of the whole system than I am and I thank him for his contribution. These are just several of the issues and programs that must help country people and, by helping country people, help farmers. We cannot seem to get the point across to the Opposition that these sorts of issues—the improvement of rail links and road links—of course help farmers and help the rural communities. They are part of what was outlined in last night's statement and we look forward to those issues passing through this Senate; we will certainly be supporting them with a great deal of relish.

PARA.TAB: The other point that I omitted to mention that has had an impact upon primary producers is drought. I do not quite know how the Government is expected to break a drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —You broke it in 1983.
—Order! Senator Brownhill, you have spoken. Senator Panizza, you are about to.

—After the Committee visited some of these places there were substantial rains. One of the Opposition's proposals to overcome what it perceives are the evils of the Australian economy is to introduce a GST. There are many names we can give that acronym, but most of them are unparliamentary so I shall resist. The Opposition fails to recognise that it will put close to 15 per cent on household food bills.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. This debate is not about the GST. I would love to debate the GST with Senator West any time. This debate is about what is happening in the rural communities. It is not about something that will happen in the future. It is about what is happening now. That is when people want help—now, not later.
—Order! That was half a point of order and half a point of view. Senator West is entitled to speak about that matter if she is relating it to the motion before us.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. My comments do relate to the matter at hand. They relate to the impact upon the spending power of farming families and farming households.
—What about the sales tax you put on ice cream, and orange juice, and flavoured milk, and muesli bars?
—I suggest that honourable senators opposite explain why they want to put a 15 per cent tax on bread, milk, meat—on those sorts of things.
—And on caviar. I know it will inconvenience you.
—The necessities of life.

—Yes, caviar really is a necessity! But it is important that people recognise what the Opposition wants to do. We have seen the basket of goods mentioned in the Opposition's Fightback package—or `Frightpack' package as it could be more aptly titled. One has only to look at an answer given in the other place by the former Treasurer, Mr Willis, on this matter. As he said, it would appear that if people want to live on the Opposition's basket of goods they will have to eat Pal and drink Harpic. I think that outlines very clearly what the package contains. I know that when I go to the supermarket each week I am up for about six or seven loaves of bread. The Opposition has something like one in its package. I know that I am also up for about $30 worth of meat. The Opposition had, I think, one chop in its package—totally inadequate and totally—
—Unbalanced.

—An unbalanced diet; I thank Senator Bell. Those opposite say that to overcome these problems and to help they will remove payroll tax. I suggest that they talk to the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner. He is in favour of abolishing payroll tax—but only if the State is compensated by the Federal Government. The other furphy about payroll tax that needs to be remembered is that in New South Wales—and I presume that other States are fairly similar in this regard—for wage bills under half a million dollars, or $500,000, employers do not pay payroll tax. It is a great thing to abolish payroll tax when most farmers have wage and salary bills well under half a million dollars. That is a false promise—an incentive or carrot—that they put up to try to entice the people of Australia to support them. I suggest that the people of Australia will certainly see through their falsehoods, to use a parliamentary word.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I turn to part (b) of the motion, which refers to General Custer. I think the Opposition has forgotten that it was General Custer who, at Appomattox, cut off the Lee troops and forced the surrender of the Confederate army. I would suggest that this week is our Yellow Tavern where Custer inflicted a serious blow to the Confederate troops about 12 months before Appomattox. I warn the Opposition to be careful of Appomattox approaching in about 12 months time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting my National Party colleague Senator Brownhill in the debate on this motion. I have listened with interest to what Senator West has been saying. She wanted to know what the coalition was going to do for rural people. I suggest that she read the Fightback package completely, because the coalition parties realise the important part that farmers play in the economy of Australia. She told us that there had been a downturn in returns to farmers. We quite realise that. But she forgets to mention the increased costs and imposts on rural producers brought about by this Labor Government. That is one thing she did not mention or bring to our notice at all. Senator Brownhill in his speech outlined a lot of the assistance to primary producers that has been removed by this present Labor Government. It is no wonder that so many of them are in such a disastrous plight.

PARA.TAB: I have made many speeches in this place about that problem. The Labor Party likes to talk loudly about social justice, but rural people apparently are not part of its social justice program. Its economic policies have already been ruinous to anyone trying to contribute to the productivity of the nation. Those of us who inhabit this nation are all Australians. Last night the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tried to claim in his blueprint for a bankcard led recovery that we are all together as one nation. But I tell honourable senators that we are two nations in terms of financial opportunity: those who are fortunate enough to live in metropolitan Australia and those discriminated against by living in rural or remote Australia. It is this Government which has created these two nations.

The Government has done nothing to try to bridge this rift. Indeed, its policies have contributed to a disturbing widening of the gulf between these two sections of our nation. This Government has demonstrated that it has no interest in those non-metropolitan Australians. Its neglect effectively punishes those who, for a variety of reasons, choose not to live in the cities and big rural towns. To be a non-metropolitan Australian under this Government is to be second class—a member of the B team; a reserve grade Australian. Last night's document purporting to be for one nation and for all Australians seems to conveniently forget the hundreds of thousands of people who live outside metropolitan Australia.

What was there in the document for rural Australians? Nothing much—only a few meagre crumbs. But we know that this document will not underwrite the price of the coming season's wheat crops to restore confidence in that industry. It will not change the income equalisation deposit scheme—an excellent scheme for people in rural Australia—to make it an effective insurance policy against low incomes. Regrettably, the Government does not intend to abolish the wholesale sales tax in order to save farmers $170m a year. The Prime Minister will not abolish fuel excise, which is paid on nearly 50 per cent of fuel used on farms and pushes up the cost of transport used to move goods to and from farms. I think that that excise is probably one of the most evil things that has been imposed over the years. Of course, the Government will not bite the bullet and implement a national drought policy, despite the severe drought conditions that have hamstrung farmers for the past 12 months.

This motion from Senator Brownhill shows that the Government's own body—the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, or ABARE—confirms that farm incomes were slashed by a massive 75 per cent last year. There is no hope being offered for these people by the economic statement. Instead, as this motion suggests, any recovery will be too late for the hundreds of thousands of farmers who are already bankrupt, financially and emotionally.

It is not as though this Government has simply turned its back on rural problems, letting them fester by callous neglect. I believe it is worse than that. Its policies have actively worked to make things worse. I have heard many speakers in this place and in the media argue about the merits of free trade and the abolition of tariffs, but I have yet to see any significant benefits flow to our rural sector. Only hardship seems to be the end result. Australia has been building its tariff policy around its commitment to the Uruguay Round of GATT. We are told that it is necessary for Australia to reduce its tariff barriers to demonstrate our good faith at GATT and to encourage the larger, more powerful nations to demonstrate that they will follow our lead. However, I believe it is quite clear that this philosophy is not working. The EC and other countries have failed to respond to any of the initiatives taken by Australia and other trading nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hewson proposes far more radical tariff slashing.

—I am telling Senator Cook my position on this matter. As far as I am concerned, I do not believe in imposing tariff cuts. This came under a considerable spotlight when we addressed the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. In that debate the Government outlined how it intended to set what it calls a `level playing field' for the motor vehicle industry; the textiles, clothing and footwear industry; the vegetable industry; and the sugar industry. What concerns me greatly is that it did this without regard to the impact of its policies on the competitive conditions within which producers in each of those industries work.

PARA.TAB: In following this policy we are really saying that because we are on the altar of free trade, because we want to be able to hold our hands on our hearts and say to the Europeans, the Americans and the Japanese that we are acting as we believe they should act, we will be in a better position to ensure that they do so. Unfortunately, in doing so we place a number of our major industries in a position where there will be even more unemployed; where there will be an even larger number of those engaged in those industries who will be shutting up plants and moving offshore; and where, in many rural sectors, we will find that imports will take over their market share. Regrettably, even with the peanut industry and the fruit growing industry, we are finding that imports are taking over the local growers' share of the market. Reductions of tariffs in these areas as some sort of grand gesture, while they are not being matched by our trading competitors, is a warm inner glow nonsense.

Indeed, no-one can ignore the impact of all the arguments and evidence about the effects of this tariff war on Australian farmers put to the President of the United States when he was here in January. George Bush simply indicated that his job was to protect American farmers first and not leave them to the mercy of such trade wars. I ask honourable senators why this Government does not do the same for our own people instead of, in effect, selling them down the chute.

What makes it even more criminal is that we are doing so after people have committed their life savings in what has been an economically difficult time and, thus, their continued economic viability is threatened. We have not made a level playing field. We have not created a climate where growers will be able to continue with their investments; in fact, we penalise them to the point where it puts enormous pressure on the continued viability of their industry.

The major problem we have is on the international scene where we are not getting a fair go in trade; Australia is proving to be lily white in the area of trade tariffs and no other country seems to be following along that avenue. This makes a mockery of the Labor Party's promise in the 1983 rural policy speech in Griffith to an unqualified commitment to maintaining the viability of Australia's great rural sector and the provincial infrastructure. The Federal Labor Government has not lived up to this commitment. Effectively, it has stripped away from Australian agriculture those measures which shielded it from the corrupt practices of the international market.

I have already made, in the past few years, what seems to me to be quite a lot of speeches on each of these subjects as they not only become more and more critical to our national financial welfare, but also involve the disintegration of a lifestyle and society which has served Australia well in the past. If we fail any of our rural industries now, we will see the disintegration of rural Australian society as many of us have known.

It has been very distressing to note that the profound shift in Australia's export earnings from farm products to other economic sectors has left primary producers with shrinking incomes. These changes mean that we cannot afford simply to sit back and wait for the farm sector to be virtually depopulated. That is really what is starting to happen all over Australia. It is not only happening in the South Burnett where I come from, but also in so many other rural areas.

The Government cannot claim that the rural crisis has only just hit. It has been warned continuously for years and the evidence to show just what is happening outside our major cities has been around for quite some time. Similarly, it is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that we eventually see the demise of the family farmer, which has already happened in a number of our major industries.

It is in the interest of everyone to control the process, to ameliorate its worst effects and to approach the whole issue with a balance of sympathy and energy. A coalition government will move swiftly to unite these two Australias into one nation and end the geographical apartheid practised by Labor. We have demonstrated that we in the coalition are the only ones who can look after the interests of non-metropolitan as well as metropolitan Australia, and bring them together in a single nation where fairness and equity prevail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill's well prepared speech accurately described the full litany of problems that are being faced by Australia's farmers. I am tempted to think that it was such a well prepared speech—and I suspect it was prepared last December to support the motion which was moved at that time—that it had to be delivered regardless of what has taken place in the immediate past.
—It was actually prepared today.

—It was a brilliant speech for one that was prepared today, but I still suggest that it was directed—I hope it was directed—to the motion which was moved last December. The disturbing thing about this speech was that the general sweep of blame that was caught up in Senator Brownhill's broom failed to discriminate honestly.

PARA.TAB: Senator West took an opportunity to list some of the external factors which influence the welfare of our rural economy. There was an unhelpful interjection which suggested that the Government tried to blame everybody else. The converse was also true and that was true throughout Senator Brownhill's speech, where everything, including the weather, was the Government's fault.

Members of the coalition seem to conveniently forget that it was they who screamed at the Democrats about free markets, especially during the wool debate. They allied with the Government to destroy the wool industry's reserve price scheme. They are still allied with the Government to persecute our farmers with the deregulated banking system, the dismantling of import tariffs—and I am sure Senator Bjelke-Petersen is interested to be reminded of that—and the reduction of government intervention in markets and in what are known as government business enterprises.

I wonder now—and even today I was reminded that I should wonder more—at the coalition's commitment to the dogma of economic rationalism. I wonder at that because we heard Senator Brownhill pleading for the underwriting of the wheat crop, something which does not fit that dogma. We would support such an action, by the way, and we would also support such an action with regard to the wool market. That is another matter.

In this very chamber not very long ago, we heard Senator Archer speak about the Industry Commission's recommendations with regard to the dairy industry. I agree with much of what he said, but I would like the coalition to take note that Senator Archer was listing the many reasons why that Industry Commission report and its recommendations on the dairy industry should not be adopted, should be refused out of hand. Those very reasons were the sorts of social benefits which derive from having a successful dairy industry located outside our metropolitan area, an industry which should not have to compete, just on price, with imports. I agree, and the Democrats wholeheartedly support, the very notion that Senator Archer brought in here. I wonder at the commitment that the coalition has towards this dry economic view of the world.

I wonder why we have to put up with the Opposition's crocodile tears about the problems that are being faced by our rural producers. The Opposition then fails to support the sorts of tangible Democrat moves that we could take to effectively support our rural areas, ranging from removing the assets test for Austudy recipients to a moratorium on tariff reduction. Senator Bjelke-Petersen often speaks in rural debates. I am disappointed that she has not stayed. I was going to remind her of her own speeches in which she often speaks against tariff reductions. The Fightback package, which is thrust in front of us so often as the saviour of all the evils in the rural sphere of Australia, proposes to reduce tariffs, as Senator Cook has reminded us, in a much more drastic way than is proposed by the Government at the moment. On the one hand, the coalition is complaining about the situation and, on the other hand, it proposes an even worse situation for our farmers.

There are other members of the coalition and its supporters who question this free trade, unregulated market, non-interventionist dogma. They are questioning it and they are waking up. They are seeing too many farmers and other Australians waking up to the disadvantages of the coalition's policies in this area, yet the coalition has the cheek to criticise the Government. I contend that the blame is not to be worn completely by the Government in this issue; the coalition must share some of the blame, as we all must if we are honest.

Far too often in this place we try to apportion blame; we try to blame someone else. Instead of trying to share the blame in the way that this motion is proposing to do, I suggest that we would be better served in this place to re-examine all of our policies, to take what is good from all of them. It has to be admitted that there are good, tangible and useful aspects in the statement. We should support those instead of wasting our time apportioning blame as this motion does—a couple of months too late, by the way. This motion is historically irrelevant. I see no reason to support it.

The aspects on which we could congratulate the Government for introducing in the statement last night might include the aspects which Senator West mentioned. For example, there is an undoubted advantage to farmers and all of rural Australia in some of the propositions with regard to rail and road improvements, the money that is being spent on increasing the efficiency of our air, road and rail terminals and ports. If we were honest, we would see the advantages in that and spend time making sure that those advantages could accrue to the Australian population instead of wasting time with this historically irrelevant motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Brownhill's motion on the rural sector. The third part of his motion, which quotes ABARE, states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is suggested that recovery is unlikely before the second half of 1992, which will simply be too late for hundreds, and maybe thousands, of farmers who are bankrupt, financially and emotionally.

I will address that point later to show that if this Government had taken the right measures a bit earlier that revival may have come a few months earlier than late 1992. I am afraid that that recovery will not come in late 1992, let alone earlier.

PARA.TAB: Last night we had the One Nation statement from our new Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Does the Prime Minister perceive that there were two nations before last night—or even three? I believe that in 1983 we had one nation. The Government's policies have divided Australia in the last 10 years. They have caused division between industries, ethnic groups, et cetera; they have divided the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your industrial relations policies—very divisive.

—We will get around to the Government's industrial relations policy later. Senator Cook should tell us his policy for Robe River where we have an industrial policy which has shown mining the way to go. Robe River has the highest paid and the highest producing iron ore miners in the world. Senator Cook tried to wreck it every point of the way.Returning to the One Nation statement, we had a statement to tell us that we are `one nation'. We are one nation! What government has made it two nations or three or 10? I believe that Mr Keating could have called it something else.

PARA.TAB: One economist commented at the last Agricultural Outlook Conference that recovery has been six months away for three years—or four years, or five years or the length of this Government. To my knowledge, the recovery in the rural sector has been coming since 1986-87. Every time the Government looks at it, it is six months away. As a result of the decisions that have been taken by this Government and certain industries, the 1990s is likely to be the worst decade in the rural industry for many decades. Australian farm families will be facing their most difficult decade with increased adjustment pressures from changes in technical, economic, environmental and institutional conditions facing agricultural industries. This Government neglects this section of the Australian community time and time again.

The outlook for many farmers, particularly those with smaller enterprises amongst the broad acres, is very much one of trouble. Farmers are making considerable savings—they have to. In the farming game, if one cannot see the dollar coming in the door, one has to economise in certain sections to survive. One can make cuts, use less inputs here and cut something else there. It has to be done to survive. People just cannot keep borrowing to get them by in this long drought—not `drought' as in rainfall but drought as in rising prices and neglect by the Government.

Even though farmers have made cutbacks in costs, net farm cash income is forecast to drop by 16 per cent to $3.2 billion in 1991-92, following a 40 per cent decrease in 1990-91. When allowance is made for depreciation on plant, stock and those sorts of things, the real net value of farm production is expected to fall by 42 per cent to $398m in 1991-92. That is the lowest on record. I repeat: $398m is the total net value profit for all farmers in Australia. That is a very damning figure. Wool, wheat, cotton and sugar producers are expected to experience large drops in income. There are a few bright spots existing: meat has always remained reasonable while dairying and horticulture are probably on the up. But, in general, the whole of the agricultural industry in Australia is suffering badly.

We have had two very savage years in a row. That has had a terrible effect on the industry. There was a drought in the eastern States last year. The Government says that it is not responsible for the drought. Of course it is not responsible for the drought. But the Government certainly claimed credit for breaking the drought in 1983. If the Government claimed the credit then, I suppose it is fair enough that we blame it for what is happening now. We had a disastrous wheat crisis in the 1990-91 season. It was disastrous because of the actions of the European Community and the American export enhancement program. We have to accept world prices. The only way that we can turn around our productivity and any profit that we make on farms is to minimise our costs. That is the only way to go.

As Australia's primary industry has now come to the end of its worst two years, one would have thought that the Government's One Nation package which was delivered last night would have given rural industry more than the half a dozen lines it did receive. Rural industry could have been in a much better position, and the Government would not have had to do quite so much in this package, if the Government had taken the right decisions in the last half a dozen years.

For instance, let us look at the IED scheme—the income equalisation deposits—that Senator Brownhill and Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentioned earlier. We had a good scheme going which commenced in the Fraser years. Unfortunately, when Senator Walsh was the Minister for Finance—and I tell him this any time I talk to him about it—he perceived that there was a rort in the system. He has never been able to explain so that anyone can understand why there was supposed to have been a rort. Anyhow, he decided that there had been a rort, the IED scheme was changed and it was useless.

I will turn to the figures I have on equalisation deposits. The first year for which there is information available is 1978-79. In that year there were deposits totalling $66m; in 1979-80, $79m; in 1980-81, $136m; in 1981-82, $163m; and in 1982-83, $165m. Unfortunately, 1982-83 is about the time that this Labor Government was elected and the IED scheme changed. So the following year, 1983-84, it went back to $155m; in 1984-85 it was $130m; 1985-86, $94m; 1986-87, $67m; 1987-88, $48m; and in 1988-89, $34m. We can see how it was drained out. If the IED scheme had been left in place as it was, those savings by farmers would have been there to be used in those tough years. But no, the Government took them away.

So while those good years—the high wheat price years—from about 1982 to 1986 were quite good right through to 1988, the rural industry was not able to use the IED scheme and it simply paid out money to the Tax Office and it was gone. The Keating Treasury got hold of that money and the bank was bare before the tough years started. That is one of the decisions that this Government has made that has gone awry. The rural industry could have been in a position to keep itself right to get over these tough years.

I now move to wool. During an exchange with, I think, Senator Brownhill about the reserve price scheme, I heard Senator Cook say that the Government was the first to want to do away with the reserve price scheme. I have been advocating since 1986, before I came to this place, that that scheme was not right and that it should have been done away with. I have always advocated that here.

When the coalition decided it was time for that scheme to go and was advising the Government that it was time to go, what did we have? We had Mr Kerin in China, the United States and Italy—and in Italy they do not forgive you for breaking promises too well; they have ways of making you remember that you have made a promise. You get a mark against you, generally on the right side of the face, so I would say that Mr Kerin should not go back to Italy! He gave a cast iron guarantee that that reserve price would stay at either 700c or 900c—I will be corrected if I am wrong. Within three weeks it was gone. No wonder we have no credibility in China, Italy and the United States. If he knew the price was going, why did he not say he would dream or hope it would stay? He gave them a cast iron guarantee, and there it was.

If we had done away with it earlier and not had that big stockpile and big debt, the wool industry would have been far better off. We had a wool Bill in this Parliament last year on which, amongst others, I spoke. The coalition arrived at a calculation that a 10 per cent wool tax was enough; it was ample. Even the Democrats believed it because they supported us in the first place and we got it up. I remember debating with Senator Cook across the chamber on certain figures. Now the call from the Wool Commission is to cut the wool tax. The Countryman dated 13 February 1992 states:

SPEECH.PARA: That call comes after this month's latest ABARE forecasts that average farm incomes will be minus $300 in 1991/92, down 105 per cent
Under current legislation, the AWRC has seven years to sell off the stockpile and repay the industry's $2.7 billion debt.
But the AWRC is required to repay only $20 million this financial year although favourable market conditions have enabled it to sell $206 million in wool.
The AWRC wants its debt reduction targets made cumulative to give it greater flexibility to stay out of the market when prices are falling.
The article states, `The coalition moved a successful motion in the Senate for the 10 per cent tax', as I said, but then the Democrats caved in and gave the Government 12 per cent.

PARA.TAB: We said here time and time again that 10 per cent was ample. Now the Wool Commission has come up with the startling figure that probably 8 per cent is ample. If only the Government had made the right decision. We told it and told it. We told Senator Cook who led the debate for the Government. If the right decision had been made, farmers growing an average of 105 bales of wool per year would have had an extra $12,487 in their pocket. But no, the Government did not listen and the Democrats of course backed up that non-listening. That is another decision that the Government could have made that certainly would have helped primary industry, and it would not be in the depths of disaster in which it is now.

Let us move on to the price of wheat and the wheat industry. Senator Bell asked, `Where's Senator Brownhill's economic rationale when he is calling for a GMP on wheat?'. I can tell you, Mr Deputy President. The wheat industry would not be in the strife it is in now if it had listened not to us—not to the Opposition—but to the Premier of Western Australia. Last year she gave a one-off and told the President of the wheat industry in Western Australia, John Walsh, that if he came back for a second time around she would throw him out of the office. She gave that one-off guarantee. We were looking at $115 a tonne this time last year when planting was coming up. She gave a guarantee of $150 which enabled the banks to lend with confidence to the growers needing money to plant crop.

In the One Nation statement delivered last night was a certain amount of money to help plant crops. Senator West made that point. But the point is, that sort of money has to go through this RAS—the rural adjustment scheme or whatever it is called on the other side. By the time it is decided who is worthy or needs that money or does not need that money, and when it is being done in the city rather than out in the bank branches, it is too late. The money comes through in July when the crop should have been planted in May. How can that work?

If the whole nation had had a one-off GMP last year, that money would now be able to go out because the local bank deals with the farmer in his home town, knows the farmer's habits, knows how careful the farmer is and what he is like with money. The decision is made in the home town. If that had been done, we would now be in a far better position.

Now I come back to my point that the wheat farming industry could have revived far earlier than late 1992. You may know yourself, Mr Deputy President, that the price of wheat—the estimate of the pool return was only altered last Monday—has now reached $180. So in the last six months or less, it has gone from $115 to $180. If there had been a one-off GMP last year all around Australia and all the crop had gone in, many—I would say most—of those farmers who have a chance of surviving would have been in a far better position because they would have been receiving $180 a tonne, and that is guaranteed money in the bank as of the end of March. This Government could not do it.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean, flagged this for one week. Then he must have been sat on either by Treasury or the Prime Minister—I do not know what happened—because he forgot about it. I am not looking any more for a total GMP on wheat; I am just looking for a one-off arrangement. The Government has put forward its One Nation program. If the Government had a one-off GMP this year—forget last year—then the farmers in the eastern States who may be battling to plant crops could do so with guarantees from their local banks. That could and should have been done this year. Senator West said that such an arrangement does not help other grain growers. I fully agree but a much smaller figure could have been provided to help out those growers. If this had been done, the recovery could have been achieved much earlier.

Senator West also referred to the amount of money mentioned in the One Nation statement that will be set aside for road and rail. Like Premier Lawrence in Western Australia when she announced her package the other week, this Government is making a virtue of neglect. For 10 years this Government has neglected road and rail. It has now allocated an extra $600m—correct me if I am wrong—to upgrade roads. I do not have the figure for rail.

Under the Fraser Government, increasing amounts were spent on roads. The last figure was $1.25 billion. That amount has remained static in the 10 years since this Government came to power. Today in real terms that $1.25 billion a year should have been at least $2 billion. So on average, $4 billion, not $400m, should have been spent on roads in those years. Now the Government is making a virtue of having put an extra $600m into roads. The same goes for rail—the Government is only putting money in to make up for past neglect.

The rural industry will be helped by the new depreciation schedules announced in last night's package. As Senator Button told us last night and today, under the depreciation schedules, claims on machines and buildings can be made over seven years rather than 20 years or 30 years. Unfortunately, very little is done for schedules which relate to periods of around five years. This is the period within which most farm machinery is written off. At Question Time today Senator Button told us that it is a rort to reduce the five-year period and, therefore, that arrangement will not be changed. What is the point of an improved depreciation schedule if the farmers do not have any money to invest in new plant? It is pointless.

Senator West said that costs to farmers will rise by 15 per cent because of the 15 per cent GST. All input costs on rural industry are rebatable. Other items, such as food, baby's clothes and all that sort of thing, to which Senator West referred, will rise by an average of 4.4 per cent. So low income earners will be rewarded twice. If this Government continues to try to criticise the Fightback package, it should be truthful and put forward correct facts.

The rural industry is in a very tight situation. If the Government is prepared to make any decisions—even decisions arising out of this One Nation package—it still has time to put them into action. I hope that any good measures that are contained in the package—or any good measures at all—will be dealt with a lot faster than those contained in the statement on 12 March last year. The legislation containing the depreciation schedules that were announced at that time has not even hit this place yet. It has gone through the House of Representatives but it is not here. How much longer will it take to deal with any good measures that might be around?

My Whip is indicating that it is time for me to wind up my remarks. I wholeheartedly support the motion moved by my colleague, Senator Brownhill, and I urge the rest of the chamber also to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to this motion and support Senator Brownhill and my colleagues, I should like to make a few observations about the contributions to this debate made by other senators. I find it absolutely amazing—and I am sure that you do too, Mr Acting Deputy President—that, bearing in mind what Senator West had to say over the last months during the hearings of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs drought inquiry, she can come into this chamber and make the sorts of comments that she made today.

PARA.TAB: I am sick and tired of people coming in here and blaming Russia, Europe, America and everybody else but ourselves for the problems which now exist in agriculture in this country. We need to have a very close look at the imposts that have been imposed not only on agriculture but also on all our exports to make them internationally competitive.

Senator West was most understanding during the hearings of the Committee at places like Bourke, Cobar, Ravensthorpe and Esperance. Yet she spoke absolute drivel here today when she blamed Russia for our current problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —She was covering up for the Labor Party.

—She is just covering up for the Labor Party. Nobody will deny that we have to face the facts in this country. As a major exporter, we are subject to what happens overseas. Nobody will deny that it is important for us to continue to pursue the objectives of the GATT rounds. But equally, let us address some of the things that can be done in Australia to help overcome the problems. Senator West failed to do this.

PARA.TAB: I hope that Senator Bell has the courage to put out a press release on what he said here today. It is nonsensical to describe Senator Brownhill's motion as historical. It is not historical. Senator Bell also attended some of the Committee's inquiries. He would have heard and seen the position that many of the growers and producers find themselves in. It is not correct to describe this motion as historical.

We have been challenged to mention some of the things that we would do in government, and I will come to that in a moment. But I want to refer to a couple of aspects of the One Nation statement which was brought down last night. One of the problems we have had in the rural sector and right across-the-board is the impact of high interest rates.

Many businesses have been forced to use their capital, and, in the process, have been forced to capitalise their interest. That is now flowing through into their ability to service their debts and their costs. The other impact of interest rates is that businesses have to pass their costs on to producers. In effect, in the end it is the exporters who have to pick them up. It is almost impossible for rural people and exporters—the people who pick up the total cost—to survive in the environment of high interest rates that was run by Mr Keating when he was Treasurer.

In the time that I have left—and I am rushing through what I want to say—I want to address the pork-barrelling exercise we had last night. The big fear of that pork-barrelling exercise is that we will return to the high interest rate regime. We must be very wary of the impact of that.

I want to say something about the rural adjustment scheme. Witness after witness told the Committee that the last thing that they wanted was more money. They said that they could not handle or service more debt, yet that is being put forward as one of the panaceas of the rural situation.

Let us now look briefly at wool. Is it not a marvellous gesture that if the Wool Realisation Commission makes a profit on the sale of the wool—the wool that is owned by the producers, the debt for which is being serviced by the producers, a wool stockpile in which they have a $2 billion investment of their own money—the producers will be paid back their own money? I do not know what the Government expected to do with the money before it brought this statement down but, in effect, it is saying that the farmers will get their own money back.

I turn briefly to a number of things the Opposition has said it will do. The first thing—and this has been raised by previous speakers—is that we will return to and put in place a proper IED scheme. I want to quote from a producer who gave evidence to us at the drought inquiry the other day—a producer who is just about out of business today, with the combination of collapsed commodity prices and drought. In the last four years before the drought started two years ago that producer averaged $40,000 income tax a year. Yet he had no mechanism by which he could set aside money to protect himself from a downturn or a drought day. One of the first issues that will get our very high attention is a proper IED scheme that will allow people to become self-reliant and look after themselves, to smooth out their income flows, because agriculture is an industry that has very rough income flows.

The other step the Opposition will be taking, and it is very important for export industries, is looking at the system under which export regulation is applied. We will be moving towards privatising that and getting rid of the overmanning, the costs, the inefficiencies and the hindrances that apply in the current situation.

Another means by which the Opposition will address rural problems—this comes straight from the Fightback package, and I make no apology for it—is that farmers, graziers and pastoralists will pay 26c a litre less for all petrol used on-farm for business purposes and 19c a litre less for petrol for personal vehicle use. Our proposed fuel reductions will also flow through to the transport companies.

We heard in the statement last night about road building, and one will not argue that we need a good road system. But it is important how that is done, whether we can afford it and whether it is funded. We did not see anything in the Government statement about how it will be funded. Under the Opposition's policy, with the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and the fuel excise, fuel reduction costs to the road transporters who carry our goods will be in the order of $53,000 per rig per annum.

As I mentioned earlier today, the rail system pays fuel excise. The cost of that to the rail system represents some 20 per cent of the cost of carrying wheat on rail—or it was in Western Australia about four years ago, and I do not believe the relativities have changed. In addition, cuts will apply to Avgas. This will mean that the cost of aerial agricultural work such as crop dusting, superphosphate spreading, mustering and all the other tasks for which aeroplanes are used will drop.

I have outlined a number of the Opposition's policies which will benefit those in rural areas very significantly. Since we have little influence on the international scene, the Government should be addressing itself to getting rural costs down. It has long been the cry of the farmer organisations, whether it be the National Farmers Federation, State organisations or the commodity councils, that the way to allow agriculture in this country to remain competitive is to look very closely at the impost of taxation on inputs and get them off; and to look at the imposts on the infrastructure industries such as transport and get them off. This Government has done little or nothing about that. We will then be able to operate on the same basis as countries such as America, Canada, Argentina, Brazil and the European countries—the list is endless. They do not have the up-front imposts we have. That is something that could be done immediately, and it would certainly make a big difference at the end of the day to the profitability of the individuals within the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to speak to this motion, but my more lucid and erudite colleagues have beaten me to it. One thing I want to say is that there are a lot of economists in this place, but no-one realises the fundamental truth about the Australian economy: unless the rural economy is doing well, the urban economy and the national economy are not doing well. We have been going through very difficult periods with commodity prices overseas and bad weather. They are factors that we really do not have any control over, but we do have control over the imposts we load onto our farming community. This Government has loaded up the farming community to a degree that we have not seen in our history. It has made economic survival a matter of desperate necessity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The President has received a letter from Senator Harradine nominating himself to be a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

—Mr Deputy President, I seek your assistance at this stage. My understanding is that earlier this day the matter had not been settled. However, I have been given a resolution appointing Senator Harradine. I wonder whether we can defer the matter of Senator Harradine joining the Committee until later in the day so that I can get better information as to whether it has been settled.

—My advice was only about an hour ago. I do not see much problem in our deferring this matter until later this evening.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bolkus)—by leave—agreed to:
That consideration of committee reports and government responses be not proceeded with this day.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I shall be brief. I particularly wanted to comment on this report, which was tabled earlier this day, because the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory is recommending that its name be changed. I hope that that will come about; I support the move. The advent of self-government in the Territory makes it inappropriate for the Committee still to be named the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. We are recommending that it be named in relation to the national capital.

PARA.TAB: The Committee is one of the oldest committees of the Parliament, passing into non-existence—if this move is accepted—after some 35 years. It is a committee on which, since the time it came into existence in 1957, 102 senators and members have served, 12 of them as Chairman. You, Mr Deputy President, were a member from August 1978 to September 1980. It is almost like looking at a history of the Parliament to note those who have been involved. In its early years, a senator was always a Chairman of that Committee. From a quick count, it seems that over 100 reports have been tabled by the Committee over the period, dealing principally with variations to the city plan.

I want to refer to a document prepared by my predecessor, the late Senator John Knight, Chairman of that Committee. It was an address to the Canberra and District Historical Society in August 1980 entitled The Capital and the Committee. It is a document which well records the Committee's history. Hopefully in the future someone might update it to the Committee's demise in 1992. I do not have time tonight to go into some parts of this document that I would like to. However, I recommend that anybody interested in the history of the national capital, the parliamentary committees and this one in particular should look at it.
It seemed to me that the recommendation to change the name, getting rid of the earlier one, was something that should not pass unnoticed at the time of the tabling of the report.
Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to concentrate my contribution to this debate on the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), on its failure to contribute to internationalising Australia, which is possibly our greatest challenge. Senator Short, on our side—our finance spokesman—will speak a little later and address the subject of the fiscal irresponsibility of the statement. Senator Alston, hopefully also later tonight, will look at some of the disappointing social consequences. The statement might be better described as a statement oriented to social injustice rather than to social justice.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating called it the One Nation statement, but it is really the `One Job' statement. Mr Keating got a job he did not deserve. His mismanagement of the Australian economy has resulted in untold disappointment and tragedy for hundreds of thousands of Australians. That he should be rewarded by his colleagues for that appalling record simply tells us of the depths to which the Labor Party has sunk in recent years.

Power has become a drug and the Government is intoxicated. The concept of service is forgotten. The New South Wales Right of the Labor Party, which controls this Government, referred to from within the Labor Party for its thuggery, governs this country for what it can get out of it, not for what it can put in.

The people of Australia did not choose Mr Keating to govern and they cannot wait for the chance to get rid of him. He had one opportunity. He could have called it the `One Opportunity' statement, to show that he could provide a vision and a policy to back it, and he muffed that chance—not surprisingly, because that is not why he was promoted. He was put there on the basis of his record of personal abuse as the one man the Government believed could blow John Hewson and his vision for Australia out of the water—just straightforward, simple, negative politics. Mr Keating's arrogance and incompetence and, to some extent, the Labor deals with its mates which locked him in led him to maintain the crushing interest rates which have destroyed so much of Australia's business.

Mr Keating, of course, has always known better. This was the recession Mr Keating brought upon Australia. There was no world recession that we got caught up in, no outside excuse. Mr Keating did this one all by himself—perhaps, Senator Button might say, with some help from others within the Government who have presided over industry policy for the last eight years. Mr Dawkins, now promoted to Mr Treasurer, and Mr Keating's mate, has done his best in recent years to wreck tertiary education in this country. Then there is Senator Richardson, who pulls the numbers and who sells out to any interest group which offers an electoral benefit. And there are a few others.

The costs of Mr Keating's unnecessary yet deliberately engineered recession are enormous. The figures are staggering enough, but they in no way show the human misery they represent. The number of unemployed increased by 38.6 per cent between last year and the current year—900,700 people were unemployed in November 1991, an increase of 220,300 unemployed in eight years. Full time employment has fallen by 34.2 per cent since April 1983. To be parochial, if I might be excused for just a moment, in my home State of South Australia unemployment is now 11.9 per cent and youth unemployment is 37.5 per cent. Mr Keating, who said that under him we would never have a recession, gave us the worst recession in 60 years. He said it was the medicine we had to take. Now, in this unfounded pump-priming exercise, he has the gall to say to us:
This statement is very much about making this nation strong. It's about Australians realising that their destiny is in their hands.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the people's fault that Australia is in such a mess. It is Mr Keating's fault. Here we are, with boundless opportunities, in the fastest growing region in the world, a small and reasonably well educated population, with enormous natural advantages, and we have record unemployment, record bankruptcies—up 154 per cent between 1982-83 and 1990-91—and record debt, with gross foreign debt having risen under Mr Keating as Treasurer to $166 billion at the end of 1991, up from $36 billion when he came to office, an increase of 362 per cent.

PARA.TAB: This is the legacy of the Hawke-Keating years, of their stewardship of the Australian economy. The key to Australia's problems lies in the ongoing current account deficit. Through wages indexed to the CPI and other mad policies of Labor, we ceased to be competitive in so many areas. It led to a crisis, a crisis which is still with us and which has been rekindled by last night's pump-priming.

In the last quarter before Mr Keating became Treasurer, the current account deficit was $612m. Under Keating, as we know, it was often over $2 billion. Mr Keating's answer, instead of seeking to make Australia more competitive, was to force up interest rates to dampen demand. But in fact he pushed up interest rates until even the best run businesses were no longer competitive. Having destroyed so much of the economy, he now wants to buy an answer with money we do not have—the quick fix, the kick start, which puts us back into the boom-bust cycle from which we so desperately need to break away.

Dramatic contrast is offered by the coalition's Fightback package. It is fully funded, because we recognise the need to arrest debt, not contribute to it by the fiscal blow-out we are again experiencing. Remember Mr Keating, as Treasurer, saying not so long ago that never again would it be necessary for the Government to put its hand into the cookie jar of people's savings. Yet here he is, doing it again.

Access Economics estimates a fiscal deficit of $9 billion this year, before Mr Keating's latest expenditure. Australia cannot afford to keep running this way. Fightback seeks to set the framework within which Australia can again be internationally competitive. It is structured to provide incentives to individuals and businesses to grow and to employ. It does so by offering cuts in business taxation of some $20 billion a year, fully funded, compared with Mr Keating's offer last night of less than $1 billion unfunded. And business taxes must come down if we are to be competitive.
