Only last month we learnt of a new OECD study which found that Australian business has to pay the highest rate of tax on new investment in the industrialised world, except for Turkey. Coincidentally, at about the same time the Business Council of Australia released a study showing that, of nine countries, Australia imposes the highest taxes on output for domestic sale except for Japan and the highest apart from Japan and Germany on production for export.

Fightback would allow a business tax structure which would be internationally competitive. As almost all the industrialised world has found, it cannot be financed without a broad-based goods and services tax, and Mr Keating knows that, too. That is why the Keating statement was flawed from the outset, if it ever was supposed to provide a more competitive economy.

Fightback provides the framework for competitive labour relations—not lower wages as Mr Keating would claim but contracts tailored to the unique circumstances of a particular enterprise so that both employer and employee can benefit. The Labor Party has been dragged kicking and screaming to enterprise bargaining, but nobody really believes that it will deliver. Senator Cook made clear today that, despite the change of rhetoric, those opposite in the Government will not deliver. They do not even understand what it means. That is why Mr Keating's statement last night requires that such agreements must be registered with the IRC, the core structure of the centralised system.

Fightback additionally provides for real reform on the waterfront and in shipping, which Labor cannot deliver because Labor will not end the Waterside Workers Federation monopoly on the waterfront. Labor will not give stevedoring companies the right to recruit and manage their own work force. Labor will not privatise port authorities or end the Australian monopoly on coastal shipping, or terminate the trans-Tasman shipping agreement and privatise the Australian National Line.

Australian transport must be at internationally competitive rates. Thus, under Fightback, and fully funded, we are able to abolish all fuel excise—$6.6 billion—55 per cent of which falls on business, and abolish wholesale sales tax which is an enormous impost on land transport.

For a more competitive communications industry under Fightback we will open the telecommunications industry to full competition and commence the privatisation of Telecom. Labor, in response to its union accountability, does not have these options open to it. In addition, because we understand that we cannot have a competitive Australia without world class schools, university and other educational training, we commit a great deal to it. Because Labor has not a goods and services tax, it is unable to match that commitment.

Again using my example of South Australia, I would point out that this year 34,319 students applied for university entrance, of which only 15,900 received offers. That is less than one in every two fully qualified South Australian school leavers who sought to get into university to further their education will not get the opportunity under Labor. Just as important as other initiatives, Fightback with the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and of course no GST on exports will mean that exports are cheaper and more competitive. Amazingly, Mr Keating's statement does so little to contribute to more competitive exports which are critical to our economic recovery.

One could go on because, in contrast to Mr Keating's statement, Fightback is not a knee-jerk reaction but an integrated fully funded package for a vigorous, outward looking, competitive Australian economy. Certainly some initiatives in his statement are stolen from Fightback! I refer to the open skies policy so far as it goes—and it is a pity that the Government has only just now realised that a level playing field means fair access to terminals—the interstate electricity grid, the money for TAFE, accelerated depreciation. All can be found in the published Fightback! document. Stolen or not, we are pleased to see it. Basically Mr Keating sees everything pretty much on track. All it needs is a kick along. But it is a track that has taken Australia to its current ruinous state. By contrast, we say that it is not the right track, and never will be when the forecast outcome is still unemployment of about 10 per cent. What we offer, we are proud to say, is a radical alternative, a real vision and a carefully crafted program to fulfil that vision.

There is too much complacency in the Keating statement, as there was in this week's analysis distributed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade entitled Australia and North-East Asia in the 1990s and in practically every Government document that we see. It is a complacency that we find so frustrating. Mr Keating should read the World Competitiveness Report 1991, which was published by the highly regarded World Economic Forum—I think Senator Button might have attended their conferences—and the International Institute for Management and Development. That report compares 23 developed countries according to eight major groups of variables. Australia was ranked sixteenth out of 23 in 1991, just ahead of Italy, New Zealand, Spain, Turkey, Portugal, Greece and Hungary.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's very good.

—I ask Senator Button to listen. Australia's weakest score was for `internationalisation', which was a composite of scores on a range of 46 sets of trade statistics in areas such as balance of trade, currency strength or exports of manufactured products as a percentage of total exports, and which shows the level of Australia's participation in the international economy.

PARA.TAB: On internationalisation Australia was ranked twentieth—only Hungary, Greece and Norway scoring lower. That appalling score was brought about by such factors as the following. As a percentage of total exports, Australia's manufactured exports were the lowest in the world below Hungary, Greece and New Zealand. Only 15.5 per cent of Australia's merchandise exports were manufactured goods compared with, say, Canada with 57.1 per cent. I use Canada as an example because it also is a major resource exporter. Even in absolute value terms, Australia's exports of manufactured products were lower than all except New Zealand and Greece.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! You really are pathetic.

—Yet Senator Button comes in here and boasts about our improvements in exports of manufactured goods. On the measure of export flexibility, which rated the adaptability of domestic products for export, Australia was also ranked at the very bottom. This is not a Government report. It is an independent, objective report on Labor's record and that record is appalling.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask those opposite to listen. They should read some of these items. Other areas in which Australia fared poorly were industrial relations, where we were twenty-second out of 23. So much for the Accord. In the area of protectionism, Australia was 21 out of 23. In railways and roads we were 19 out of 23, and as to port access 20 out of 23. These are factors that Senator Button should be taking into account rather than dismissing them in his usual way.

PARA.TAB: What is obvious is that, although Australia might be changing, others are changing more rapidly. We are not chasing static targets. We have not improved our position even in Asia, the fastest growing of all the markets. Even in the so-called `Son of Garnaut' report issued this week by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade there is an acknowledgment of Australia's failure to increase market share with this remarkable sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years, Australia's export performance was strong enough to maintain market share in North-East Asia.

That is all we are doing with Labor's so-called reforms—at best maintaining our position. Australia's market share in North-East Asia in 1990 was 3.8 per cent, the same as it was in 1987, even lower than it was in 1984 when it reached 4.3 per cent. That is what is pathetic. Although most of the recent growth in Australian exports has been to Asian markets, which I accept, our market share is not increasing.

PARA.TAB: I draw Senator Button's attention, as obviously he does not read these things, to another report delivered this week from the Business Council of Australia on participation of Australian companies in trade and investment in Asia. The report expresses the position in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is being pulled along in the slipstream rather than making a major share gain.

To us that is not good enough. Between 1985 and 1987, for example—this is what those opposite should be seeking to do in their stewardship of this economy—Western Europe increased its share of the Japanese market from 9.5 per cent to 18.2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Asia is clearly the most significant trading area for Australia, accounting for about 50 per cent of our exports, but our profile in Asia, if resources are excluded, is very small. Primary products plus metals and basic manufactured metals account for 83 per cent to 88 per cent of goods exported. The real problem is that in the higher value added area we are not competitive. Under Mr Keating's economic policies of high interest rates and a high dollar it was difficult enough for our natural resource exporters to remain competitive.

To recapitulate some of Professor Garnaut's main points, in his report, which the Government claims to have adopted as a recipe for a greater involvement in the expanding markets of Asia, Professor Garnaut said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's larger problem is that isolation has been greatly compounded by exceptionally high costs of trade at and beyond its borders—on the waterfront, in our civil aviation and high protection for manufacturing industry.

Garnaut also stressed the need for stable macro-economic policy to keep domestic expenditure on a steady, low inflation growth path—which, of course, we did not get last night. Here is Mr Keating again pump priming the economy in a way which must add to our current account, inflation and then interest rates. The same argument applies to the need for a more efficient tax system. I remind the Leader of the Government of the 1989 Hughes Committee report on Australian exports, which I would have thought the Minister would have read, which identified the lack of a value added type of tax as a factor reducing Australia's competitiveness vis-a-vis competitors employing the same systems.

PARA.TAB: One would have thought that this `Son of Garnaut' report produced by the Ministry this week would have made an assessment of progress in the micro-economic reforms so necessary to improve our competitiveness. But no, the report says that it does not discuss domestic reforms at length because it `was the most controversial part of the Garnaut report', because `debate on this issue has waxed and waned' and because `arguments have become blurred, as longer term structural change has been confused with short-term cyclical movements in the level of unemployment'. What a contribution!

It is ironic that whilst much of the report describes how the economies of North East Asia are adapting to the changing economic patterns of the region, the complementary changes in the Australian economy, which are allegedly taking place, are not analysed at all. DFAT, as is the style of this Government, gives much greater attention to the regulatory impediments in North Asian countries than to our competitive deficiencies. It is always easier to attach blame elsewhere. Analysis of the progress post-Garnaut is left to others. David Chessell of Access Economics analysed the Government's performance in the Independent Monthly and said:

SPEECH.PARA: Two years after the Garnaut report was delivered and therefore two years closer to the year 2000—the target date for most of Garnaut's reforms—we are still not showing enough speed or enterprise in seizing our opportunities in North East Asia.

That is why we feel so frustrated. That is why all Australians should have felt disappointed last night. When John Hewson announced the Fightback package he said that he hoped the Government would pick it up and run with it because it was essential for Australia. It is probably the first time the Opposition has challenged the Government to run with its policies. The Government has picked up a bit, but not much. This is not a government of political courage. There is no Coronation Hill in the statement, no abandoning of its restrictive uranium mining policy, and no GST, which even Mr Keating realises is essential for a real package of reforms. There is just enough, Mr Keating hopes, to build a bit of consumer confidence to get him home at the next election—just enough for him and his cronies to hang on to power.

PARA.TAB: It is not good enough. What Mr Keating does not seem to understand is that the party is over. The Australian public knows how serious the problems are. They know that only radical reform to completely restructure the economy will be good enough. They know that finally they have an alternative government with the vision and courage to chart the necessary course.

The future is in internationalising Australia; to seize the opportunities of the huge and growing markets around us—to thereby solve the problem of the current account and to provide sustainable jobs for so many more Australians. That is what it is to be internationally competitive, which is so necessary. Fightback shows how this can be done. It shows what governments can and must do to contribute to a more competitive Australia. Mr Keating has missed his opportunity. It is a tragedy that so many innocent Australians as a consequence will miss theirs. These Australians at the first opportunity will pass the reins of Government to John Hewson and the coalition, and the Fightback, so desperately needed in this country, will commence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night filled me with hope—words such as `recovery', `long-term prosperity', `social justice' and `jobs'. The Australian Democrats were ready to support such concepts and the moves designed to realise them. But they were words—just words. There was neither substance nor vision behind those words. The Prime Minister's statement completely lacked any coherent vision. It failed to halt the loss of Australian jobs or to stem the closure of Australian businesses. It claimed dishonestly initiatives and projects which are already under way. It introduced as new spending money which in fact was filched from other programs.

PARA.TAB: But if there was no vision in Mr Keating's statement, there was also, and is, no vision in Dr Hewson's reply either. Indeed, the Government and the Opposition are in bed together. But the fruit of their union will be aborted because it is not environmentally sustainable. There is no real vision in this mini-Budget of an Australia 10 to 15 years from now for the sort of society which we should have—whether that society will be fairer, more equitable, better educated, more creative, more caring and with an economic system that our environment can sustain. How will we run our economy in 10 to 15 years? Will the economy still run us, as it does today?

I found in Mr Keating's statement only the apathetic shrug of the shoulders of one who, like his colleague in the Opposition, would sacrifice ordinary Australians to the idol of economic rationalism. In our time the policy of putting ideology before people has been practised primarily in the Kremlin. We know how that ended up.

That is not to say that the Australian Democrats found the Prime Minister's statement without some value. We found some elements very positive. Work on the rail network is good, as far as it goes—which is not very far. Construction of a modern sewage plant in Perth is a step in an environmentally sound direction. The establishment of a group for the commercial exploitation of Australian research in Australia is a step that, as the Prime Minister himself observes, should have been taken years ago when the Xerox photocopier invented in South Australia fell for want of Australian encouragement into foreign hands. One can point to the atomic absorption spectrophotometer and a host of other world class inventions in this country which have followed the Xerox copier.

These are bandaids with which Labor is trying to staunch the haemorrhage from a mortal wound. The patient, the Australian people, the Australian economy, the Australian environment—indeed, the Australian nation—is suffering an iatrogenic disease. As a medical man, I must tell the Senate that the prognosis is dire, for the suggested treatment will continue to exacerbate the illness.

The statement was supposed to be about jobs but, despite some obvious bribery, the One Nation statement does very little for the unemployed or for those Australians living on low incomes. It does not, for instance, even mention Aborigines—the original and most impoverished Australians. An Aboriginal activist telephoned me today and asked how the Prime Minister can talk of one nation without mentioning Aborigines and the jobs that are needed by Aborigines.

What does the Prime Minister mention? He mentions a series of figures, and very unclear ones at that. For instance, do the 800,000 jobs Mr Keating is going to create over four years include the 200,000 jobs in tourism over 10 years? These jobs, as I understand Mr Keating, are dependent on the numbers of tourists tripling in the next 10 years—a factor, to a great extent, outside our control. The figure is a wish rather than a promise.

Once again, the Government has failed to seize the moment and do what is most desperately needed. The statement One Nation confidently predicts that `the economy will turn around', and continues the parroting of the Treasury line that if the Government only stays out of things the economy will recover. Note the symbolism: the economy is not of our making, it is not under our control; people must become the servants of the economy and not the other way round. The problem with this view is that it accepts a high long term level of unemployment.

One Nation predicts unemployment falling to 7.5 per cent in 1995-96. When put against the Fightback figure of 8.2 per cent in 1996, unemployed Australians are surely entitled to ask: where do we fit into either of these so-called grand visions of the future? The fact of the matter is that both the Government's and the Opposition's packages blatantly consign about 700,000 Australian workers to the employment scrap heap.

When it comes to employment, once again both the Keating and Hewson plans for the country are sadly lacking the truly visionary quality that would have enabled ordinary working Australians to have some confidence in their future and the future of their children. The Government's package is especially disappointing in this regard because it had a very real opportunity to shift direction and actively intervene in the economy to create jobs. Instead, we have a mishmash of recycled ideas which cater to the financial markets and fail to target those areas most in need.

We welcome the increase in funds for labour market programs and apprenticeships, but the Government needs to triple its $2 billion investment if it is to make a realistic assault on unemployment. The $6 billion should be invested in infrastructure, job creation schemes and sales tax reductions to reduce inflation and wage demands whilst providing jobs for Australians. That $6 billion is still only 1.5 per cent of GDP. According to experts such as Access Economics director Chris Murphy, $2m will be lucky to cut unemployment by half of one percentage point. This is borne out by the Government's own figures.

To those who criticise our proposal as irresponsible, I say that it is the adoption of free market ideology that has been irresponsible. I remind the Senate that the banking sector, which was deregulated by the Labor Government, is currently carrying $30 billion worth of non-performing loans, which is a huge cost to the economy. I ask the Senate to compare that $6 billion of carefully targeted spending to provide employment with the $30 billion which the Opposition and the Government have supported into a non-performing area of the economy.

The Democrats are greatly disappointed in the Labor Government's continuing refusal to acknowledge the merit of direct job creation programs in times of high unemployment. To state, as One Nation does, that `the Government is not interested in make-work schemes which offer no hope of real employment' indicates the Government's lack of understanding about the range and the nature of potential job creation projects and illustrates its paucity of understanding about the human needs of unemployed people.

The Government proposes to hand out at least $125 tax free in April to every family eligible for family allowance. One can only ask: why? A bribe? Trinkets for the natives? A spot of pork-barrelling? Tokenism of the worst kind? A somewhat bizarre one-off attempt to stimulate the economy? Or simply the biggest by-election campaign in history? It is really Paul Keating saying, `I'm sorry; here's $125 compensation for making your life a misery'. The money will be welcomed by most families, if somewhat cynically.

This payment seems to be the one measure in the package designed to provide an instant kick-start to consumer spending. It comes wrapped up in the guise of a social justice measure, but it fails on both counts. Firstly, the additional $300m is a mere drop in the ocean of consumer spending. Further, many of these families will not use the payment to buy consumer goods. They will, despite the Government's exhortations, use it to pay off their very many debts which have accumulated during the recession—a recession brought on by Mr Keating himself and in some cases due to earning limitations on unemployment beneficiaries and pensioners. If they are able to afford to spend the payment, the risk is that the money will go on imported goods.

If the Government is expecting the payment to stimulate the economy, it should therefore be urging families to use the payment only on the purchase of Australian goods. One way to ensure this would have been for the Government to develop the `100 per cent Aus' labelling scheme. Consumers could then actually make an informed choice about what they were buying, and Paul Keating should now be urging families to spend their one-off payment on 100 per cent Australian production.

Secondly, the payment really demonstrates very clearly this Government's inability to come to grips with the structural problems of poverty. Yes, families are assisted by the payment, but what about those single people or couples without children who are trying to live on low incomes? Where is the help for them? We welcome the increase in family allowance supplement, the boost in funding for welfare agencies and the reduction in rent assistance waiting periods. We have been calling for such measures for some time. The Government has listened with ears closed and eyes shut.

These are somewhat hollow gestures in the context of a package that accepts around 8 per cent unemployment for at least the next four years. With that long term prospect in mind, what does the package do by way of addressing the structural problems of poverty? The short answer is: absolutely nothing. Here was a chance to tackle some of those structural problems. For example, the Government could have increased the amount people on pensions and benefits are permitted to earn before losing their entitlement to payment. It could have reinstated young unemployed people's incomes back to the adult level. It could have reduced or removed all the existing waiting periods for income support, which are currently responsible for so much poverty in this country, particularly amongst families. But the Government has not gone for genuine social justice for the victims of this recession. Instead, it has gone for the easy option, the social justice gimmick, the money, not the structural box.

The Democrats welcome the $720m funding boost to the education and training sectors. We recognise this as a vital link between employment, education and training. But again, $720m is simply not enough. Over 100,000 applicants missed out on TAFE places this year. That is a tragedy both for them and for this nation. The Prime Minister has failed to develop a strategy to overcome this shortfall in future years. Commonwealth estimates of funding requirements for the TAFE sector indicate that between $2 billion and $2.5 billion in recurrent annual expenditure will be needed to meet the education participation goals of the Government by the year 2001. This is especially so if, by the year 2001, 95 per cent of all 19-year-olds are either in the work force or in higher education, as the Finn review recommends and the Democrats strongly hope will occur.

The sum of $720m over the next three years is totally insufficient if the Government is to meet these goals, even if the allocation was clearly explained—which, in Mr Keating's statement, it is not. We urgently require a comprehensive plan that details recurrent and capital expenditure for TAFE over the decade and irons out the existing imbalance in funding arrangements. Equally, we need to know—and the Prime Minister is not telling us—how the Government plans to fund the infrastructure, staffing and capital works programs needed to cope with the increased university enrolment that Labor has been imposing on universities and promises to continue. The record of the Labor Government is not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the MFP?

—I will get to that. As more prolonged participation in higher education increased, government spending on higher education actually decreased. In 1983 it was 1.03 per cent of GDP; in 1992 it is envisaged it will have fallen to 0.92 per cent of GDP. The Democrats believe that Australia can be and must be both a clever and a capable country, but only with a fresh approach to education policies—an approach which is missing from Mr Keating's statement.

PARA.TAB: The threat to the worker does not come only from unemployment or inadequate social security structures. The Government has buried among its sweeping statements of reform a potential threat to the public interest in the preparation of enterprise agreements. Yesterday Senator Bell asked a question of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) regarding the Government's intentions. These intentions are no clearer for Mr Keating's having gestured in their direction. The Labor Government has been promising large scale industrial reform for some time. The Democrats call on it to bring on the legislation so that we can see clearly just what the role of the Industrial Relations Commission is to be and what precise steps the Government will take to see that the public interest is met.

Mr Keating is to spend $1 billion on big projects, especially in the transport sector. We have long advocated this, although we have said that $2 billion in outlays was needed for that expenditure to be effective. Mr Keating has, to the extent of $1 billion, now confirmed our view. Senator Powell has already raised our concerns in this chamber, but because of the importance of this area I shall repeat some of them. This statement has been touted as a major boost to rail transport. An additional $454m will be provided to the National Rail Corporation to standardise and improve the national rail system. At first glance, this level of rail spending looks like a welcome boost to a vital element in our national infrastructure. But it must be remembered that, under Labor, investment in rail has been appallingly low and has been progressively run down.

In his statement, Mr Keating points out that the construction of a national rail highway `should have been done a hundred years ago'. That means it could have been done over the last nine years under a Labor government in which Mr Keating was the chief policy architect. The fact is that $454m over the next two years will compensate—and that is all—for the total neglect of rail by Labor. No evidence has been provided by this Government to demonstrate that the money it proposes to spend will result in a major shift of freight from road to rail. We are told that Melbourne to Sydney rail transit times will be 12 hours, a reduction of 1 1/2 hours. But a modern heavy truck can do the trip in 10 hours and can go direct to the final destination.

I would be fascinated to know whether any cost-benefit studies have been done, predicting such things as the shift of freight and passengers from road to rail, the reduction in road deaths and the reduction in greenhouse gases due to greater fuel efficiency. If not, the Government has simply thrown public money at rail in the absence of a cohesive transport policy. If there are studies, the public and the Parliament deserve to see them.

In summary, the transport initiatives in this statement appear to have been hastily cobbled together in the absence of a clear transport policy framework and without thorough cost-benefit assessments. It is difficult to know how far they will go to meeting the desirable long term objectives. If the Government begs to differ—and no doubt it will—then it needs to put some evidence on the table.

The One Nation package proposes a one-market policy for the airline industry. It remains to be seen whether moves to allow Qantas and the domestic airlines to buy an interest in each other will lead to the increased competition in the marketplace that the Government has promised.

The Democrats congratulate the Prime Minister for adopting the recommendation from the Australian Democrats' platform paper on transport to improve the international facilities at Brisbane and Melbourne airports. Improved facilities under the Democrats' program would help to disperse international activity to airports other than Sydney, thus eliminating the need for a third runway. But we are angry and concerned at the raw deal given to country air services in this package. Further deregulation may well mean greater competition and consumer choice on some main routes, but the Government is abdicating its fiscal responsibility to rural aerodromes and regional and rural users.

The Government proposes to boost industry by accelerated rates of depreciation, changing tax rules and making investment in Australian industry more attractive. The emphasis is on big, durable investments. This is indeed a step in the right direction but, again, it does not go far enough. To regain our economic standing we must become innovative. We lag behind Japan and Germany, which are already innovation driven. It is truly a disaster for Australia that we are locked into a sort of time warp of the early 1900s, when all we had to do was dig it up or chop it down and ship it out. It was so easy. Overseas companies manufactured, created and invented. We simply bought our products from them—and we have not moved very far beyond that mentality.

The Government's package does little to alleviate this. It re-states that exporting raw materials and value-adding to them will continue to play a vital role. Despite the Government's stated belief that `Australia's well-being depends on the country having dynamic and internationally competitive industries', the Government's only contribution towards making Australia a leader in research and technology is to create the Australian Technology Group. But a one-off capital base of $30m to bid for the rights to publicly funded research projects and sell them to business is totally inadequate. We commend the Government for picking up on Australian Democrats' policy, but we believe this funding should have been at least doubled to stimulate R&D promotion.

The Australian Democrats believe in preferential support for projects based on ecologically sustainable development, such as energy efficient products, solar energy and telecommunications. Australia will achieve ESD only by building a more internationally competitive manufacturing sector that adopts international environmental standards to achieve ESD goals.

The decimation of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries would not have happened if tariffs had been maintained during the recession. Thirty thousand people, mainly women, have lost their jobs in TCF industries and they will never regain them—migrant women, older women, women without other skills who will find it extremely difficult to find work in other jobs. Industry is crying out at the very least for a freezing of the planned tariff cuts to help tide it over until better times. Unless this is forthcoming, many industries will collapse beyond resuscitation.

Australia's trade performance is the invisible factor in Mr Keating's statement. The Government is clearly content to rest on the laurels of exporters who have taken our products abroad with little or no help from the Government. Manufacturers, workers and farmers have been left to rot while the Government continues to cut tariffs, which will demolish what is left of the Australian manufacturing industry. Meanwhile, the Government is happy to pin its hopes on the Dunkel recommendations in the GATT round of negotiations—which are clearly destined to fail. A boost for Austrade is welcome news, but it is a woefully inadequate response to the urgent need to protect the remaining jobs in our manufacturing industry.

To rural Australia, the Prime Minister brings a mixed message. There is undoubted advantage to growers of broadacre crops, but it is clear that many wheat growers need assistance to plant this season's crop—they need it now. But One Nation does not make clear which farmers will be eligible for assistance, how much assistance, for how long or in which regions. The action to aid the wool industry is equally imprecise. After last night, woolgrowers will not know whether they will receive a pay out.

Australia's farmers deserve more. They deserve assurance, certainty and encouragement to continue to develop sustainable agricultural practices. The new depreciation schedules may offer farmers the opportunity to invest in silos and other capital items as a hedge against drought, but the Prime Minister is not precise. Again, an opportunity to target and encourage wise farming practices has been ignored.

The projected job growth in the tourism industry is illusory. The economic statement suggests that 200,000 new jobs could be created in the tourism industry over the next decade, yet the overall job projections call for the creation of 800,000 new jobs over the next four years. Can the Government please explain if this projected growth in the tourism industry is included in these overarching job figures, or has the Prime Minister simply `fiddled the sums'?

The Democrats are somewhat more sanguine about the Prime Minister's tax proposals. After all, most of the measures are either reversals of previous erroneous decisions or adaptations of Democrat policy. The major initiative is the new accelerated depreciation regime. The Government has abandoned the level playing field to a point and has skewed the tax system slightly towards productive investment. We have been calling for that for years. The Prime Minister is now claiming that `Australia now has a world competitive depreciation regime'. What he does not tell us is that up until 1988 we had an even more generous depreciation regime than the one announced last night. Mr Keating, as Treasurer, destroyed that regime.

Similarly, the so-called development allowance is basically a less generous, more targeted investment allowance which was originally introduced by Prime Minister Fraser and axed by `Level Playing Field' Keating in 1985. Unfortunately, though, there are two tax decisions that reinforce the impression of the entire document that the Government does not understand ecologically sustainable development. The first is the sales tax reduction for new motor vehicle purchases. It is Democrat policy to tax cars on the basis of their fuel efficiency. The sales tax reduction should apply only to fuel efficient vehicles. This would reduce our consumption of and hence importation of oil and therefore our current account deficit. It would also reduce the smog which recently grounded about 10 per cent of Sydneysiders who suffer from asthma and other respiratory allergy disorders and were therefore advised to remain indoors on two successive particularly smoggy days.

There are other alternatives. It could have taken up a suggestion which has been around for at least two decades and has been taken up by the Industry Commission. For instance, it could have reduced to near zero the fixed costs of car ownership, that is, registration and third party insurance, and replaced these charges with a levy on fuel. Such a strategy would have encouraged car ownership while discouraging car usage for non-essential trips. It would have also cost the Government nothing; it would have been revenue neutral.

Imagine the combination of this Government and the Opposition's proposals—a reduction in sales tax on cars; people buying more cars; a reduction of 18c per litre on fuel under Hewson; a further 15 per cent impost on public transport fares; and a reduction of expenditure on public transport under a Hewson government which would reduce government expenditure. That is a recipe for absolute disaster in the major capital cities such as Melbourne and Sydney. The overriding impression left by this statement is that the Government has completely missed the opportunity to reorient economic policy towards ecologically sustainable development. All Mr Keating is really doing is lending legitimacy to some resource industry plans to exploit protected areas.

In summary, we note that the statement further weakens Commonwealth powers and, although it does not provide any details of arrangements with the States and Territories to protect the environment, there is clearly anticipated a watering down of those powers. Mr Keating's One Nation statement is simply a slick public relations exercise. There is the presentation as new initiatives projects which are already under way. There is expenditure of new money which is actually filched from old programs such as the MFP program taken from the better cities program. There is a danger of foreign takeover in the program. There is a complete lack of awareness of the future; there is no vision. Mr Keating is simply on the wrong track and in most of the statement he has pushed ahead on that wrong track. This program will lead to chaos, to poverty, to misery, to despair, to nowhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make my contribution I would like to acknowledge in the gallery the Chairman of the Queensland Cane Growers Council, Mr Harry Bonanno, and the General Manager, Mr Ian Ballantyne. They are down here fighting for the rights of their sugar industry.
—Survival.

—Their survival. Last night the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) presented to Australia the Government's fourth attempt in the last 12 months to get the economy going again. Australians looked to the Government's economic package for hope—hope that this Labour Government would at long last start to get things right and repair the damage its policies have inflicted on all Australians over the past nine years.

PARA.TAB: What the Government has failed to understand is that there is a real world out there full of suffering Australians—but Australians only too eager to drive in and get their country going again. The Government must recognise and address the real problems. Australians deserve a better deal than they are getting from this Government. Just look around Australia and see the devastation and struggle: farmers crippled by debt, by years of high interest rates imposed by this Government, by a trade and subsidies war that corrupts the markets for their products. While their competitors overproduce because of government protected prices and export subsidies, the world prices our farmers are expected to accept are lowered below the cost of production.

Generations of labour are lost as farms are sold up, employment opportunities are forgone, and our efficient agricultural products are replaced in the domestic market by subsidised imports. Likewise, there are efficient manufacturing industries unable to compete and win contracts against imports. Factory owners are becoming their own factory hands in the fight to save their investments and in today's climate they are seeing their hard earned capital base disappear before their very eyes.

All this leads to one million unemployed with youth unemployment levels at 35.8 per cent. The idea of 800,000 new jobs over the next four years is a flight of fancy. In fact, the $20 billion rise in public debt over the next four years represents a cost to the taxpayer of $40,000 per job. Even on Mr Keating's rosy prediction, the unemployment rate will be 10 per cent in a year's time. It is Mr Keating's rosy vision that concerns me greatly. A growth rate of zero to 4.75 per cent when the rest of the world is in recession—higher than the major OECD countries—is a very rosy and brave prediction. His predictions have not been good in the past.

There was his 1988 Budget Speech prediction that Australia was now well on its way to prosperity. What have we got? His 1989 Budget Speech prediction was that `as a result of the Government's economic policies, Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving'. What a misrepresentation! His record on predictions leaves a lot to be desired. In fact, he does not have one right yet.

We have had droughts and economic downturns before, but this time it is different. The difference this time is that when the massive drought and economic downturn occurred in 1982 and 1983 we had a viable farming and manufacturing industry to fall back on. This time we are fast approaching having nothing.

During 1983-84, agriculture grew at the rate of 45 per cent, and mining at 9.5 per cent. A good viable farming sector was the backbone of the 6 per cent growth after that recession. Real growth in 1983-84 would have been only 2 per cent or 3 per cent had agriculture and mining not recorded good growth. During the last time of drought and recession, the Liberal-National Party Government did not adopt a scorched earth policy like this Government. Its programs made sure that rural industries were not depleted, so that when the economy picked up, they were ready to fire—immediately earning export income, immediately contributing to Australia's economy.

Today, when one-third of all farmers are suffering negative incomes, when farm exports have plunged to a low of $1.4 billion, when 10 per cent of broadacre farmers have experienced two consecutive years of negative cash income, and average farm incomes are only two-thirds of the level of the 1982-83 drought, this Government will regret the neglect and anti-rural policies it has inflicted on rural Australia. As happened in the last recession, the economy cannot get going again without its power house—agriculture—as its impetus.

The real problems attacking rural Australia must be addressed. This Government must not follow the recommendations of the Industry Commission to eliminate the tariffs for the sugar industry and the dairy industry. To cut tariffs without cutting input costs is to destroy the industry that could really lead to our economic recovery.

The US and the EC are continuing to increase their subsidies and lowering world prices. Our farmers have to compete on world markets distorted by annual subsidies of $385 billion. Of this, the EC provides $133 billion; the US, $74 billion; and Japan $59 billion. Just this year, the US Government increased its dairy export incentive scheme fivefold. The effect is to undercut world markets by 60 per cent. The EC also gives dairy subsidies at the level of 69 per cent. It is the same with wheat, with the US selling subsidised wheat into our traditional markets. Only one-third of all wheat production is freely traded in the entire world. Just this month our ally, the US, offered 200,000 tonnes of subsidised wheat to Yemen—our traditional market—on top of the 300,000 tonnes of subsidised wheat it has already sold there, taking over half of our market.

It is the same with sugar where a 57 per cent subsidy is provided by the EC. The sugar industry is presently feeling the effects of major droughts and low world prices. It has to accept the corrupted world price of 8c a pound while its competitors in the US receive a guaranteed domestic price of 23c a pound and 15c a pound in Thailand. The sugar industry, for example, has a goal to increase production to five million tonnes by the turn of the century. It is an industry capable of lifting our much needed export earnings, but when it is the sugar producer most exposed to world prices and has just lost $350m from drought and corrupt world prices now is not the time to remove the small tariff levels.

However, the real attitude of the Government to Australia's farmers is seen by the $51m payment to the textile, footwear and clothing industry to assist adjustment, compared with the assistance given to farmers. Besides this, the rural sector is to receive only $10.8m next year and $6m for part B of the rural adjustment scheme for 75 interest subsidies to enable grain growers to plant crops—and cane growers too, I might add. This is a totally inadequate response.

With 10 per cent of all broad acre farms with two consecutive years of negative cash income and our wheat crop down to 9.5 million tonnes, the industry called for underwriting for one season to give confidence to growers to plant a crop and to lenders to finance a crop. This has been totally rejected by the Government. A GMP could definitely provide a major turnaround for the national economy—surely it is just the type of scheme we should be considering. With current prices at a high of $180, government exposure would be minimal, but it would provide that boost, that confidence, to get Australian wheat farmers planting again.

Since the US export enhancement program was introduced, Australian plantings have reduced by 40 per cent from 15 million tonnes to 9.5 million tonnes. Who knows how the EEP subsidy will increase under pressure from the US presidential election later this year to further distort world prices on sugar and wheat.

A GMP would have ensured an immediate increase in plantings of 20 per cent. Twenty five per cent of Australian wheat farmers need assistance. This new scheme will help 10 per cent of them, leaving 15 per cent still in need. The sugar industry and Mr Bonanno will have to get in the queue. There are 7,000 wasted farmers who could be investing, employing and earning. At the moment, we are struggling to meet our long term contracts of 13 million tonnes. The buyers are there. With a GMP we would have a strong wheat industry underlying a real economic revival.

Plantings have to take place by early March in Queensland—two weeks away—and by late March in the southern States. But already, one day after the announcement, there are indications that the scheme will run into problems. To qualify for part B there have to be short term money problems. But for a bank to lend, a farmer has to be able to service the debt and repay the capital. When a farmer is eligible for part B, he is in a difficult position to get approval for a bank loan. An interest subsidy will not help when farmers are in desperate need of credit. Banks will need security before they will lend, plus a guaranteed ability for the farmer to pay back the debt. Already these farmers on part B are being assisted with interest payments to make them viable. The Government has to address this problem urgently—not just flick past it and leave it for State rural adjustment authorities to work out.

There is also the problem of how the scheme will get up and running in time for planting next month. It is of the utmost importance to achieve a decent wheat crop. I ask the Minister to give an assurance to the industry that the scheme will be fully operational so that no eligible farmer will miss out on planting times because of paperwork requirements. RAS is being used by the Government as its too hard basket for rural Australia. It is now a social welfare department, a financing organisation. It is now being asked to make assessments as to who will be picked out of the barrel for crop assistance.

As the scheme now stands, any farmer in part A cannot be considered for the new scheme; any farmer who is viable will not be considered; any farmer in part C will not be considered; and any farmers seeking Jobsearch will not be considered. This assistance package must not be allowed to miss the mark as the Jobsearch proposal has. It is shaping up just like that fiasco. The Jobsearch scheme announced last December was aimed at 2,000 farmers. In fact, many senators here tonight will remember Senator Richardson's statement. I ask the Democrats whether they remember that he told the Senate that he wanted it passed immediately so that the farmers would have it available `next Monday'. Do they remember that? Yet, since 1 December only 116 certificates for farmers' Jobsearch have been issued—116 is nowhere near the 2,000 farmers the Jobsearch allowance scheme was targeted at and they certainly did not get it the next Monday. Hopefully, farmers will have easier access to the one-off crop planting program.
By contrast, the coalition policy is to provide 95 per cent underwriting. The coalition is prepared to stand by the wheat industry and the contribution it could make to economic recovery.

The economic statement also announced changes to allow the wool stockpile debt to be repaid on a cumulative schedule rather than the fixed annual debt reduced target. At long last, the Government has answered the industry's plea to be allowed to manage its funds more effectively and reduce market speculation.

The excesses of the stockpile earnings should be able to go back to benefit the industry now, when it needs it, by reducing the level of the 12 per cent tax and relieving the tax burdens on woolgrowers. All this puts more money into struggling rural economies. Farmers' payments provide great stimulus to rural towns.

The effect of our farm machine industry and other suppliers is at a critical level. Capital expenditure on new plant, machinery, buildings and infrastructure declined by 35 per cent in 1990-91 and is forecast to fall a further 8 per cent next year. The latest Outlook conference was told that Australia's agricultural implement manufacturing base has continued to shrink to the extent that in future machinery designed for unique Australian conditions may no longer be available. This is the state we are in. Our farms, our manufacturers are disappearing forever. When the recession does end, when the upturn does come, there will be very few industries left on which to base a recovery.

Despite Mr Keating's plan, the only way to help the economy in a long term and sustained way is to boost export industries and import replacement industries. Yet a report from a New South Wales manufacturing survey yesterday revealed that one in eight New South Wales manufacturers were contemplating moving offshore, and one in 20 large New South Wales manufacturers had in fact moved offshore in the past two years. That is repeated in every other State.

There is something vitally wrong with Australia when, to survive, the only course available to its industries is to go offshore. The Government's trade policy leaves battered and bruised Australian industries with only one defence: anti-dumping. Yet take any recent anti-dumping case example—subsidised dumped tomatoes, peaches and pears, dumped peanuts: an action takes at least a year and sometimes longer. The whole process takes 195 days or 11 months to reach a decision, with the cost of a case averaging around $170,000 and able to go a lot higher.

Imports are at such a high level that some canneries will not process one Australian tomato this year, and peach and pear processing will be reduced by 30 per cent. Our anti-dumping system is still not adequate. It must be quicker. It must have the strength to defer importers who are thumbing their noses at our system. Some industries are just too small to launch anti-dumping cases. The small navy bean industry of Queensland knows that baked beans are being dumped. In the pig meat industry, which has seen its market lost to highly subsidised Canadian imports, almost two million kilograms of Canadian pig meat have flooded our domestic market over the last year.

If anti-dumping is the only defence against subsidised imports, then surely these smaller industries must have financial assistance to launch their cases or else be wiped out. As long as Australian industries do not operate on a level playing field because of highly subsidised competition or high costs, our anti-dumping laws must work.

Mr Keating may have broken the back of inflation, but in doing so he has broken the hearts of millions of Australians. Everyone wants Australian industries to reach international competitiveness, but to keep on increasing costs on employees is not the way to go. We are told by Mr Keating not to worry about wage increases, that he has reached a deal with the unions, that their claims will not increase past the inflation rate. But the increase in costs since the accord was introduced in 1983 for extras such as the training guarantee levy, structural efficiency levy, classification creep, shorter hours equalling 5 per cent—that is, a 38-hour week—has seen at least a 25 per cent increase in wages from 1983 to 1987, and they have increased considerably more since then.

This package confirms that the Government is going ahead with legislated superannuation for small business—all extra costs that industries cannot afford to bear and beyond the capacity for them to pay.

Our quest for internationalisation must be seen from the angle of what it costs to employ labour in countries with comparable living standards. In Japan, an employee works 2,000 hours a year; in Australia, it is 1,700 or less. Japanese employees have no holiday leave loading whereas Australian employees have a 17 1/2 per cent loading. Japanese employees have no rostered days off whereas Australian employees enjoy them to the extent that our manufacturing industry is reaching the point where rostered days off amount to an extra 12 long weekends a year when those employers do not have access to their staff. In Australia it costs an employer 75c a minute to employ a worker. In New Zealand, just a short trip across the Tasman, an employee costs only 55c a minute, with New Zealand industry having a 40c exchange rate advantage on us.

The point has been reached in Australian industry where, with the increased cost of a 38-hour week, rostered days off every month, superannuation and training levy and increases in wages by accords and other adjustments, a 17 1/2 per cent loading, long service and sick leave, Australia has priced itself out of the market. The Government's policies have increased costs to Australian manufacturers, miners and farmers. While this Prime Minister and the previous Prime Minister have said that we must become internationally competitive, they have at the same time put these extra cost burdens on Australian farmers and manufacturers. They have undermined industry by increasing costs and then pulling the rug right out from underneath them by removing tariffs.

The Government wants it both ways. It wants its cake, it wants to eat its cake, and it even wants a picture on the wall of the cake. If the Government believes we can be internationally competitive by increasing costs, reducing working hours, adding training and superannuation levies to Australian business, farmers and miners, then it has only to see the results: the kids who cannot get jobs; the increased bankruptcies from collapsed businesses; the farmers who have been forced off their farms; and the unemployed searching for jobs which have been exported overseas to disappear forever. This is the living proof of this Government's failure.

This recession which our present Prime Minister said we had to have has seen dreams dashed and equity built up over generations destroyed and gone forever. This package will not fool the people out there who know what life is like outside the thick walls of this parliamentary building. This package is a political package for the survival of Mr Keating and his Government. It may have jogged the memory of the Government, but it will not fool the people who remember that rail spending on the election of the Hawke Government, plunging from $65m to $11m and reaching nothing for the years 1988 till yesterday. In fact, Mr Keating in September 1990 said:

SPEECH.PARA: People here believe they can have brand new roads, buildings, brand new everything—well—they can't.

This package is merely a $2.3 billion unfunded desperation bid for power. The electorate has lost total confidence in the Government. The greatest contribution this Government could give to the Australian people is an election as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very good for Australian politics, and perhaps the Australian people are being better served than they have been in recent years, that there are now before the Australian people two major economic packages—alternative plans for the future of Australia; alternative views about the way the country should best develop economically; alternative views about economic, social and, to some extent, cultural values and policies. I think that is for the good; that is the way Australian politics should be conducted at that level of debate.

PARA.TAB: That those two packages are now before the people 12 months before the next election is a plus. It is a plus because it gives to the Australian people the opportunity to compare and contrast, to make over the period an informed judgment about their preferences. That is the way the democratic system should work. It is why we have the Westminster system, which requires political parties aspiring to government to put forward economic programs that cover the broad spectrum of policy issues and makes informed judgment possible.

But this process is not helped when we find people endeavouring to make wildly exaggerated criticisms of economic packages. I have not wasted a lot of my time, which could otherwise have been better spent in watching the cricket—and I regret to say that England will win—but I did spend a minute or two watching Dr Hewson's response to the economic package. He said that no credible spokesperson has had a favourable interpretation of the Keating economic package. That could mean only that the definition of `credible' is people who agree with Dr Hewson.

I went to my office and picked up the first two documents in front of me. Disregarding the Labor Party and, just to make people here happy, disregarding all the trade union people who came out and supported the package, and of course there are many of those, I decided I would look at the comments of a few international and Australian commentators, none of whom, as far as I know, are card-carrying members of the Labor Party and all of whom can be properly defined as credible. We have on the AAP wire from Washington:

SPEECH.PARA: US financial analysts today welcomed Prime Minister Paul Keating's recovery plan as the right short-term medicine for Australia's ailing economy.
The economist David Hale, of Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, who I think is broadly accepted as one of the better international analysts of the Australian economy, said amongst other things:
—the supply side spending on infrastructure and things designed to enhance export competitiveness is the correct policy for a country still in a severe recession.

So that we do not fall for the trap of thinking that what is happening in Australia is something rare and unique that other responsible governments would not be doing, he went on to say that the package is `consistent with recent policy developments in the US and Europe', which is correct. Merrill Lynch's analyst, Douglas Johnson, said:
. . . the statement should help to break the psychology of the recession by providing a boost to business and consumer confidence.

He said that the recovery package was a plus for the equity market. I suppose Dr Hewson might not think that Merrill Lynch and Kemper Financial Services in the United States are credible economic spokespersons. I do not know what he thinks about John Elliott, but the Dateline News Digest quotes former Liberal Party President John Elliott backing Prime Minister Paul Keating's economic statement. It quotes the ANZ chief, Will Bailey, as saying:
The stimulus to the economy announced in the Government's economic statement last night was a sound move.
It quotes the BHP Managing Director, John Prescott, as saying:
Industry would be encouraged to invest by measures announced in the Government's economic statement.

I suppose none of those constitute credible economic commentators because they do not agree with Dr Hewson. But by any objective measure it is a very comprehensive range of endorsements, and there are plenty more, as people would know.

PARA.TAB: Why do we have this comparison and contrast? It is because, now that the alternative package has been brought down, it is becoming clear, and the opinion polls have made it clear since the discussion about it has emerged, that the fascination with the Fightback package is receding. It used to be the only show in town and it was therefore getting some support because the Australian people said, `We might not like it but it is the only proposal about'. That is no longer the case, and they are starting to wake up to it. That is why the opinion polls show that support for Dr Hewson has been falling rapidly since the middle of January.

The Australian people understand. They have a long time to make a final judgment, but it is very dangerous to underestimate them. They understand some of the key criteria. So let us have a look at the comparisons between these two documents—just a preliminary one, because there is a long time to go. There is a year's worth of analysis to go. We will have this debate another 364 times, I suspect, between now and then.

Let us have a look at the jobs proposal. It is very easy to see where the jobs will come from in the One Nation package. One does not need any smoke and mirrors. One does not need a big distortion to put in an economic analysis saying, `If you had this program it would create two million jobs. Put it in your package and hope that people will not notice that the package that is being analysed is not the Fightback package. The big job scenario is based on some different package. It does not even include the goods and services tax'.When one looks at the Fightback package one asks where the jobs are. I can see where lots of people will get sacked. I can see where lots of jobs will disappear. I cannot see where any jobs will be created. As Ralph Willis, the Minister for Finance, said in the House of Representatives tonight, it is an incredible hoax.

There are 800,000 jobs on offer over four years. We would be delighted to be able to say there will be more. One would like to be able to say that the rate of economic growth could be higher and that therefore unemployment would fall more quickly. But it is an achievable, responsible goal against the Fightback package, which claims, with some smoke and mirrors, that with a bit of luck a lot of jobs will be created. In the middle of a recession, what it is proposing is to tighten fiscal policy by between $1.7 billion and $3 billion in the first year. First year high school economics would tell us that doing that in the middle of a recession would lose a lot of people their jobs, and there are a whole lot of other proposals in the package to sack people. So on the jobs front the alternative is very stark.

On the tax front, it is as stark as it can be because of the goods and services tax—the ideologically driven commitment to change the tax mix from income to consumption. There is a lot of sophisticated capacity to analyse the implications of the tax policy, but just look at it by this one criterion: if people consume 100 per cent or more of their income—and many people are forced to consume more than 100 per cent—they pay the GST on the whole 100 per cent of that income. If other people are wealthy enough not to have to spend all their income, if they can save 20 per cent, 30 per cent, 40 per cent, they have to pay the GST only on what they spend and they get tax cuts to help them enjoy the fruits of their higher income. They also get bigger tax cuts than the people down the bottom, who pay the GST on every cent they spend.

The GST is a very indiscriminate tax. It taxes the necessities. It taxes the food and clothing. It taxes the necessities at the same rate as the luxuries. In a comparison between the two documents, we should look at the priorities. The cars that will be more expensive if the GST comes in are the cars that ordinary Australians buy—the Holden Commodores, the little Barinas, all those sorts of things. But the Ferraris, the Maseratis and the Rolls Royces will be cheaper and the people who buy them will have the biggest tax cuts to pay for them.

The GST is an indiscriminate and unfair tax. The money will not be used to fund the tax cuts to the poor to compensate them. That will be funded by expenditure cuts, the significance of which I will come to in a moment. The alternative package, the One Nation package, is able to deliver the 30c rate to Australian workers without the strings of a 15 per cent GST.

That points up one of the other areas of contrast. We have a big contrast in jobs. We have a big contrast in tax. There is a big contrast in prices and inflation. The One Nation package is able to supply growth with low inflation, particularly because of wages policy, and I will come to that in a moment, but also because it does not give that massive one-off surge to prices that the GST does. All the modellers, even the supporters of the GST, are saying that if one does not have a wages policy one cannot get that one-off surge out of the system. It is possible in the economic textbook for it to be a one-off surge, but only if one can get a wages policy to get it out of the system, and there is no wages policy in this statement.

The fourth area of major contrast is in wages policy. There is absolutely no wages policy. What does that mean? Combine that with the GST, and it means one gets the surge in inflation. There is no way of getting it out of the system and no fiscal policy capacity to do it because the Opposition has its fiscal policy locked in. The only vehicle the Opposition has left is higher interest rates, and that means interest rates will go up. The economy, already tightened by $1.7 billion to $3 billion worth of cuts in expenditure, will tighten even further as we get the impact of the higher interest rates trying to squeeze the inflation out of the system.

We then get the emotional argument—whoever wrote Senator Boswell's speech was making the same point—that this is somehow terrible because it is what is called an unfunded increase and because in 1992-93 we will have a projected 1.9 per cent of GDP as a deficit. I will come back to that in a moment. Australian public sector debt is very low. It is very easy to play the distorting game and say that Australia has a massive debt. Australia's public sector debt is one of the lowest in the OECD. It remains very low and modest even under this package.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about its foreign debt?
—There is a lot of private sector debt. I wish John Stone were still here so that he could explain to Senator Short the significant difference.
—The difference is absolutely irrelevant and you know it.
—I wish John Stone were here to explain it to Senator Short. Why does not Senator Short go back and get some lessons from him.
—He told you exactly the same thing.

—No, he did not; he understood the difference. If Senator Short wants to talk about overseas debt, I suggest to him not to bother going to former Senator Stone, who used to make some very sensible comments about this. I did not agree with the conclusions he came to because we started from different philosophical assumptions. But at least he understood his policy and logically pursued it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short should read the speech of the Minister for Finance. Mr Willis pointed out that even under the worst predictions—which I think were absolutely wrong—that Dr Hewson made tonight in the House of Representatives about what would happen to overseas debt under our package, the position is not as bad as the scenarios of what will happen under the Opposition's Fightback package. I think the Opposition is exaggerating what will happen under ours. But even at the most pessimistic, that is not as bad as the overseas debt predictions in the Opposition's package.

I want to talk mainly about public sector debt because that is what this debate is about. How will this be funded? It will be funded in the same way as other deficits that Australian governments have run up in 26 of the last 30 years were funded. It may have escaped the notice of Senator Short and his colleagues that only one government in Australian history has ever delivered a surplus and that was this Labor Government. There was a surplus for four years. In every other year there was a deficit and we funded it.

The projection for the five years from 1991-92 to 1995-96 is for an average deficit of 0.88 of one per cent of GDP. I can compare that average. The highest projection is for 1992-93. I think it is a pretty accurate projection; it is not far out. The projection is that it might be 1.9 per cent of GDP. Even that is less than the deficit as a percentage of GDP in 15 of the last 40 years in Australian history. It is less than it was in five of the eight years of the Fraser Government in which the deficit as a percentage of GDP averaged 2.5 per cent.

How was that funded? It was funded in the same way that every country around the world funds deficits in a recession. It is approximately the average deficit as a percentage of GDP of the 30 years before 1983. The average would be even less if one took the Labor Government's record of running some surpluses into it. But the average of the 30 years before the Labor Government came into power is approximately what is projected for the next five years. So let us not get in a panic about how we will fund this very modest deficit.

I am sorry that Senator Short has left—I do not want to speak about him while he is not here. I only want to refer to a question he put today. He asked, `Will not this borrowing to fund the deficit push up interest rates?'. Does anybody seriously think that the problem in the Australian economy is an excess of demand for money; that there are too many people out there wanting to borrow to invest; that there is too much demand? I really do not think that is the problem we are confronting.

Nor is there an excess of demand for other resources. I wish there were an excess of demand for labour; it would be great. We would not have the One Nation package then. What we would be doing probably would be inflationary. That is why we did not do it when there was an excess of demand. That is why in the good years we cut back. We went into surplus so that when the difficult times came we had the capacity to spend and still remain within the normal standard parameters of the fiscal policies pursued by Australian governments over the last 30 years.

Great concern has been expressed that we are going to spend all this money on roads and railways. Nobody says that that is a bad thing; they are just worried about whether we should be doing it now and so quickly. There will never be a better time to invest in road and rail than now. We will never get the construction projects undertaken more cheaply than now because the resources that are required to carry out those constructions are available.

Idle resources will be put to use. There are contractors out there with machinery just waiting to start. We are not out there competing with a busy private sector. If we do not do it this year or next year, when will we do it—in 1994-95 or 1995-96 when the economy has picked up and those resources are already fully utilised? Then we would be putting too much demand on the system; it then would be inflationary. When tenders were called, we would find that the tenders would be a lot higher. People would not be out there saying, `I will put in low tender to get the work'; they would be saying, `I am working flat out now. I will only do this job if I get an extra margin'.

Any sensible investor, public or private, who has the cash to undertake an investment now or who has the capacity to borrow now, invest cheaply and efficiently at the bottom of a recession and get the benefits when the pick-up comes, would do so. I should add to that the fact that this discharges the macro-economic responsibility of any responsible government. Put aside the very reasonable social concerns that this will provide jobs for people. Just talk about it as the macro-economic responsibility of a government to say, `In a recession it is our responsibility to try to maximise the level of growth to get the economy back on a growth path, to give it a stimulus'. That is what every country around the world is doing except those few dominated by the sterile accounting and ideological fixation that also dogs this Opposition at the moment. The United Kingdom and Canada, which have conservative governments, are in even worse recessions than Australia.

Although there is, entirely appropriately, a major public sector stimulus at this time, the principal stimulus in this economy is with the private sector through a broad range of measures. The private sector has said in the quotes that I have just read, `We will get the economy going, we will encourage investment and we will create jobs'. The depreciation changes will create jobs. They will get new equipment into Australian factories so that we can be more efficient and more competitive and get our manufactured exports growing even more quickly.

There will be special increased assistance for tourism. That industry, which has been growing so effectively, needs another spurt of growth so that new projects can come on stream. Members of the Australian Tourist Industry Association told me that the change they most wanted was that the write-off rate for tourist buildings should be increased from 2 1/2 per cent to 4 per cent. That is exactly what is in this package. That is exactly what will encourage the investment in those tourism projects that can create hundreds of thousands of jobs and position us to meet the requirements of the growing number of tourists that we much need to come here.

I strongly support the changes that are being made in respect of offshore banking units. Between now and 1997 offshore banking units will be leaving Hong Kong and looking for somewhere to invest and create jobs. We are now saying, `Come to Australia; we want you to create jobs here'.

I can remember when Neville Wran first proposed this. People were surprised because it sounds like something that creates jobs for only an elite few—perhaps for an elite few who come in from overseas. But when one thinks about it, those offshore banking units will take up office space in Sydney, Melbourne or whichever city they base themselves. There will be support workers, cleaners, couriers, drivers—all the support jobs that Australians need as well as the high quality professional jobs in the banking industry itself.

The major tax change, which has been so welcomed by the motor industry, will not only create jobs and investment but also will result in cheaper passenger motor vehicles for Australians—cheaper cars that will become more expensive if the Opposition gains government. The only cars that will become cheaper under the coalition will be luxury cars.

There are special tax benefits for small businesses. We will not bog them down in the red tape of the GST; we will say, `You get 50 per cent of your goodwill on the sale of a business as an offset and we will defer the next income tax instalment to assist you'. Special pooled development funds will provide equity capital for small business and enhanced programs which will provide export assistance. They are the key elements. When he was a committee chairman, David Beddall was told by representatives from small business that this is what they wanted to maximise the potential for small business to contribute to the Australian economy.

We have the incentives for the banks—and the other reforms to the financial sector which I do not have time to talk about—to encourage them not to foreclose on businesses but to keep viable businesses running. Already I can see examples of where this might be of particular benefit—to ailing but long term beneficial businesses here in Canberra, and it will be the same all around Australia.

Probably the most significant private sector incentive in terms of a major change that could, if it were successful, drive major investment and create many jobs is what I call the development bonds, the bonds to encourage the private sector to invest in infrastructure: in land transport, ports and electricity. These will be very important. They have the potential to be very important. There is still a need finally to deliver on that. One cannot claim in advance that something is going to be fantastic, but this incentive has the potential to make a significant improvement. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating, but I remain optimistic and, of course, there is the very significant new development allowance.

So we have the public sector stimulus and the private sector stimulus. We can see in the One Nation package the tangible evidence of where the jobs are going to come from, against the alternative, which is a wish list and smoke and mirrors. The only thing which the Fightback package says in concrete terms about jobs is who will be sacked. It does not say anything about who will be employed. It just puts in a misleading document which purports to be a measurement of Fightback but which actually measures something quite different.

There are more things I would like to talk about, but let me refer to only two in the time available—two significant contrasts between these packages. The first relates to the environmental irresponsibility of the Fightback package. I did not hear much of Senator Coulter's contribution, as with Dr Hewson; I thought that I owed it to Australia to watch the cricket. But I did spend enough time listening to pick up the fact that he was expressing serious concern about some of the environmental elements of Fightback—the environmental consequences of the grubby little populist trick of cutting the price of petrol.
