I do not know how any representative of New South Wales, having seen the report about the pollution problems in Sydney which the Greiner Government tried so hard to suppress—I suppose to serve the interests of Dr Hewson—could seriously propose such a policy. I am a critic of many things with Mr Greiner, but to his great credit he had the nerve to deliver some things that needed to be done. He put a levy on petrol. He did not do it for environmental reasons, but it actually was not a bad policy. He might have come to it back to front, he might not exactly have done with the money what I would have done, but at least he had the nerve to do the right thing.

This grubby bit of populism, this sell-out to the National Party, is environmentally grossly irresponsible. That is the starkest example of a leap back to the policy of the 1950s, the mentality that in some way or other we might buy some votes, that it worked for Bob Menzies in 1949 so we might give it another go. The spirit of Bob Menzies is stalking. It is not only his foreign policy and his policy towards Britain that the coalition is talking about; it now wants his petrol policy as well.

The coalition will also be putting up the price of solar panels and recycled paper—those areas where the wholesale sales tax has the capacity to discriminate environmentally. The coalition's broad-based, broad-axed tax will make environmentally responsible purchases less competitive. For those and a variety of other reasons it is an environmentally irresponsible package.

The other point that has been significantly underestimated about the contrast between the Fightback package and the One Nation package is the social justice consequences of the massive expenditure cuts that are there to fund the tax cuts. The GST is frittered away on things like the cheap grab on the petrol prices. The coalition funds the tax cuts by massive expenditure cuts and tries to pretend that it is concerned about the poor, the underprivileged and those in need, when everybody has always known that the most significant redistributive function of government is not how it raises its money but how it spends its money.

At last it has been proved. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has brought out data about the social consequences of government spending. On page five of the Australian Financial Review of 21 February this year Tim Dodd, analysing the ABS data, said:
The household expenditure survey is relatively new and has its limitations—

SPEECH.PARA: which is true—

but the fact that the value of indirect benefits to households, such as schools and hospitals, outweighs the value of direct benefits through welfare payments draws attention to a deficiency in the Federal Opposition's Fightback package, which has not taken into account the loss of indirect benefits to households which will follow from the government spending cuts it outlines.

No wonder the Sydney Morning Herald was running that cartoon depicting the Fightback package with the hole in it. People are starting to see through it. The Opposition has had to withdraw the superannuation proposals because they did not work. The tourist industry is asking the Opposition to change the proposed laws as they relate to tourism because they will destroy that industry—the Opposition knows it, Mr Jull knows it and, in his private moments, he concedes it. The Opposition will have to revisit that. The people are starting to analyse it.

PARA.TAB: The last thing I want to comment on is the very interesting situation that makes two points about what is going on in the politics of New South Wales at the moment, about what happens when the people get a close look at the Liberal alternative. New South Wales is the one State where there has been a Liberal government, the one State from which both Mr Keating and Dr Hewson come, where the people know the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition best—their home State. People have seen a Liberal government in action. They have seen the contrast between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. That is the one State where the Labor Party is leading in the polls, and I am not surprised.

The One Nation package is a fairer package. The One Nation package is the one that has proper regard for the requirements of Australia's future, for the future country we leave to our children, economically, environmentally, socially and culturally. That is why over the next 12 months of debate we all should welcome the fact that these two comprehensive packages are before us. That is why I am confident that the Australian people will choose the One Nation package when they are given the chance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan has once again tried to put a brave face on what is an extraordinarily difficult situation for him, because he is going in to bat for something which has been seen already, and which will continue to be seen, as a fundamentally flawed package. Where he is right is when he says that the battlelines have been drawn. There now is a very clear distinction and stark choice facing the Australian electorate. We look forward to putting that to the test whenever the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has the courage to call a by-election in Wills. As John Hewson said tonight in the other place, we would delight in having that by-election turned into a general election.

PARA.TAB: If the Government is as confident as Senator McMullan says it is about the great success and the great virtues of this package, this `One Nation' or, as John Hewson says, this one broke nation as a result of it, then why does the Government not put it to the test and have a general election as soon as possible? It has the chance coming up with Wills in the next few weeks.
Yesterday, in a very interesting article in the Australian Financial Review, Peter Robinson said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to recall a Prime Minister who has so totally made himself a hostage to one policy document as Paul Keating has to the economic statement he is issuing today.
He went on to say:
Mr Keating has chosen to present his statement as `make or break'.

That is certainly what he has done. The bottom line is that he has gone for broke, and in the course of it he has sounded the death knell for himself and for his Government. As was said by my leader, Dr Hewson, Mr Keating had the chance last night but blew it totally.

PARA.TAB: The document has very little to do with economics, it has very little to do with the well-being of this country and it has nothing to do with a more secure future for those 1.5 million Australians who are already either out of work or under-employed, and for those many other millions of Australians who have suffered declines in their living standards as a result of this Government's policies. It is not an economic document. It is, as Michelle Grattan said today, `An unashamedly political pitch for votes'.

Today the statement has received a mixed bag of responses in the media and elsewhere, but what comes through the comments that have been made is an overwhelming concern for the underlying structure of what the Government has put forward. The Canberra Times says, `Keating spends and hopes'. Another referred to it as, `One nation—a big gamble'. Geoffrey Barker in the Age today calls it, `The triumph of survival politics'. That is what this is all about. It is petty, vote-buying, a spending binge, an attempt to salvage a dying government document. It is spend now, pay later, damn the consequences for this nation a few years down the track. So it goes on in most of the comments made in today's media.
Let me quote Terry McCrann, a quote that will come back to haunt—

TALK.START.PARA: —Terry McCrann.

—No, it will not come back to haunt Terry McCrann. It will come back to wake up Senator McMullan in the middle of the night and his party before too long. It shows the shear unbelievability of the parameters that the Government has put in to underpin its spending and revenue figures. As Terry McCrann said today in an article headed `On the first day PM creates havoc':

SPEECH.PARA: If you believed just half of what was said last night, Moses would have to stand aside in utter embarrassment for our Paul to lead us to the promised land.

That is a pretty good description of the unbelievability of the proposals that have been put before us. This statement will stand or fall on whether it has any more credibility than the credibility that the new Prime Minister has. He was Treasurer for eight years, the architect and implementer of the greatest recession we have seen in 60 years. This was the Treasurer who boasted that he pulled the levers of economic policy. Well, he sure pulled them and with them pulled 1.5 million Australians out of work or caused them to be under-employed, and he pulled millions of others into a recession that he deliberately engineered.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has no credibility at all. Last night's statement suffers the same fate as its author, the Prime Minister. It has no credibility either. Australians should never forget the track record of Prime Minister Keating when he was Treasurer and the number of times he misled the Australian community with statements which were obviously at variance with the facts and with the real economic situation.

The literature is replete with them. One would not want to waste the time of the Senate by going through them all, but some need repeating and repeating and repeating. There is an attempt going on by the Government and the Prime Minister to rewrite the economic history of the past eight years. The Opposition will never allow this Prime Minister and his Government to get away with it. Just four days before he made his first attempt at the political assassination of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, at the end of May 1991, the former Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The economy is now moving into the recovery phase of the cycle.
He said that a few months after he had also said:

The worst is now behind us. The Government established the strategy to deal with the current account deficit and inflation and has stuck to it and is succeeding. . . We are, I think, starting to recover and the prospects for growth are promising and we will see in time whether we think we can say then at some time point hence that we are out of the recession—
Whatever that meant. In August 1990, just before the peak of the recession started to hit, Mr Keating said in his Budget Speech:
This year inflation will fall further—
Well, he was right on that. He continued:

. . . the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up. In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

I wonder what the 300,000 Australians who lost their jobs in the following 12 months thought about that. I wonder what the many thousands more Australians who suffered hardships in so many other ways felt about it. I wonder what they thought when at the same time in that Budget Speech Mr Keating said:
These are definitely the golden years of change. Of course they are the golden years of change.

They were certainly years of change but they were years of very cruel disaster for most Australians. The Prime Minister has a fundamental credibility problem which extends par excellence into the One Nation document that he presented last night.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say that there are not some good points in the document, because certainly there are. The coalition has welcomed the accelerated depreciation provisions, or at least the principle of them. We have welcomed the opening of the aviation market and the development of the aviation policy. We have welcomed the one-stop development approvals. We have welcomed the national power grid. We have welcomed the changes to capital gains tax. All those are announcements that the Prime Minister has taken straight out of the policies of the coalition's Fightback proposals.

There are some other aspects of last night's statement that I certainly welcome as well. Again they reflect in important measure the spirit and content of the coalition's Fightback proposals. The proposals relating to foreign banks are to be welcomed; the relaxation in the foreign investment rules are also to be welcomed. There are some good points in the statement. But they are, if anything, at the edges of the core of the statement. It is when one looks at the core of the statement that one finds its basic problems, faults and deficiencies.

The essence of the problem with last night's statement is that the Government has gone on a very major spending binge, particularly in the area of infrastructure spending, without taking one offsetting decision which would enable the increased spending to be funded. As a result we shall face, according to the Government's figures, a situation where over the next four years, including 1991-92, we shall see a cumulative Budget deficit of $20 billion.

I asked Senator Button at Question Time today how that $20 billion would be funded. Senator Button was unable to answer that question. He did not know, for example, that there is not one word or line in last night's statement to explain how it would be funded. Senator Button did not explain it. Senator McMullan did not explain it adequately tonight. The only way it can be funded is by government borrowing, either overseas or domestically or a combination of both, or by going to the Reserve Bank of Australia and cranking up the printing presses.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a very small percentage of GDP. The average for the deficit over those years is less than one per cent of GDP. It is less than the average of the last 30 years and less than the average of the Fraser Government. You know that is true. Stop misleading people.

—That is where we come to some very interesting points. I will deal with two of those points. Firstly, in actual volume terms, it is a huge amount of money. The Government will have to raise that money on the domestic or overseas markets. Presumably, it will aim mainly to raise it on the domestic market because of its rightful concern about an even bigger blowing out of the foreign debt than will occur anyway. I will come back to that later. However, assuming that the Government aims basically to raise it on the domestic markets, that loan raising and drawing on the national savings will occur at a time when, assuming there is a recovery in the economy, as there will be at some stage—all economies recover; even the Australian economy will recover, at least in part, from the bludgeoning that this Government has subjected it to in recent years—the private sector as well will be seeking funds as part of the recovery process.

PARA.TAB: What the Government seems to have completely overlooked is that already there is a very significant stimulus moving through the economy as a result of the interest rate cuts of the last year or so. Because of the lagged effects, those cuts have still to make an impact. Also, there has already been an enormous stimulus given through the unprecedented deterioration in the Government's budgetary position over the last two years. We have moved from a situation in 1989-90 when the Government had a Budget surplus of $8 billion to a situation this year, just two years later, where, even on the Government's own reckoning, the deficit will be $6.8 billion—say, $7 billion. That represents a turnaround in those two years of $15 billion.

No-one really believes that that $6.8 billion will be achieved. It is more likely to be a deficit of something approaching $9 billion. To come in during the next five months—the figures are as yet unknown—with a deficit of $6.8 billion will require between the first half of 1991-92 and the second half a turnaround of an amount that is absolutely unprecedented in Australia's history. We have a deficit in the first six months of this year of $11 billion. To achieve a deficit of $7 billion means that there has to be a surplus of $4 billion in the second half of this year. That makes a turnaround between the first and second halves of the financial year of $15 billion. That has never before been achieved in our history. It could be achieved only if there were a major increase in economic activity in the second half of 1991-92—that is, between now and the end of June. Even the Government acknowledges that that will not happen and that we are still in a very recessed condition.

The budgetary stimulus that is in the economy is very great indeed. What the Government is doing with the package that it announced last night—this unfunded package, this absolutely, totally irresponsible spending package—is to compound that deficit situation in a way that will put enormous pressure on the financial markets. The bond market moved up today as the analysts started to look at the impact of the package. I am certain that on further inspection that market rate will increase. So we are now facing again a situation of inevitable and inexorable rises in interest rates. The last thing that the private sector in this country needs, if we are to attempt to get any recovery, is yet another increase in interest rates to the crippling levels that brought this country to its knees over the last couple of years. The impact of the deficit will be very considerable.

Senator McMullan before he left the chamber said, `Oh, well, it wasn't really all that big a problem because it was only a small percentage of GDP'. The forecasts in last night's statement are not really forecasts, as the Government itself admits in the fine print in this document. The so-called forecasts for the next four or five years are only scenarios. As the document makes clear, they are not forecasts as such, yet the whole of the figuring of the Budget has been predicated on the basis that they are forecasts. That is a fundamental flaw in the whole conceptual calculation.

The other enormous difference between the statement of last night and the coalition's Fightback proposals is that every ounce of increased revenue that the Government is relying on to fund its spending binge over the next four years is based on a very rapid rate of economic growth. The Fightback proposals that the coalition put forward were absolutely self-financed without any allowance at all for an incentive effect as a result of increased economic growth, which would obviously occur.

Whereas the Fightback proposals are costed on the most conservative possible basis, the Government's statement last night and all its calculations are based on the most ambitious and least conservative result that could be achieved. There only has to be a hiccup in the growth forecasts on which last night's figures are based and there will be an enormously greater Budget deficit than the one forecast. For example, the predictions in the economic statement last night were based on a growth in the economy of something over 4 per cent on average over the next four years. That is a very optimistic scenario. If the growth rate falls below 4 per cent the $20 billion cumulative deficit over the next four years will absolutely skyrocket.

Some modelling has been done today by the coalition using the Murphy model, which I think is accepted by both sides of politics as a very accurate econometric model. The results show that the Prime Minister's One Nation package will cause a major blow out in foreign debt. It will boost inflation significantly. It will cause a massive increase in the current account deficit. The Budget will remain in significant deficit through the whole of the four-year period—not just in a cyclical way but in a way that will produce a very significant structural deficit.

According to the modelling we have done today, growth in gross domestic product will be much lower than the Government's suggested figure of 4 per cent to 4.3 per cent. In fact, the figure will average 3 per cent a year. Inflation, far from the Government's 3 3/4 per cent claim by the Prime Minister last night will, on the basis of the modelling done today, blow out to 6 per cent.

The current account deficit will increase to over $27 billion and net foreign debt will increase by about $100 billion. The results of that modelling are very clear. They indicate what really was clear last night but has become even clearer today and, that is, that the Keating so-called economic statement—as I said earlier, it should have been called a political statement—will cause massive structural damage to Australia's economy.

A great con job has been attempted by the Government in the last 24 hours in the area of its supposed personal income tax cuts for Australians. The Government was claiming that average taxpayers would get an income tax cut of $46 a week in 1994 and 1996. That is palpably wrong. Firstly, on the Government's own admission in the statement last night, there will be no tax cut at all for persons earning less than $20,700 per year, and 42 per cent of all Australian income tax payers earn less than $20,700 a year. Almost half of the taxpaying population of Australia will not get one crack at tax cuts out of this package. Even those who will get tax cuts will have to wait until 1994 for the first cut and 1996 for the second cut to get anything out of it at all.

Someone on average weekly earnings, which is now the equivalent of $30,000 per year, will get a tax cut of around $14 per week. Those on $50,000 per year and above will get a $47 per week tax cut. Sure, there is a $46 a week tax cut for some people but it is for those people earning $50,000 and above per year, not the average earners as the Prime Minister has so dishonestly tried to say.

In stark contrast, the coalition's Fightback proposals not only offer tax cuts to all categories of income earners but they also allow for large increases in social security payments, increases which far outweigh the one-off price effect of about 4.4 per cent that will result from the introduction of the coalition's goods and services tax.

Not only are we giving the tax cuts and not only are we giving a very generous increase in social security benefits, but on top of all of that we will abolish sales tax, we will abolish petrol tax, we will abolish payroll tax, we will abolish the training guarantee levy, we will abolish the lump sum superannuation tax and we will abolish the coal export levy. All of those things add up to about $20 billion. That $20 billion is now paid by business simply on the cost of doing business in this country. It is not a tax on the profit that business earns; it is a tax that slugs business while it is trying to produce goods and services.

If we want to get this country moving, we have to lessen that crippling burden that we have imposed on our business sector. That is the only way to make our country competitive. That is the only way that we can boost our exports and enable our local producers to compete against imports. There was not one jot in the economic statement last night that will make Australia a more internationally competitive economy. That was the whole thrust of the comments of my leader, Senator Hill, in his very valuable contribution to this debate tonight. Not one cracker of last night's economic statement will make Australia a more competitive nation.

The economic statement will add to our rate of inflation. It will not do it overnight, but it will do it very soon thereafter. It will add to the interest rate burden that consumers and producers alike face; it will not remove anything from the tax burden of businesses actually doing business in this country; and it will exclude 42 per cent of taxpayers—the lower end of the income tax scale, those people in our community who have been most hurt by the Government's crass, incompetent economic policies. They will not get one iota of benefit out of this package over the next five years. Because of the increase in inflation and the increase in interest rates, they are all going to be worse off. As Senator McMullan said, we have a very clear contrast and a stark choice for Australians to make over the next few months, pending the forthcoming election.

There are some other significant omissions from last night's economic statement. One of the most important reforms that this country needs and one which to his credit the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was working towards, is a major reform of Commonwealth-State relations—particularly, Commonwealth-State financial relations. This Prime Minister is the centralist par excellence. He has knocked that proposal on the head. He has said nothing about Commonwealth-State financial relations, despite the fact that reform of Commonwealth-State financial relations is arguably the most important micro-economic reform that this country requires.

Last night's statement by the Government fails on virtually every count. It fails on the confidence test. The Government has tried to buy confidence. You cannot buy confidence. The only way that governments can get confidence back into the community is by earning it through performance and sound, responsible economic policies. The Government has absolutely abrogated from that. It has failed the vision test. The one thing that the Prime Minister was going to be judged on last night was whether he had a vision for the future. Where was he going to lead Australia? Where does he want Australia to go? How is he going to get there? There was nothing about that in last night's statement. He absolutely failed.

I think that the Prime Minister made a very great mistake, personally, when he pinned his colours to the mast in placing so much weight before the event on the significance of last night's economic statement. He will live to rue the day he did that because last night's statement was a disaster and it will be seen as a disaster for this Government when the election comes around. I say to those opposite that that election cannot come soon enough, either for us or for the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very valuable opportunity to be able to speak in this debate. If one were to believe the Government, all our problems would be over after last night's performance. The sort of extravagant rhetoric that we have had from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is part and parcel—indeed, stock in trade—of the way in which he has conducted himself on economic issues. I have no doubt that in the days to come the analysts, the economists and the commentators will do the arithmetic and will come to only one conclusion, which is inevitable: that this package is simply unsustainable. It is built on sands that simply do not exist. Indeed, it is the height of irresponsibility.

PARA.TAB: If one tries to think of the most important single line that goes through Australian politics in terms of economic responsibility, it is: where is the money coming from? It has almost in itself been enough to bring down governments in the past. When one tries to judge these things objectively, it is right that it should because it is the height of irresponsibility to make promises to spend money that is not ours, to hock the country in the future and to, in effect, mortgage one's grandchildren. This is precisely what we have before us.

A public debt that will rise by $20 billion over the next four years is an horrific sight to contemplate, given the enormity of our foreign debt and all the economic indicators that are weighted so heavily against us already. I do not think anyone can express it better than did Max Walsh today. I noticed Senator Button's churlish response. In one breath he said, `Of course, I don't want to put Max Walsh down; he is really quite an intelligent fellow, but he is a bit of a manic depressive basically'. At the same time, he was careful not to decry Max Walsh's economics.

I think we can take it that even Senator Button is embarrassed to have to defend the package in the way that he tried to do today. It was painfully clear from his answers to several questions, one from Senator Short, that he was embarrassed in the extreme. He did not know some of the fundamentals of the document, and quite clearly was intellectually uncomfortable in defending the indefensible. What Max Walsh says, for example, when talking about this as a crude and dangerous political pork-barrelling exercise, is that Mr Keating has gone on a spending spree. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The magnitude of Mr Keating's gamble . . . is best illustrated by the treatment of public saving.

He then goes on to demonstrate that the public sector borrowing requirement is indeed much higher than the Government would claim and is destined to go even higher in the very near future because of the blow-out of State deficits. What really is the ultimate in magic puddings is the statement that the Government will halve that borrowing requirement simply by restoration of the Commonwealth Budget balance, relying on restraint in outlays which decline as a proportion of GDP from 1992-93, partly offset by a decline in revenue as a proportion of GDP.

PARA.TAB: That is economic gobbledegook. It is simply another way of saying that the Government refuses to give the slightest commitment to expenditure cuts. At the same time, it will not raise taxes. Indeed, we are in the process of having bribes thrown at us, on a deferred basis. At the end of the day it is simply a means of pretending that somehow the Government will be able to achieve savings when it has given not the slightest indication of how it hopes to do so. There is no doubt at all that the Government can finance these sorts of spending sprees only by borrowings; yet, just to quote another one of Mr Keating's immortal lines from only two years ago:

SPEECH.PARA: In three years there will be no government debt, domestic or external. It is an enormous claim that I can make on behalf of the Government of Australia. I doubt there is any other OECD economy that will not have any bonds on issue at all.

As Senator Short said, bond rates have already moved upwards today in anticipation of the inevitable, and it is quite clear that, if the Government is not going to embark on expenditure cuts or taxation increases, there are only two other options: one is simply to print money, which has drastic inflationary consequences; the other is to borrow, and that will indirectly force up interest rates and presumably exacerbate inflation in due course.

PARA.TAB: So there is no semblance of responsibility in all this. Mr Keating has reached new heights of bombast which I suspect even Mr Hawke could not have achieved with a straight face. It really defies common sense when we look at some of the statements he has made in the past, such as `We are leading the world, as usual'; `redesigning capitalism'; `If we get the economy right then the security we give our people will really be quite profound by an international comparison'. Probably one of the most telling is a statement of about 18 months ago:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no prospect of massive increases in public spending—full stop. If you're savings poor you can't have it—like the people who say we've got to have a super highway from here to there. People here believe they can have brand new roads, buildings, brand new everything. Well, they can't.

Of course they cannot. He knew it then and he knows it now. But he has the gall to get up and somehow pretend that you can have all these things—in the hope, of course, that he will be taken at his word. We will not have anything to see for this prior to the next election. We will have some promises about all sorts of things down the track, but the political strategy is clear: simply to muddy the waters, pretend that things are happening, and make extravagant promises about the future to disguise the fact that unemployment will still stay around 10 per cent. Again, of course, the Government simply chooses to pretend that it will be below the magic 10 per cent figure. Somehow that is even more excruciatingly embarrassing for them, so it says that it will be around 9.5 per cent. The truth is that the Government has no idea.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating said as recently as December 1990 `We are setting up a market economy but built around a compassionate policy', and then last night he announced obscene taxation cuts for the likes of Senator Tate, who is on $100,000 a year. He will be picking up about $2,500 a year as a result of this package. But the 3.9 million taxpayers and the people least able to defend themselves, the low income groups, part time and casual employees, mostly women, students and the aged—all those who are simply eking out a living on the side—get absolutely nothing at all. That is a travesty of social justice.

The most extraordinary thing of all was when Senator Button today was asked for his assessment of the social justice implications. From where I sat it was quite clear that he had not a clue what the question meant; or, if he did, he was so acutely embarrassed that he had no answer to it. Of all people, who had to come over and give him some advice but Senator Richardson, who was in earnest conversation with him, presumably explaining to him how to spell the term and desperately trying to find some sort of rational justification for the policy. But there is not one. It is simply a naked bribe aimed at the middle classes in the desperate hope that somehow they will clutch at it and be grateful. Well, they will not.

It is also verging on the obscene, after years of being told that welfare is being targeted and is going only to those most in need, to find that we get this ridiculous one-off handout of $125 by way of family allowance for those who have fewer than five children and $250 for those who have more. That is the very antithesis of welfare targeting. People on $75,000 can be eligible for this sort of handout. What are they meant to do with this $125? I suppose they could buy 2 1/2 bottles of Veuve Cliquot, or maybe another hub-cap for the Mercedes. But could anyone in his right mind suggest that those people are in need of that sort of assistance? The people who are desperately in need of more help than a one-off transparent bribe are those who are out of work and those on low incomes. But here we have a payment that will go to anyone earning less than $75,000 a year, irrespective of their circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're going to get it too, are you?

—I do not know. We probably do qualify, although one's children have to be under 16, so the honourable senator might just miss out. In any case, it will go to many hundreds of thousands of Australians—I think there are 1.9 million recipients of family allowance—and a considerable proportion of those people simply do not need it. Where is the sense in that sort of cheap and transparent gimmickry? It is quite clear that this is conscience money; it is an apology for the recession we had to have, but it is utterly irrelevant in terms of solving economic problems.

PARA.TAB: The sort of derisory payment to voluntary agencies of about $2m this year is really put in perspective when one considers the cynicism of the way in which the Government is going to hand out this $125—by personal cheques from the Prime Minister. The cost of postage will probably be about the same as the amount of money that the Government is handing over to voluntary agencies in order to alleviate distress in the community. Can honourable senators think of anything more cynical than that, anything worse by way of wasting taxpayers' funds? That money could have been given to the agencies, in spades. Indeed, the sort of money that is being handed over in these $125 payments is of the order of several hundred million dollars—a $317m package in one-off payments. As a number of welfare agencies have said, that money could have been much better applied if it had been given directly to charitable organisations to disburse. The Anglican Home Mission Society said that last night. The Sydney City Mission said that putting a bandaid over the wound was not going to heal it. It is quite clear that, as the Anglican Diocese of Newcastle spokesman said, this is little more than a bandaid measure.

The fact remains that the Government could not use this money less effectively if it tried. If it were in any way serious about trying to help those who have suffered most from the recession, it would not give the money to fat cat public servants; it would not disperse it in such a way that it almost dissipates it by sending off 1.9 million cheques. Indeed, it would give the money to voluntary agencies. Yet the money was there for the taking—because it is all unfunded. Instead, what happens? None of it will go to them except a miserable $2m, and $3m next year—for what it is worth—presumably after the election so the Government does not have to deliver on it. The cynicism is breathtaking. One can only conclude that the people who made these sorts of decisions have long since lost touch with reality.

Mr Keating has now been in this place for about 24 years. One would have thought that he had pride and self-respect, that he had tried over the years—putting all that hyperbole and euphuistic nonsense aside—and was somehow interested to establish a reputation for some degree of economic rationality, and that perhaps he was sensitive to some of the charges about what had happened to his predecessor but one when he had a fairly extravagant Budget in his last term in office. All of those lessons seem to have gone for nought, because we have Mr Keating here simply being prepared to throw it all on one roll of the dice, to be about as profligate as he could ever be in expenditure terms—not just in one year but, if this package were to be taken seriously, which of course it will not, a commitment to spending of the order of $20 billion over the next 4 years with nothing more than pious hopes about how it will be funded.

To talk about labour productivity increasing by 300 per cent I would have thought is pretty breathtaking stuff. To talk about GDP going up by a factor of two within the next 12 months is again defying recent history when there have been very modest growth rates. Indeed, labour productivity has been averaging less than 1 per cent over the last five years and all of a sudden we are talking about 1.5 per cent. So the figures are not just rubbery; they are unrecognisable if one is serious about arithmetic. Of course, that shows the hollowness and emptiness of this whole package. It does not tackle any of the fundamental issues. It does not do any more than aggravate our economic circumstances.

If Mr Keating were fair dinkum, if he really wanted to get Australia back on track, it is not very hard to work out what he has to do. He certainly has to tackle some of those labour market rigidities and some of those rorts that go on around the country in terms of work practices in government business enterprises and elsewhere and he certainly has to embark on economic reform. He has done none of that; it is all in the too hard basket.

It was suggested last year that Keating should stop the Government's disgraceful early retirement scheme—which is laughingly known as superannuation—by raising the preservation age from 55 to 60. That is a perfectly rational proposition which every responsible commentator would endorse as a means of closing off the double dipping gap. But what was Mr Keating's response? It was, `We will not do it because it is too difficult politically and industrially'. In other words, there is not one rational economic argument for not doing what must be done; simply that Bill Kelty and the ACTU will not wear it. Look at the sort of veto that the ACTU is able to continue to exercise on this country. There will be an announcement tomorrow which presumably will mean that we will see more of it. We will certainly see a lot more of it in terms of superannuation over the period of the next weeks and months because we know that this progressive impost—a $4 billion payroll tax on employers—will simply be funded from their own retained earnings and profits; it certainly will not come out of the pockets of workers.

Even the likes of Senator Cook, who has to be the ultimate member of the club, had the grace to concede last year that perhaps workers ought to bear some share of the burden in terms of contributing to superannuation, but there was not a skerrick of a suggestion that that will happen in practice. There was simply a reaffirmation in last night's statement that the whole of the burden will be borne by employers—up to 9 per cent—and some vague waffle about the other 3 per cent being funded by a combination of wage restraint and tax cut trade-offs. We all know that is a fiction. It will clearly be a 12 per cent employer impost within a period of eight years. That is totally unsustainable, about the last thing the Government would ever want if it were serious about economic recovery. To pretend, as people such as Kelty do, that somehow this will not have any inflationary impact, that it will not cost any jobs, is again simply showing breathtaking cynicism.

One does not have to go through all of the areas in which the Government could have tackled reform, if it had been fair dinkum, to have some idea of the missed opportunities and to understand that this does virtually nothing to address Australia's economic difficulties. Sure, accelerated depreciation is a worthwhile initiative. Sure, there are a few other little bits and pieces around the place. But can anyone seriously suggest that this even amounts to tinkering at the edges? It clearly does not. If the Government is talking about giving business some $2.5 billion worth of assistance over the next five years, when what we have in mind is a fully funded $20 billion worth of concessions and seven tax replacements for business, it is not hard to see that there will be a very real gap between the respective packages. In some ways, it is quite extraordinary that business has not recognised that as yet, but I hope that some of the captains of industry do have some second thoughts and look beyond their noses and realise that if they want to live in a country that is going to turn the corner—not one that is simply going further and further downhill and which will force them offshore—then the economy needs a very great stimulus and not the sort of nonsense that is being put forward by a very desperate Prime Minister.

To urge the Federal Airports Corporation to provide common user terminals is a classic cop-out in industrial relations terms. To propose an unfunded contribution of $41m over the next three years to ease the burden on exports does not just pale into insignificance beside our $1.7 billion relief under the Fightback package; it simply shows that the Government is not particularly interested in boosting exports and trying to right the trade balance. A $15m handout to Austrade over the next three years is nothing more or less than pandering to the Public Service Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could have shown a bit of accountability for what they have done over the last year, of course.

—That is right. It is just another black hole. We know the great difficulties Austrade has had. They obviously overwhelmed Senator Button because he had that toy taken away from him several years back. To throw another $18m at DIFF is really just protection under another name, and one would have thought that the Government would long ago have recognised that if it is not serious about being competitive it does not play around with DIFF payments in this way. DIFF will make nothing more than a marginal difference. It will simply be swallowed up and costs will be readjusted. It will do nothing for efficiency or competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: There are many restrictive work practices which continue to take my breath away when I read about them. For instance, there are crane drivers who are being paid $150,000-$160,000 a year; giant earthmoving shovels which, for the rest of the world, have one seat but for the Australian market have one seat and two beds; and earthmoving shovel operators being paid $70,000 plus. In the New South Wales coal industry, drag lines are being managed by three people whereas in the rest of the world they only require one. A local council in New South Wales is having to spend $6,000 in overtime just to have someone unlock a chain admitting cars to the local tip. An Australian stevedore company calculated it could save as much as $400,000 a year in one main port just by replacing amenities men who look after the lunch room. Wharf foremen at the Albany port are earning an average of $30,000 for eight hours work a week. The Government is paying picketers social security payments when they are supposed to be actively looking for work. Australian construction workers are losing 10 per cent of working days due to bad weather when the international figure is around 2 per cent.

Does anyone really need to be persuaded that the Government simply does not have the stomach to tackle these obvious impediments to economic efficiency and to realise, of course, that nothing will happen whilst the ACTU and the Government are in the unholy relationship they have enjoyed for the last eight or nine years?

It is quite clear that last night's package is not only an abject failure but also simply compounds our economic problems. It will undoubtedly make matters worse, not better. It offers no consolation at all to the people who are most vulnerable and who have already suffered the most. It offers no hope to those who are out of work. Indeed, the Government's own figuring confirms that those who are on the unemployment scrap heap can continue to rot there for the remainder of the life of this Government. The Government can offer them no prospect, no glimmer of hope. Yet it is prepared to waste billions of dollars on cheap electoral handouts and initiatives which clearly do not address Australia's difficult circumstances.

We only have to look at Mr Keating's announcement today that Coronation Hill is an insignificant venture and that the Government's decision to block it is final. We well know that people of the likes of Senator Walsh claim to have been on a promise about that decision being reversed. One would have thought that if Mr Keating had any gumption at all he would have clearly recognised that that remains a totem issue for business—that business is desperately looking for some indication of gumption and moral fortitude. Yet, when a challenge as simple as that—when he is given winks and nods—suddenly proves too hard, he throws in the towel.

What hope is there that in any way the real problems will be tackled over the next 12 months? None at all. There is no consolation for the victims other than these sorts of throwaway items. Presumably, by way of substitute we will have yet more cheap rhetoric, a bit of Pommy bashing, a bit of Opposition kicking—you name it, you'll get it—if you see a head, kick it. We will not get too many sensible policy initiatives. We will get a desperate attempt to distract attention at all costs from the fact that this country is down the drain and that there are no sensible proposals on the table to do anything about it. The likes of Max Walsh will simply be dismissed and derided as doomsday merchants. We will have an extravagant smokescreen of rhetoric and criticism of the Opposition to take us through the next 12 months.

That is a tragedy for Australia. We will have to grin and bear it on this side of the chamber. I suppose the unfortunate thing is that here we are recession proof, we are not at risk of losing our jobs—at least until the next election. In the meantime, the Australian taxpayers and citizens have to pay the penalty. I am quite sure that they will not have gained any solace from last night's announcement. The more they think about it, the more they will realise that their predicament is indeed worse, not better, as a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We hear a great deal about how unpopular this present Labor Government is. The polls quite clearly indicate that that is because this Government is clearly identified with the creation of this recession that we are now suffering.

PARA.TAB: I think we concede that this economic statement is designed to fix this Government's political problem by pretending to deal with the recession. It gets good publicity from some, but I do not think it can really deliver. This is just another ultimate public relations exercise the like of which this Government has excelled in over the years. It pretends to change direction; it pretends to change philosophy; it pretends that somehow again there is a role for government; but it actually accelerates the process of economic rationalism which has delivered the current disaster for the Australian community.

That is not to say that there are not some worthwhile initiatives in this package; on the contrary, there are some. Some of them are Democrat policies which have been picked up. The theme which is being sold—and we have heard it here tonight from Senator McMullan—is that suddenly overnight there

SPEECH.PARA: is a huge gulf between the policies of the Opposition and the policies of the Government. I do not think that is true. I think we now have a tiny little chink of difference between the Government and the Opposition. The Government has stolen, copied, the aviation and radical deregulatory banking policies of the Opposition and included them in this statement.

PARA.TAB: Before considering the specific measures, I want to look at the big picture that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has presented to us. We are supposed to believe that the Government has announced a massive stimulus to the economy. The facts simply do not support this contention. The Prime Minister has announced measures amounting to less than $500m this financial year. That means that the immediate stimulus is an increase in this year's outlays of less than half a per cent and 1.5 per cent in next year's Budget program. I do not think we could call this massive—in fact, it is almost trivial.

It is significant that Government spending is forecast to fall from this year's peak of 26 per cent of GDP to 22.6 per cent of GDP in four years time. That means that we have economic rationalism, reinforced by this commitment to smaller government throughout the 1990s. That is what the Fightback package is all about—smaller government. There is no difference there.

The One Nation package seems to have forgotten that there are 960,000 Australians who are unemployed now, today, and about 300,000 of them lost their jobs during the last 18 months because of the Government's policies. They have very little to look forward to from this statement. Where are the short term community level jobs which can alleviate some of the distress and despair of unemployment? I think that the Local Government Association put forward some excellent propositions on behalf of local councils to fund worthwhile projects at the local level. I happen to believe that local communities can best identify the needs in their communities. They are very well placed to channel and supervise funds needed for those communities. The sort of short term employment for over 100,000 people would include things such as building and landscaping parks and recreation areas, cleaning up our polluted waterways—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not real jobs.
—The Government also says that these are not real jobs. The dignity of anybody's labour, the long term benefit to people from being employed, means that they are real jobs.

PARA.TAB: The most fraudulent piece of this document is the absurd assumption that the Australian economy will grow by almost 5 per cent for the next five years. From this flows the claim that 800,000 jobs will be created. This is simply an act of faith which cannot be justified. It was the number needed to slot into the model to produce the politically important number of 800,000 jobs.
Even if all of this were true, what would happen to the unemployment rate after Comrade Keating's four-year plan? Not much at all. Page 120 of the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: Employment is expected to trend upwards through 1992 and could grow by about 2 1/4 per cent in 1992-93. This would be consistent with a steady fall in the unemployment rate to 10 per cent in 1992-93 . . . and to around 9 1/2 per cent by mid-1993.
This means that in about 15 months one out of 10 unemployed Australians might have a job—so much for the concern and compassion for the victims of the recession.

PARA.TAB: I think by any objective criteria this statement is a complete failure in its stated objective of reducing unemployment. Judging by the positive reaction from many commentators, all of whom have jobs, the real objective, the political objective of this statement may well have been achieved.

I now turn to some of the specific matters contained in the statement. Most of the taxation measures are positive. We welcome some of these. In fact, they are reversing previous poor decisions of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right.

—Some of them are even adopting Democrat policy. The major initiative, and other speakers have mentioned this, is the new accelerated depreciation regime. The Government has abandoned the level playing field to an extent—it is a pity it does not apply the same philosophy in the rural sector—and has skewed the tax system slightly towards productive investment. The Prime Minister is claiming that Australia now has a world competitive depreciation regime. But what Mr Keating conveniently did not remember to tell us is that, up until 1988, Australia had a more generous depreciation regime—it was destroyed by him when he was the Treasurer—than the one announced last night. Similarly, the so-called development allowance is basically a less generous yet more targeted investment allowance which was originally introduced by Prime Minister Fraser and axed by level playing field Keating in 1985.

PARA.TAB: There are two tax decisions in particular which show that the Government does not understand ecologically sustainable development. Despite Senator McMullan's protestations earlier that this One Nation package is more environmentally friendly than the Fightback package, the fact is that there is no competition and neither of them would win the prize for this.

The first environmentally bad decision is the sales tax reduction for new motor vehicle purchases. It is Democrat policy to tax cars on the basis of their fuel efficiency. The sales tax reduction should apply only to fuel efficient vehicles. This will reduce our consumption and hence our importation of oil, thereby reducing the current account deficit—something which everyone keeps bleating about but does not seem to make the vital connections. The second decision is the increase in the depreciation rate for tourist accommodation from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent. We think the best thing to do is to encourage efficient design by granting the higher rate of depreciation only to energy efficient buildings.

The infrastructure bonds are an innovative attempt at boosting long term private sector development projects. Whether they will assist the private provision of infrastructure is a moot point. The Government's own figures do not estimate any activity in this area until 1993 or 1994. There are some tax carrots for small business, which we support, the most important being the increase in the capital gains tax exemption for goodwill from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. The goodwill exemption was created by the Democrats when the original capital gains tax legislation was passed. Then there is the token measure of delaying this year's first company tax payment for small businesses by nine weeks. I do not think this will do much to usher in a recovery and neither do the small business people, judging by the reception they have given the package.

Financial deregulation is again championed in this statement. We are to have more foreign banks. These will be allowed to operate at a wholesale level as a branch instead of as a separate subsidiary. This undoubtedly means that the Reserve Bank will not be able adequately to supervise the banks which are operating as branches, not as subsidiaries. We are told that this is okay because foreign central banks will be supervising them. The world has just seen the collapse of a significant international bank, BCCI, which was not prevented by the international monetary authorities. This ideological worship of foreign financial institutions is simply a manifestation of the cultural cringe. Mr Keating made much today in the House of Representatives about our cultural cringe towards Britain, about being bootstraps to the British. I think Mr Keating could well look at his own record in respect of Australia's cultural cringe to foreign investment, to foreign banks.

The ultimate hypocrisy can be seen in the decision to grant a 10 per cent income tax rate to profits earned by offshore banking units. This approach was explicitly rejected by Mr Keating while he was Treasurer in a press release issued on 1 July 1986. The Government cannot see its way clear to assist the productive industries of the twenty-first century in appropriate individual ways, yet it bends over backwards to cater to unproductive paper shuffling by granting the most generous tax regime possible. Senator Button admitted today that such arrangements had been rorted overseas, especially in Singapore, and that therefore this Government would ensure that the concession was not abused. I think we have to ask: how can we be sure this can be done?

The last taxation matter I wish to mention is the so-called income tax cuts to be paid over the next few years. These are politically motivated and politically targeted. They do not favour, as Senator Alston pointed out, those with the lowest income. They are simply directed to neutralise the proposals of Dr Hewson. Two weeks ago Mr Keating said he would not get into an auction tax with Dr Hewson, but obviously he has not been able to resist the temptation to do so. Mr Keating's priorities are clear. Ordinary workers are promised a maximum income tax rate of 30 per cent in four years, and offshore banking is to face a maximum tax rate of 10 per cent from 1 July this year.

The most important matter I have been able to identify from my interest in this package is the proposals concerning foreign investment. The Hawke and now Keating governments have successively weakened and liberalised the pathetically meagre controls Australia imposes on foreign investment. The Foreign Investment Review Board is merely a part of Treasury which approves about 98 per cent of the proposals that come before it. The foreign investment decisions contained in the One Nation package are nothing short of scandalous.

Mr Keating did not have the courage to say to the Australian people, `I have been Prime Minister for two months and in that time I have decided that virtually all foreign investment proposals should proceed without any controls'. Sure, it is in the text, but not a word did he convey to us orally. He did not say it because he knew that the Australian people feel very strongly about this issue. He did not say it because he knew that it was an outrageous proposition. He did it so that the financial markets would continue to give this Government the thumbs up. In this package the Government has proposed that the previous threshold for automatic consideration of proposals by the Foreign Investment Review Board be raised from $5m to $50m. That is an intolerable difference. That means that any business or farm or building worth less than $50m can be bought by foreign interests without any assessment of the effects of that purchase.

Looking quickly at what was not in the statement, there were no measures to remove the regressive taxation regime which applies to superannuation; no relief from the tariff cuts which are killing manufacturing and rural industries; no action on child-care expenses being recognised in the taxation system; and no action on positive incentives to boost our disastrous savings performance.

The One Nation package and its emphasis on liberalising foreign investment is a recipe for disaster. We do not get better management. We do not automatically get greater access to markets, although that is the one claim that can be made for foreign investment which may eventuate. We do not get technology transfer. What on earth do the beef cattle producers of this country have to learn from overseas interests? Nothing. They are the best in their field. We are told by many that Australia will be the continent of the twenty-first century. What a comfort it will be if we are left owning and controlling virtually none of it.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Musicians--Minister for the Arts and Territories

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to note the passing of two important Australian musicians. Both contributed in their different ways to the development of musical activity in Australia. Both were friends, people whom I respected and certainly people whose musical ability was undoubted.

PARA.TAB: The first person I want to talk about was Werner Baer, who has been properly described as an elder statesman of classical music in Australia. He died on 28 January, aged 77, after a long illness. Mr Baer, who lived in Castlecrag, was an outstanding accompanist, organist, lecturer, choir conductor and composer, a former ABC music supervisor for New South Wales and a founding musical director of the Sydney Jewish Choral Society. He also played the organ for me, for which I was always grateful, at my first wedding, which was 29 years ago last week.

Werner Baer was born of middle class Jewish parents and grew up in Berlin in the 1920s. When he was aged only 3 1/2, his mother heard him naming the notes as the piano tuner struck the keys. At six he went to his first opera, which was the marvellous Mozart opera Cosi Fan Tutte. At nine he wrote his first composition and at 12 he took up the organ.

In 1932, Werner Baer enrolled in Berlin's High School of Music where a teacher was the marvellous pianist Artur Schnabel. In 1938, the synagogue at which Mr Baer was organist and choir master was burnt down. Six weeks in a concentration camp followed, after which Mr Baer was issued with an exit permit for Thailand. When Japan entered World War II, he naturally left Thailand. He came to Australia and enlisted in what was then known as the Army Labour Corps.

In 1951, Werner Baer joined the ABC as a New South Wales music supervisor and took on other roles such as Program Director in New South Wales, Assistant Director of Music and Music Editor. At one stage he was responsible for the staffing and administration of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra.

There are various sides of Werner Baer. He was a person who unfortunately did not enjoy good health. There are those who have taken the view that sometimes he could be a little hard to get on with, perhaps because of these successive illnesses. Some people did see him as perhaps a little bit of a martinet, irascible and prone to flashes of temper. I would say that to an extent, though, he set such high standards himself that he did have difficulty putting up with people who did not meet those high standards. I must say that everyone who was in contact with him had the highest possible regard for him.

Werner Baer was certainly very prominent in the Australian Jewish community. The music critic of Australian Jewish News, David Brown, said in his obituary that Mr Baer was well known throughout the Australian musical community but that within the Jewish community his undoubted talents often went unrecognised and unappreciated. This was despite the fact that he had taken up the position of founding Musical Director of the Sydney Jewish Choral Society, which of course achieved great status despite his poor health.

I last saw Mr Baer at the opera in Sydney a few months ago. He was looking frail and ill. I rejoice in the fact that his life enabled him to contribute so much to Australian music, but I regret that we have lost such a significant influence in the Australian music scene. To his wife, Sibilla, daughter, Miriam and son, David, I certainly send my condolences.

The other musician that I would like to mention here tonight is John Douglas Gordon, who was my choir master at St Albans's Church of England, Lindfield—longer ago than I would like to admit here. He was the first person to play the Canberra carillon. He was the Australian expert on carillons. When John Gordon was an arts undergraduate in 1932, he began his unique 59-year association with Sydney University and its carillon as a skilled performer, composer, arranger, teacher and author. In fact, his 1928 treatise, Notes of the Art of Carillon Playing—a Guide to Students, featured his own composition arrangements and theories on quadrangle acoustics and became something of a classic reference book in the formation of Australia's first carillon school.

John Gordon was born in Sydney in January 1915. He graduated as an MA from Sydney University in 1939. He had also gone to the school that I went to—North Sydney High. He was honoured by the Queen with the medal of the Order of Australia.

John Gordon was appointed the first carillonist to the Canberra carillon and gave the inaugural recital on 26 April in the presence of the Queen and Prince Philip. So in nearly 19 years at the Canberra carillon tower, John Gordon gave some 350 public recitals and trained many students, including the six currently active Canberra carillonists. As George Howe, the Deputy Canberra Carillonist, said in a tribute to him:

SPEECH.PARA: He was truly a dedicated artist who, since his youth, gave virtually all his energy to music.
I simply place on record in the Senate my tribute to John Douglas Gordon.

PARA.TAB: To make a total break from that atmospheric, I will now regrettably become involved in an argument with Ms Wendy Fatin, the Minister for the Arts and Territories. If Ms Fatin's interview with the Age on 17 February is an indication of what her style is going to be as Minister for the Arts and Territories in dealing with the Opposition, I am afraid it will be a stormy time and we will have an uncomfortable relationship. I do not take kindly to being as ludicrously misrepresented as Mrs Fatin has managed to do. I hope that it is only incompetence rather than malevolence that has led her to it.

Mrs Fatin says in this interview that she is appalled by the Opposition's plan to cut arts funding by $43m under a GST. That statement is totally, ridiculously and self-evidently false and Mrs Fatin should be embarrassed for having been led into saying it by what I presume to be some overenthusiastic staff. If in fact it was her own invention, I suppose we will have a difficult time together. That will be unfortunate because I must say that I had the highest personal regard for her predecessor. I found that Mr Simmons and I could agree to disagree on many matters but we never ever became involved in misrepresenting each other's positions.

It is possible to exist in political life without entering into the style of behaviour that Mrs Fatin has evidenced in this statement. David Simmons was regarded highly by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Australia Council and people in the arts community for the good job that he was doing within the constraints of government policy and particularly within the financial constraints imposed upon him. My original disappointment, distress and sorrow that he was losing that job—firstly, because of our personal relationship and, secondly, because I think he had done a good job—was compounded by seeing the sort of nonsense that Mrs Fatin is prepared to utter.

In the first place, the $43m alleged cuts is in fact largely due not to cuts in the arts at all. In fact, the cuts to the arts element of the arts portfolio—that is basically, the Australia Council—are specifically and deliberately not aimed at any arts grants whatsoever that are based on arts criteria.

In other words, there are some grants that are not based on arts criteria which are subject to cuts. They are minimal, probably less than $1m. But as is clearly and uncomplicatedly stated in a document which is incapable of honest misinterpretation, there will be no cuts affecting the funding available to arts based arts programs.

We point out in the GST package that the delivery of $53m in arts money through the Australia Council costs $8.6m to administer. In other words, it costs $1 to run the Australia Council to distribute every $6 of grants. Quite frankly, I would rather see arts money going to the arts and not to the arts bureaucrats—not to the people running the Australia Council. Some of them are very good, but it does not mean that they should get a bigger and bigger proportion of the arts dollar, and that is what is happening.

On top of all that, the Australia Council is managing to continue to increase its own Council programs, I think last year by 23 per cent, while cutting the delivery of arts money to arts organisations. For example, last year all the arts groups, with only one exception, suffered funding cuts. The exception was the Literature Board, which received an increase. All the rest suffered funding cuts, with the exception of course of the Australia Council's own Council programs, such as the Donald Horne talkfest—which strikes me as maybe being worth while but not at the expense of arts money. I do not see why these gatherings of intellectuals—I suppose I am expressing sour grapes; I am not regarded as an intellectual so I was not invited—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can sing.

—Yes. I could have gone and sung. The honourable senator is quite right. These talkfests may be of great intellectual stimulus to some people, but to my mind they are an improper diversion of arts money away from the arts. That is the area that I said was to be cut. There are to be no cuts to arts grants. Yet we have Ms Fatin complaining about my plan to cut arts funding by $43m. Maybe she was mistakenly looking at a whole lot of other things. Maybe she was lumping in the cuts to the Australian National Gallery, the National Library, the National Museum of Australia and the National Maritime Museum. That must have been what it was. If she was, she was being equally dishonest because the cuts there are cuts to capital programs in 1994—in other words, after those programs have basically been completed anyway. It was a clear warning to those organisations that in a recession they cannot expect to keep getting capital programs funded.

PARA.TAB: If Ms Fatin meant that, it might have been a nice idea if she had been honest and said so, but to present that as arts funding cuts is a disgrace and she ought to be ashamed of herself. Maybe she was looking at another section—film. There is no doubt that there will be some cuts in the area of film. In fact, under the Government's funding programs there is to be a significant cut in grants to film in the coming years unless the Government changes its mind which, quite frankly, I expect it to do. But what I had said was that the Opposition would support the continuing Government policy, which was to diminish the role played by grants in funding Australian films and increase the proportion provided by way of tax incentives to those people prepared to invest in Australian film.

The Government's policy is this: this year's grant to film, including all film activities, of $91.3m is projected in the Government's latest Budget Papers to be almost halved in 1992-93 and slashed from $91m to only $16.8m. That is a cut of $74.5m by 1993-94. If anyone is slashing arts funding, one could claim, if one were prepared to be as dishonest as Mrs Fatin—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, you must not impute improper motives to or make a personal reflection upon a member of another House. I think you can choose your words accordingly.

—I take the point. It does create a difficulty, because if I try to ascribe another motive to her it would probably be stupidity, and I imagine that would be equally offensive. It is difficult to establish what someone's motives could be apart from being—I suppose an offensive term is—blatantly political. I presume that `blatantly political' is acceptable.
—I think we could get by with that one.

—If she is being blatantly political, without a care for the welfare of her portfolio, then maybe that is the motive that is involved. But it is extraordinary. I have said that, instead of facing this cut in grants of $75m, which would proceed if the Government's policy did not change, I was going to limit the cut to $20m under the Fightback package. That is exactly what I have said. I said that the coalition government will accelerate the rationalisation and privatisation of the film industry and its financing as it no longer needs to depend so heavily on Commonwealth funds. I said that this follows our overall policy commitment to freeing industry from government intervention and dependence. With grants totalling almost $112m, including the Australian Film, Television and Radio School, plus considerable tax expenditures worth more than about $20m, film receives 50 per cent more government grants than all other arts in Australia combined.

PARA.TAB: The Government's policy of reducing direct funding is now being reviewed before the expiry of the present grants program next year. To avoid undue disruption to the industry during its transition period, the coalition will limit the reduction in direct assistance to $20m in the first instance. This will be reviewed subsequently. I then said that in addition Film Australia would be privatised and so on and that total savings in film in terms of direct grants would be $27m.

Maybe what Mrs Fatin has done is added all these together—the end of the capital works program for the Australian National Gallery and all those other museums, libraries and so on—added up the film situation where we are limiting the fall to $20m instead of the Government's Budget figure of $75m, added up the $4m only of cuts to administration and to the non-arts activities of the Australia Council and come up with this magic $43m. That seems to be the only explanation for her extraordinary statement.

There may be one other excuse she might have for misrepresenting the facts or distorting the truth or falsely representing the coalition's figures. I thank Senator Patterson for those three alternative suggestions. The reason may be that there is a deliberate and disgraceful attempt to attack, by dishonest means, the coalition's Fightback package and its position on the arts through organisations that the Australia Council happens to fund with government money.

What Ms Fatin has said is exactly the same deceptive nonsense that a magazine called Arts Action wrote before Christmas and to which I responded vigorously. What I find intolerable is organisations which receive funding through the Australia Council, allegedly for arts purposes, using that money to run blatant, dishonest political attacks on the coalition's arts policy. If organisations such as that think it is their moral duty to spend taxpayers' money which is directed towards the arts in that kind of political dishonest smearing of my policy, then I will say to those organisations that they underline the need for arts money to be redirected back to the arts, instead of their being diverted for political stunts supported by a member of the Parliament in a Ministry in a disgraceful comment to a newspaper. Exactly the same figure is used; exactly the same nonsense is spoken. It is funded by this Government, funded through the Australia Council, diverted away from the arts to which the money should be directed. Ms Fatin should be ashamed of herself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to take a few minutes to raise a matter which has had some considerable publicity in recent days in Tasmania. The recent attacks on environmentalists who are blockading the road in the Picton area in Tasmania are not isolated incidents, as readers of most of Tasmania's newspapers might have assumed. These attacks are instead part of a pattern of violence and harassment that has been present in the area near Geeveston in southern Tasmania for many months. The so-called `greenies' who are now in the area have simply become an easy and very public target for the sorts of vandalism and harassment which have been taking place and which were directed at other people previously. The State Government's inaction in regard to the attacks—and both the Field and Groom governments have to take some responsibility—has in effect given consent to the activities of local thugs.

PARA.TAB: Premier Groom's comments last night on ABC News in Tasmania that the blockade is not peaceful, that the protesters are inciting the attacks, and that no further police action is required, condones the violence against environmentalists and ignores the facts behind the story. I would like to present to the Senate some of the facts behind that story.

One relevant fact is that the tourist group Tasmanian Expeditions has experienced considerable harassment while taking tourists into the Picton area. This group used to camp overnight at the Tahune Reserve before a day's rafting on the Picton River. The groups have been frequently kept awake by a gang who would get drunk, shout verbal abuse at the tourists, throw beer cans at them and urinate on the camping area.

In early December last year this behaviour became so serious that one guide left the reserve in a mini-bus to call the police. He was chased by cars, which attempted to force him off the road, ramming the bus several times. The tour operator is trying to press charges, but has met some resistance from the police in the area. He has had to be very persistent just to get someone to come from Launceston, a considerable distance, to take evidence such as paint scrapings, headlight glass embedded in the bumper bar and that sort of thing. Several people are able and willing to identify the people involved in the attack—they know who it was. The operator no longer camps in the area because of the risks involved, and instead stays at a youth hostel, which means extra travelling and expense for him.

Only a fortnight ago when this tourist group stayed at a cabin near the river the same gang of thugs appeared again, shouting and jumping on the rafts that were to be used. They were chased off to the other side of the river, where they started throwing rocks. One rock went through a camper's tent and struck a person inside. All these incidents have been reported to the police and to the Ministers responsible for tourism and police. The operator, Mr Lars Winberg, says he has no faith in the willingness of the police to do anything about this. They know who does this but no action is taken.

Mr Charlie Brignell from Wandering Albatross, another group, had a group of guides on a training camp in the Tahune Reserve in late November last year.
