This group was also abused by the gang; the incident included shots being fired into the air. Now when they take tourists into the area they do not stay overnight if there is any sign of this gang. He feels that reporting it to the police is useless because they will do nothing, and indeed have done nothing when other operators have reported similar attacks. Mr Brignell says that there is also concern about recriminations from the gang if they are reported.

The situation now is that there are some people who are protesting about forest activity in the area. The protesters who are at the blockade which has been established there are also convinced that this violence is not new and is not happening just because the protesters are in the area. The tourist operators are justifiably angry that nothing has been done previously. They have expressed real concern that it will not be long before somebody takes the law into his own hands and people will be seriously hurt.
Rumours abound about gangs and teams ready to `take out' the protesters. This becomes more likely when the government of

SPEECH.PARA: the day in Tasmania virtually says that the blockaders are getting what they asked for.
Let me quote from the Examiner in Launceston of Wednesday, 26 February:
Earlier the Tasmanian Logging Association warned that the Government must intervene in the next two days to prevent a dangerous physical confrontation between industry workers and the demonstrators.

PARA.TAB: TLA executive Director Mr Bernard Saunders said that because of Government inactivity, the people of nearby Geeveston had action plans to `clean up their own backyard'. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that this is not the sort of attitude which any of us can proudly call an Australian attitude. There is no place in our society for this sort of violence. We come to this chamber to make laws for the good government of this country. We make no laws that permit or condone in any way the attitude that is evidenced by what I have said to the chamber tonight. We cannot possibly endorse this attitude.

PARA.TAB: I alert the Senate that on the next day of sitting I shall be asking the Senate to express its disapproval of the lack of effective action by Tasmanian governments. This disgrace is not restricted to Tasmania. Just today I have received desperate communications from people in Queensland who are terrified that the Douglas Shire Council, the Departments of Lands, Mines, Police and the National Parks and Wildlife Service will not protect people who are being threatened by the sort of gangland attitude that I have described as existing in Tasmania's Picton forests.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) With the takeover of the Fairfax media empire by Kerry Packer, what proportion of the Australian print media and electronic media would be controlled by Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer.
(2) What are the estimated earnings from the Australian media empires owned by Messrs Murdoch and Packer.
(3) What proportion of these earnings is paid in tax to the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) On 13 December 1991 the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) announced that it was satisfied that Mr Kerry Packer had withdrawn from the Tourang consortium bidding for Fairfax. The ABT was informed by Tourang that no arrangements exist for Mr Packer to return to the consortium.

(2) The only publicly available material on Mr Packer's earnings is in the returns of Consolidated Press Holdings (CPH), lodged with the Australian Securities Commission. From those returns, it is not possible to isolate the magazine and television activities of Mr Kerry Packer from his other business activities.

CPH, (excluding media interests) is involved in chemical manufacture, resort operations and primary production. According to the latest annual accounts for the financial year 1989-90, CPH reported pre-tax earnings of $182.7m. Prima facie tax payable on this amount would be $71.2m but due to allowable deductions CPH paid tax of $17.0m.

Nine Network Australia Limited (NNAL), of which CPH owns a 39% share, reported a preliminary pre-tax operating profit of $55.7m for 1990-91. In its preliminary accounts, NNAL has allowed a provision for tax of $20.8m (after abnormals) which is approximately the normal company tax rate of 39 cents in the dollar on reported earnings.

The estimated earnings of the Australian media interests of Mr Rupert Murdoch are not distinguishable from his other interests in the accounts of News Corporation. According to the preliminary accounts of News Corporation for 1990-91, the interests of all News Corporation subsidiaries in the Australia/Pacific basin reported earnings before interest and tax of $332m (down $94m on the previous year). Some of these subsidiaries are involved in activities other than print and electronic media. It is not possible to establish from these accounts the amount of tax paid to the Australian Taxation Office by these Australian/Pacific Basin interests.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Mr Packer's private company CPH paid 9% of its 1989-90 net earnings in tax. Nine Network Australia Ltd has made provision to pay tax of 41% of earnings in 1990-91.

PARA.TAB: It is not possible to establish from the published accounts of News Corporation or News Ltd the amount of tax paid to the Australian Taxation Office by the Australian media interests of either company.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there a limited capacity on STD lines from Brisbane to Cairns at weekends.
(2) What is the daily average number of STD calls from Brisbane to Cairns (including weekends).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from AOTC, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The STD lines catering for calls from Brisbane to Cairns during weekdays remain fully available for weekend call traffic. However, the level of traffic generated between 6.30pm and 9.30pm on Sundays exceeds the available capacity and network congestion does occur.

Although call traffic at all other times does not exceed the existing available capacity, AOTC is currently providing additional circuits between Brisbane and Cairns which will increase the existing capacity by 44 per cent. This is to cater for future demand throughout the entire week and should also eliminate the congestion currently experienced on Sunday evenings. Work is scheduled to be completed by mid March 1992.

(2) The average number of calls during weekdays ranges from nearly 90,000 on Mondays to 75,000 on Fridays, with in excess of 80,000 from Tuesdays to Thursdays. On Saturdays there is an average of 40,000 calls with approximately 60,000 calls on Sundays. A large proportion of calls on Sundays is made between 6.30pm and 9.30pm.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that the installation of airbags, as safety measures within a car, reduces the risk of death for drivers, according to the Medical Journal of Australia, by at least 14 per cent to 22 per cent.
(2) What has the Government done to encourage the use of airbags.
(3) Is the Minister aware that over 50 per cent of the retail cost of an airbag is sales tax and import duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The figures referred to by Senator Watson from the Medical Journal of Australia appear to come from a publication titled "Effectiveness of Safety Belts and Airbags in Preventing Fatal Injury" by Dr David Viano, a renowned biomechanical engineer from the United States of America.
Officers of the Federal Office of Road Safety are well aware of Dr Viano's work and have held detailed discussions with him in 1991.
The 14 per cent to 22 per cent reduction in risk of death to the driver refers to fitment of an airbag alone, ie when the occupant does not use any other form of restraint.
The report acknowledges that airbags have limited effectiveness in side impacts and are not effective in roll-overs.
The report notes that lap shoulder seat belts, as fitted in all Australian vehicles, provide 38 per cent to 46 per cent reduction in risk in all types of crashes.

Dr Viano estimates that when airbags are used in conjunction with lap shoulder seat belts, the combination has the potential to further reduce fatalities by 3 per cent to 5 per cent. Dr Viano acknowledges that this estimate is based on expert judgement and not on statistical methods applied to crash injury data. The statistical sample upon which this study was based did not contain crash data involving airbag equipped vehicles.

In other research based on actual crash data involving airbag equipped vehicles, the airbag when used alone is credited with reducing the fatality risk by about 21 per cent, and when used together with lap shoulder belts by about an additional 9 per cent.

In earlier research Dr Viano estimated that the combination of airbags and improved technology seat belts may be able to provide up to 15 per cent reduction in fatal injury risk beyond that provided by basic lap shoulder belts. This estimate is based on the expectation of 100 per cent lap shoulder seat belt usage. If the more realistic seat belt usage rate of 80 per cent is assumed, Dr Viano estimates that a 5 per cent injury reduction risk can be expected.

Airbags can provide additional protection against injury in frontal and near frontal impacts. Research currently under way on behalf of the Government is seeking to identify the total reduction in road trauma (including injuries and fatalities) that can be expected in Australia, with various combinations of restraint improvements. This is expected to be published by the middle of 1992.
(2) The Australian motorist enjoys the benefit of vehicle safety standards which are amongst the most stringent in the world.

Our rules are largely harmonised with international standards, although Australia has led the world in a number of safety areas such as seat belts and safety requirements for Forward Control Passenger Vehicles.
The Government is determined that Australia will maintain its position at the forefront of international developments in vehicle safety.
We have taken the initiative of allocating an additional $10 million for road safety research and public education over the next three years.

The Government is actively pursuing future improvements in the level of protection offered by modern cars. A major study was commissioned in 1989 by the Federal Office of Road Safety to examine how vehicles are performing in real life crashes with a view to identifying areas for improvement.

This report recommends the examination of a number of measures to improve occupant protection. This research is well advanced and results are expected by the middle of 1992; airbags are only one of these measures.
From the Australian point of view, the debate focuses on how to achieve the optimum protection against the background of our high seat belt wearing rates.
In recent years, dramatic developments in seat belts and a range of new safety technologies have offered an effective alternative to airbags. We need to look at all these options.

The cost of airbags is still high in spite of the economies of scale. Airbags have to be engineered into a vehicle from the early design stages. They are not simply `add-on' options like a different sound system.
(3) The recent media attention on the sales tax and import duty on airbags has focused on vehicle models near the luxury tax threshold.

We have put in place a comprehensive test and research program to determine the real facts and provide guidance on the most cost effective way to ensure the level of safety enjoyed by all Australian motorists continues to be at the forefront of international standards.

The National Road Trauma Advisory Council has considered the sales tax applying to vehicle safety items. I understand that the Council is to recommend to the Government that innovative vehicle safety items such as airbags and high technology seat belts supplied over and above the requirements in vehicle safety standards should be exempt from sales tax. The issue of sales tax exemptions will be considered when the Council's final report has been received.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 14 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is there a limited capacity on STD lines from Brisbane to Cairns on Sundays.
(2) What is the daily average number of STD calls from Brisbane to Cairns (including weekends).
(3) Has consideration been given to allowing Sunday concessional rates to apply on Saturdays in order to spread the concessional traffic over both days.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from AOTC, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The STD lines catering for calls from Brisbane to Cairns during weekdays remain fully available for Sunday call traffic. However, the level of traffic generated between 6.30pm and 9.30pm on Sundays exceeds the available capacity and network congestion does occur.

Although call traffic at all other times does not exceed the existing available capacity, AOTC is currently providing additional circuits between Brisbane and Cairns which will increase the existing capacity by 44 per cent. This is to cater for future demand throughout the entire week and should also eliminate the congestion currently experienced on Sunday evenings. Work is scheduled to be completed by mid March 1992.

(2) The average number of calls during weekdays ranges from nearly 90,000 on Mondays to 75,000 on Fridays, with in excess of 80,000 from Tuesdays to Thursdays. On Saturdays there is an average of 40,000 calls with approximately 60,000 calls on Sundays. A large proportion of calls on Sundays is made between 6.30pm and 9.30pm.

(3) The concessional rate which applies on Sunday commences at 6pm Saturday and remains unchanged till 8am Monday. Call patterns show that the STD line capacity is under-utilised for most of this period. AOTC continues to advertise the extent of the concessional rate but customers have shown a preference to call within a short time period on Sunday evening.

Although AOTC does not intend to extend the Economy rate to include all day Saturday for all customers, flexi-calling plans to be introduced shortly will give customers greater flexibility to choose a plan which offers discounted rates over periods other than those currently offered. One option will include concessional rates from Friday evening until Monday morning.
The introduction of these options, combined with the increased capacity currently being provided between Brisbane and Cairns, should alleviate current call congestion experienced on Sunday evenings.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 3 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the self-regulatory code on the treatment of violence on television, in particular, the six o'clock news reported by the commercial channels where graphic and often violent television, for example, intrusions into cases of private grief, lack of care in the reporting of suicide and disasters, accidents, terrorist attacks, murders and executions are depicted:
(1) Is there a lack of compliance and adherence of the television stations to this code.
(2) What action can be taken to ensure that television stations comply with the code.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The television industry's Code on the Portrayal of Violence on Television which was launched in March 1991, was developed by the industry in conjunction with the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. In answering these questions I have obtained information from the Tribunal as it has an ongoing monitoring and reviewing role regarding the code.
(1) Since its implementation, the Tribunal has been provided with an opportunity to assess the effectiveness of the Code as a consequence of the Strathfield shootings in August 1991.

The Tribunal received very little complaint about the television coverage of the shootings. However, it assessed the television coverage against the criteria of the News and Current Affairs guidelines of the television industry's Violence Code. It found that the coverage was consistent with requirements of the Code, which indicated that the Code was being effectively applied by the industry.

It should also be noted that the Code is only one facet of the regulatory framework which relates to broadcasting of program material: the Tribunal's Television Program Standards (TPS) form the basis of the Code, and must be observed by all commercial television licensees.

TPS 5 particularly relates to the presentation of news programs during the 6.00pm time slot. This Standard says that news and current affairs programs may be transmitted during this time provided care is exercised in the selection and transmission of all sound and visual items.

(2) Administration of the Code is the day-to-day responsibility of the broadcasters. However, the Tribunal will review broadcasters' performance in relation to the Code during licence renewals, or if it has reason to believe that broadcasters are acting in serious or repeated disregard of the Code.
The industry also intends to review the Code every two years in light of prevailing community standards and has invited viewer comments on specific concerns and on the Code itself.
The Tribunal has a number of options open to it in cases of disregard of the Code; for example it can reprimand or admonish licensees, or put conditions on a licence.
